speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, first, the economy.

sentence: We know that not everyone is sharing in this prosperity.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And my plan would be to, first of all, make community college free and make sure that everyone else besides that top percentile gets help with their education.

sentence: My own dad and my sister got their first degrees with community college.

sentence: There's many paths to success, as well as certifications.

sentence: And then the third thing I would do is make it easier for students to pay off their student loans.

sentence: Because I can tell you this: If billionaires can pay off their yachts, students should be able to pay off their student loans.

sentence: I am just simply concerned about kicking half of America off of their health insurance in four years, which is exactly what this bill says.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There is a much bigger issue in addition to that, and that is pharmaceuticals.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The president literally went on TV, on Fox, and said that people's heads would spin when they see how much he would bring down pharmaceutical prices.

sentence: Instead, 2,500 drugs have gone up in double-digits since he came into office.

sentence: For the rest of us, for the rest of America, that's what we call at home all foam and no beer.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We got nothing out of it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And so my proposal is to do something about pharma, to take them on, to allow negotiation under Medicare, to bring in less expensive drugs from other countries.

sentence: And pharma thinks they own Washington?

sentence: Well, they don't own me.

sentence: I just want to say, there's three women up here that have fought pretty hard for a woman's right to choose.

sentence: I'll start with that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then I just want to make very clear, I think we share the goal of universal health care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the idea I put out there, the public option, which the governor was just talking about, this idea is that you use Medicare or Medicaid without any insurance companies involved, you can do it either way.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the estimates are 13 million people would see a reduction in their premiums, 12 more million people would get covered.

sentence: So I think it is a beginning and the way you start and the way you move to universal health care.

sentence: Yes.

sentence: But I do think you want to make sure that you have provisions in place that allow you to go after traffickers and allow you to go after people who are violating the law.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What I really think we need to step back and talk about is the economic imperative here.

sentence: And that is that 70 of our Fortune 500 companies are headed by people that came from other countries.

sentence: And so my proposal is to look at that 2013 bill that passed the Senate with Republican support, to upgrade that bill, to make it as good as possible and get it done.

sentence: It brings the doubt down by $158 billion.

sentence: It gives a path for citizenship for citizen -- for people who can become citizens.

sentence: And it will be so much better for our economy in America.

sentence: It was imperfect, but it was a good deal for that moment.

sentence: I would have worked to get longer sunset periods, and that's something we could negotiate, to get back in the deal.

sentence: But the point is, Donald Trump told us when he got out of it that he was going to give us a better deal.

sentence: Those were his words.

sentence: And now we are a month away from the Iranians, who claim now that they're going blow the caps on enriching uranium.

sentence: So what I would do is negotiate us back into that agreement, is stand with our allies, and not give unlimited leverage to China and Russia, which is what he has done.

sentence: And then, finally, I would make sure that if there is any possibility of a conflict -- and we're having this debate in Congress right now -- that he comes to Congress for an authorization of military force.

sentence: My life and my career and my work in the Senate has been about economic opportunity.

sentence: And when you want an economy that works, you need to have retirement that works, you need to have public schools that work.

sentence: So in short, we need, one -- and I will do this in my first 100 days as president -- we will work to make sure everyone can vote at this table, everyone can vote in this country...

sentence: ... but if we let the Republicans run our elections and if do not do something about Russian interference in the election and we let Mitch McConnell stop all the backup paper ballots, then we're not going to get what we want to do.

sentence: Three things to know about me.

sentence: I think you know that I don't agree with some of these proposals up here, George, so I'm talking about...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If I could - if I could respond to some of the proposals from my friends.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: First of all, Senator Sanders and I have worked valiantly to bring down the cost of pharmaceuticals.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That was a Klobuchar-Sanders Amendment to allow for drugs to come in from less expensive countries like Canada.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have worked to bring down the cost by fighting to allow 43 million seniors, that's a bill I lead, to negotiate for better prices under Medicare.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I figure that's a lot of seniors and they should be allowed to get a better price.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But when it comes to our health care and when it comes to our premiums, I go with the doctor's creed, which is, do no harm.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And while Bernie wrote the bill, I read the bill.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And on page eight - on page eight of the bill, it says that we will no longer have private insurance as we know it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that means that 149 million Americans will no longer be able to have their current insurance.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's in four years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I don't think that's a bold idea, I think it's a bad idea.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what I favor is something that what Barack Obama wanted to do from the very beginning.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is a public option.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: A non-profit choice that would bring down the cost of insurance, cover 12 million more people, and bring down the prices for 13 million more people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is a bold idea.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Current health insurance.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yes, but a house - a house divided cannot stand.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is not how we're going to win this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's not my record.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We are here at a historically black college.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think of an alum of that college, Barbara Jordan, and something that she once said.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: She said, "What the people want is simple; they want a country as good as its promise."

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that same can be said of the criminal justice system.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So when I was there, the way we handled these police shootings, I actually took a stand to make sure outside investigators handled them.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I took on our major police chief in Minneapolis.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But in the prosecutor's office, they were handled with a grand jury.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's how they were all handled across our state.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I now believe it is better for accountability if the prosecutor handles them and makes those decisions herself.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That aside, I am proud of the work our staff did, 400 people in our office.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The cases that came to us, the African-American community that came to us, they said there was no justice for their little kids.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There was a kid named Byron Phillips that was shot on his front porch.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: No one had bothered to figure out who did it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When I came into that office, we worked with the community groups; we put up billboards; we found the shooter and we put him in jail.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We did the same for the killer of a little girl named Tyesha Edwards who was doing her homework at her kitchen table and was shot through the window.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What changes did we make?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Go after white-collar crimes in a big way, diversity the office in a big way, work with the Innocence Project to make sure we do much better with eyewitness ID.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And as a senator and as your president, I will make sure that we don't just do the First Step Act when it comes to criminal sentencing, that we move to the Second Step Act, which means the 90 percent of people that are incarcerated in local and state jails, let's reduce those sentences for nonviolent offenders and let's get them jobs and let them vote when they get out of prison.
LAW: the Second Step Act;the First Step Act;

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I so appreciate what the congressman's been doing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I want to remind people here that what unites us is so much bigger than what divides us.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Everyone up here favors an assault weapon ban.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Everyone up here favors magazine limitations, which, by the way, would have made a huge difference if that was in place in El Paso, in that store, where all those ordinary people showed such extraordinary courage.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And certainly in Dayton, Ohio, where in 30 seconds, one man guns down innocent people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The cops got there in one minute, and it still wasn't enough to save those people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what unites us.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You know what else unites us?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I'll tell you this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What unites us is that right now, on Mitch McConnell's desk, are three bills - universal background checks, closing the Charleston loophole, and passing my bill to make sure that domestic abusers don't get AK-47s.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So if we want to get something done - and I personally think we should start with a voluntary buyback program.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what I think, David.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But I want to finish this, because if you want action now, if you want action now, we got to send a message to Mitch McConnell.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We can't wait until one of us gets in the White House.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have to pass those bills right now to get this done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Because we cannot spare another innocent life.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What we've got right now, though, George, it's not a focused tariff on steel.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What he has done here, he has assessed these tariffs on our allies.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He has put us in the middle of this trade war and he is treating our farmers and our workers like poker chips in one of his bankrupt casinos.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And if we are not careful, he is going to bankrupt this country.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: One forecast recently says that it has already cost us 300,000 jobs, all right?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There is soybeans that are mounting up in bins all over the Midwest, in my state of Minnesota and in Iowa.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So what I think we need to do is to go back to the negotiating table - that's what I would do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I wouldn't have put all these tariffs in place.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I wouldn't have had a trade policy where on August 1st he announces he's going to have tariffs on $300 billion of goods, on August 13th, he cuts it in half, a week later, he says he's going to reduce taxes, the day after that, he says he's going to do it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The leaders of the world are watching this, and it undermines our strength as a nation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And, yes, we want fair trade, but we must work with the rest of the world.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he has made a mockery of focused trade policy, which I think means enforcement, like we've done in northern Minnesota, passing bills, getting President Obama to do more on that, so that our workers can benefit, so we are importing, exporting goods and making sure that it's a competitive policy where our goal is that we are making things, inventing things, and exporting to the world.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He is defeating that goal.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is the existential crisis of our time.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's - you know that movie "The Day after Tomorrow"?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's today.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have seen a warming in our world like never before.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We're seeing flooding in the Midwest, flooding in Houston, fires in the West.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think having someone leading the ticket from the Midwest will allow us to talk about this in a different way and get it done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day one, I will get us back into the international climate change agreement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day two, I will bring back the clean power rules that President Obama had worked on.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day three, I will bring back the gas mileage standards.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You can do all that without Congress, which is good.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day four, five, and six I will, working with Congress and mayors and business people all over the country, introduce sweeping legislation to get at that 2050 goal.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And on day seven, you're supposed to rest, but I won't.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is what we need to do if we're going to get at climate change.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have to take this on as a crisis that's happening right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My challenges and resilience have brought me up here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I grew up with a dad who struggled with alcoholism his whole life.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And after his third DWI, he had a choice between jail and treatment.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He chose treatment, with his faith, with his friends, with our family.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And in his words, he was pursued by grace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that made me interested in public service, because I feel like everyone should have that same right, to be pursued by grace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I then got married.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My husband's out there somewhere, hopefully smiling, and our daughter.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When our daughter was born, I had this expectation, we're going to have this perfect, perfect birth, and she was really sick, and she couldn't swallow.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And she was in and out of hospitals for a year-and-a-half.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But when she was born, they had a rule in place that you got kicked out of the hospital in 24 hours.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: She was in intensive care, and I was kicked out.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I thought, this could never happen to any other mom again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I went to the legislature, our state legislator, not an elected official, a mom, and I advocated for one of the first laws in the country guaranteeing new moms and their babies a 48-hour hospital stay.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when they tried to delay the implementation of that law, I brought six pregnant friends to the conference committee so they outnumbered the lobbyists 2 to 1.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when they said, when should it take place, they all raised their hands and said now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is what motivated me to go into public service.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when I got to that gridlock of Washington, D.C., I got to work and pass over 100 bills, and I know a lot of my friends here from the left, but remember, I am from the middle of the country.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I believe, if we're going to get things done, that we have to have someone leading the ticket with grit, someone who's going to not just change the policies, but change the tone in the country, and someone who believes in America and believes it from their heart because of where they came from, that everyone should have that same opportunity.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We can do two things at once.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's our job.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have a constitutional duty to pursue this impeachment, but we also can stand up for America, because this president has not been putting America in front of his own personal interests.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He has not been standing up for the workers of Ohio.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He's not been standing up for the farmers in Iowa.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I take this even a step further.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You know, when he made that call to the head of Ukraine, he's digging up dirt on an opponent.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's illegal conduct.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what he was doing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He didn't talk to him about the Russian invasion.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He talked to him about that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I'm still waiting to find out from him how making that call to the head of Ukraine and trying to get him involved in interfering in our election makes America great again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I'd like to hear from him about how leaving the Kurds for slaughter, our allies for slaughter, where Russia then steps in to protect them, how that makes America great again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I would like to hear from him about how coddling up to Vladimir Putin makes America great again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It doesn't make America great again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It makes Russia great again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is what this president has done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So whether it is workers' issues, whether it is farmers' issues, he has put his own private interests ...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... and I will not do that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: At least Bernie's being honest here and saying how he's going to pay for this and that taxes are going to go up.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I'm sorry, Elizabeth, but you have not said that, and I think we owe it to the American people to tell them where we're going to send the invoice.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I believe the best and boldest idea here is to not trash Obamacare but to do exactly what Barack Obama wanted to do from the beginning and that's have a public option that would bring down the cost of the premium and expand the number of people covered and take on the pharmaceutical companies.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is what we should be doing instead of kicking 149 million people off their insurance in our years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I'm tired of hearing, whenever I say these things, oh, it's Republican talking points.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You are making Republican talking points right now in this room by coming out for a plan that's going to do that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think there is a better way that is bold, that will cover more people, and it's the one we should get behind.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yes, I do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I appreciate Elizabeth's work.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But, again, the difference between a plan and a pipe dream is something that you can actually get done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we can get this public option done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we can take on the pharmaceutical companies and bring down the prices.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But what really bothers me about this discussion, which we've had so many times, is that we don't talk about the things that I'm hearing about from regular Americans.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is long-term care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We are seeing -- I once called it a silver tsunami.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The aging -- and then someone told me that was too negative, so I call it the silver surge -- the aging of the population.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need to make easier to get long-term care insurance and strengthen Medicaid.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: In this state, the state of Ohio, that has been hit by the opioid epidemic, we need to take on those pharma companies and make them pay for the addictions that they have caused and the people that they have killed.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Those are the issues that I hear about when I'm in Toledo.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It could work.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I am open to it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But I want to give a reality check here to Elizabeth, because no one on this stage wants to protect billionaires.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Not even the billionaire wants to protect billionaires.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We just have different approaches.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Your idea is not the only idea.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when I look at this, I think about Donald Trump, the guy that after that tax bill passed went to Mar-a-Lago, got together with his cronies, and said, guess what, you guys all got a lot richer.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That was the one time in his presidency he told the truth.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So we have different ways -- I would repeal significant portions of that tax bill that help the rich, including what he did with the corporate tax rate, including what he did on international taxation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You add it all up, you got a lot of money that, one, helps pay for that childcare, protects that dignity of work, makes sure we have decent retirement, and makes sure that our kids can go to good schools.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is not one idea that rules here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would like to respond to that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You know, I think simply because you have different ideas doesn't mean you're fighting for regular people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I wouldn't even be up on this stage if it wasn't for unions and the dignity of work.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If my grandpa didn't have unions protecting him in those mines, he wouldn't have survived.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If my mom didn't have unions as a teacher, she wouldn't have been able to make the wages she made when my parents got divorced.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So just because we have different ideas, and get to the same place in terms of beating Donald Trump and taking this on, we are in Ohio.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We can win Ohio in the presidency, but only if we unite, if we unite around ideals and don't go fighting against each other and instead take the fight to him.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need to work with our allies, to work with Turkey and bring them out.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is an outrageous thing that happened here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think we need to talk about this not only in terms of the horror of what happened here with Turkey, but the fact that our president blew it and now he's too proud to say it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what do we do now?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We continue that humanitarian aid, but then we work with our allies to say come back, Turkey, and stop this, because what Mayor Pete has just said is true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Think about our other allies, Israel.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: How do they feel right now?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Donald Trump is not true to his word when they are a beacon of democracy in the Mideast.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Think about our allies in Europe when he pulls out of the Iranian agreement and gives them holding the bag and gives the power to China and Russia.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Think about the nuclear agreement with Russia that he precipitously pulled out of.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is part of a pattern.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's not an isolated incident.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I want to respond to Mr.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yang.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I want to respond to Mr.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yang.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I don't see a moral equivalency between our country and Russia.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Vladimir Putin is someone who has shot down planes over Ukraine, who has poisoned his opponent, and we have not talked about what we need to do to protect ourselves from Russia invading our election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This wasn't meddling.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what I do when I call my daughter on a Saturday night and ask her what she's doing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Sorry.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This was much more serious than that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This was actually invading our election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So to protect ourselves in 2020, what we need, one, backup paper ballots in every single state.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is a bill that I need, and we need to stop Mitch McConnell from stopping that from happening.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then we need to stop the social media companies from running paid political ads, including ones last time in rubles, without having to say where those ads came from and who paid for them.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's the Honest Ads Act.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's a bipartisan bill that I lead.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we can't wait...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... to become president to get that done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need to get it done now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just keep thinking of how close we are to finally getting something done on this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I'm looking at the mayor of Dayton.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I met one of the survivors from that shooting, 30 seconds, nine people killed.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The public is with us on this in a big way.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The majority of Trump voters want to see universal background checks right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The majority of hunters want to see us move forward with gun safety legislation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There are three bills right now on Mitch McConnell's desk, the background check bill, my bill to close the boyfriend loophole so domestic abusers don't get guns, the bill to make it easier for police to vet people before they get a gun.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what we should be focusing on.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I just don't want to screw this up.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When I'm president, I do want to bring in an assault weapon ban and I do want to put a limitation on magazines so what happened in Dayton, Ohio, will never happen again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But let's not mess this up with this fight.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, I want to thank her for this question.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is something that should never have happened to begin with.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I remember, when I was a prosecutor, these were not the kind of cases that were coming in our door.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And it's gotten worse and worse.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we now know why.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As the evidence is coming out of those lawsuits, probably one of the most horrible things that I saw was the e-mail from one of the pharma executives that actually said, "Keep pumping them out.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They're eating them like Doritos."

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So my first answer to that question, and which is included in my plan, is that the people that should pay for this, that should pay for the treatment, are the very people that got people hooked and killed them in the first place.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is the people that are manufacturing these opioids.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's the first way.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And you can, with a 2 cents per milligram tax, bring in the money, plus with the federal master settlement, to help rural areas where they're so isolated, and also in urban areas, where it's, by the way, not just opiates.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There are still mental health issues and crack cocaine issues.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is personal for me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My dad, he struggled with alcoholism his whole life.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And by his third DWI, they said to him, the prosecutor, you've got to face jail or you got to go to treatment.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He picked treatment, and he was pursued by grace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he has been sober ever since.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And now he's 91 and in assisted living, and he said to me last year, it's hard to get a drink around here, anyway.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But he still has an AA group that visits him there.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And so for me, I believe that everyone in this country, including the people in rural America, have that same right to be pursued by grace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would like to have a different take on this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I was in the private sector for 14 years, represented companies that were fighting to get into the telecom markets.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I had a life before government.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what I saw was when we got more competition there, the prices went down in a big way in the long distance market.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, right now we have another gilded age going on, and I am the lead Democrat on the Antitrust Committee.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have the lead legislation, which means, one, changing the standard so we can do a better job of doing just what we've been talking about here, is breaking down some of this consolidation, and also making sure that the enforcers have the resources to take them on because they're so overwhelmed.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But the issue here is this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Start talking about this as a pro-competition issue.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This used to be a Republican and Democratic issue, because America, our founding fathers, actually wanted to have less consolidation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We were a place of entrepreneurship.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We are seeing a startup slump in this country.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And this means everything from tech on down.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would codify Roe v.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Wade and make it the law of the land.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But what I want to do right now is just say, what if Donald Trump was standing up here on the debate stage with me?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You know what I would say to him?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I said, you knew -- you said you wanted to do this in your race for president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You actually said that you wanted to put women in jail.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Then you tried to dial it back, and you said you wanted to put doctors in jail.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is exactly what the Alabama law is.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It put doctors in jail for 99 years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You, Donald Trump, are not on the side of women.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You are not on the side of people of this country, when over 75 percent of people want to keep Roe v.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Wade on the book, when over 90 percent of people want to make sure we have available contraception.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You defunded Planned Parenthood.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would fund it again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You know, this isn't a flyover part of the country to me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The heartland is where I live.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I want to win those states that we lost last time, and I have bold ideas to get us there.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think just because they're different than Elizabeth's doesn't mean they're bold.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But we can't get any of this done on climate change or immigration reform unless they win.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what I have done is win and the only one up here, time and time again, the reddest of red districts, Michele Bachmann's, I -- I won that district three times, rural districts that border Iowa and North and South Dakota.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I do it by going not just where it's comfortable but where it's uncomfortable.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is why I have been in Pennsylvania and in Michigan and in Wisconsin and all over Ohio and in Iowa, because I think we need to build a blue Democratic wall around those states and make Donald Trump pay for it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: For me, it's John McCain, and I miss him every day.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I traveled all over the world with him.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he would sometimes, when we were seated with world leaders, and they would look away from me, he'd say, "Senator Klobuchar is the lead Democrat on this trip, and she will go next."

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I still remember being there at his ranch.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: John and I went to visit him and Cindy when he was dying.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he pointed to some words in his book, because he could hardly talk.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the words says this: "There is nothing more liberating in life than fighting for a cause larger than yourself."

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what we're doing right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And while we have had major debates about policy, we have to remember that what unites us is so much bigger than what divides us.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we have to remember that our job is to not just change policy, but to change the tone in our politics, to look up from our phones, to look at each other, to start talking to each other, because the way we win -- and not just win the presidency, but take back the U.S.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Senate -- is by winning big.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the way we win big is with that fired up Democratic base that's out there today, but it is also about bringing in independents and moderate Republicans.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I can lead this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I ask you to join me because I've done it before and I will do it again, amyklobuchar.com.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Join our team.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have made it very clear that this is impeachable conduct and I've called for an impeachment proceeding.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just believe our job as jurors is to look at each count and make a decision.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But let me make very clear that what this impeachment proceeding about is really our democracy at stake.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is a president that not only with regard to his conduct with Ukraine, but every step of the way puts his own private interests, his own partisan interests, his own political interests in front of our country's interest, and this is wrong.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is a pattern with this man.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And it goes to everything from how he has betrayed our farmers and our workers to what he has done with foreign affairs, leaving the Kurds for slaughter, sucking up to Vladimir Putin every minute of the day.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is what this guy does.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think it is very, very important that we have a president that's going to put our country first.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I was thinking about this when I was at the Carter Presidential Museum.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And on the wall are etched the words of Walter Mondale when he looked back at their four years, not perfect.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he said this: We told the truth, we obeyed the law, we kept the peace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We told the truth, we obeyed the law, we kept the peace.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is the minimum that we should expect in a president of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, I just -- I'm someone that doesn't come from money, and I appreciate the work of Mr.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Steyer.

sentence: But right now, we have a system that's not fair, and it's not just fair for money.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And so I would do is start a constitutional amendment and pass it to overturn Citizens United.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what we should do, so that we stop this dark money and outside money from coming into our politics.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have led the way on voting.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I can tell you right now, one solution that would make a huge difference in this state would be to allow every kid in the country to register to vote when they turn 18.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If we had a system like this, and we did something about gerrymandering, and we stopped the voting purges, and we did something significant about making sure we don't have money in politics from the outside, Stacey Abrams would be governor of this state right now.

sentence: And that's what should happen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So while I appreciate his work, I am someone that doesn't come from money.

sentence: I raised $17,000 from ex-boyfriends.

sentence: And I'd like to point out, it is not an expanding base.

sentence: So I don't just think this with my head.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I feel it in my heart.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: First of all, I've made very clear I think that Pete is qualified to be up on this stage, and I am honored to be standing next to him.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But what I said was true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Women are held to a higher standard.

sentence: Otherwise, we could play a game called name your favorite woman president, which we can't do, because it has all been men.

sentence: And including all vice presidents being men.

sentence: And I think any working woman out there, any woman that's at home knows exactly what I mean.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have to work harder, and that's a fact.

sentence: But I want to dispel one thing, because for so long why has this been happening?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I don't think you have to be the tallest person on this stage to be president.

sentence: I don't think you have the loudest voice on this stage.

sentence: I don't think that means that you will be the one that should be president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think what matters is if you're smart, if you're competent, and if you get things done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I am the one that has passed over a hundred bills as the lead Democrat in that gridlock of Washington in Congress on this stage.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think you've got to win.

sentence: I govern both with my head and my heart.

sentence: And if you think a woman can't beat Donald Trump, Nancy Pelosi does it every single day.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I've looked at this economically, and I want to make sure that we help people.

sentence: Because as just pointed out, we are way behind the curve, our country is, when it comes to providing paid family leave and childcare.

sentence: We must do this and we will do this if we have the right person heading up the ticket so we can win big.

sentence: But what I have done with all of my plans is I have shown how I'm going to pay for them meticulously.

sentence: I think that is really, really important when we have a president in the White House right now one who has told over 10,000 lies.

sentence: So when you look at my website, at amyklobuchar.com, you will see my plans and you're also going to see how I'm going to pay for it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think that is so important, because this president is literally increasing the debt, treating our farmers and workers like poker chips in a bankrupt casino, and really putting this country in a worst financial situation every single day.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So, yes, my plan is three months.

sentence: I think that's good.

sentence: I'd love to do more.

sentence: As I've said before, I'd love to staple free diplomas under people's chairs.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just am not going to go for things -- and this is not -- I'm talking about Senator Harris' plan here, but I'm talking about some of the other ideas that have been out here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I am not going to go for things just because they sound good on a bumper sticker and then throw in a free car.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think that we have an obligation -- we have an obligation as a party to be, yes, fiscally responsible, yes, think big, but make sure we have people's backs and are honest with them about what we can pay for.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is everything from sending rich kids to college for free, which I don't support, to kicking 149 million off their health insurance -- current health insurance in four years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just think we have to be smart about how we do this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need a new foreign policy in this country, and that means renewing our relationships with our allies.

sentence: And it means reasserting our American values.

sentence: And so when the president did not stand up the way he should have to that killing and that dismemberment of a journalist with an American newspaper, that sent a signal to all dictators across the country that -- across the world that that was OK, and that's wrong.

sentence: And I want to add a few things to what my colleagues have said, first of all, the question about Russia.

sentence: When we look at international agreements, we must start negotiating back with Russia, which has been a horrible player on the international scene, but the president precipitously got out of the nuclear agreement with Russia and we must start negotiating, even though they were cheating, for the good of this world.

sentence: And we must also start the negotiations for the New START Treaty.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when it comes to China, we need someone that sees the long term, like I do, just like the Chinese do, because we have a president that literally makes decisions based on his next tweet, and they are in it for the long game.

sentence: And this president indicated early on what he was going to do, and he's done it.

sentence: When he was running for office, he literally said women should go to jail.

sentence: So no surprise that we're seeing these kinds of laws in Georgia, in Alabama, where his allies are passing these bills.

sentence: And I predict this will be a big election -- issue in the general election.

sentence: And I just can't wait to stand across from Donald Trump and say this to him.

sentence: You know what?

sentence: The people are with us.

sentence: Over 70 percent of the people support Roe v.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Wade.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Over 90 percent of the people support funding for Planned Parenthood and making sure that women can get the health care they need.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He is off the track on this, and he will hear from the women of America, and this is how we're going to win this election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just -- I want to add this...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I want to point out...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I agree with what the mayor has just said, but this is a good example where he has said the right words, but I actually have the experience and of leading 11 of the bills that are in that House-passed bill you just referred to.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think this kind of experience matters.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have been devoted to this from the time that I've got to the Senate.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think having that experience, knowing how you can get things done, leading the bills to take the social media companies to task, a bipartisan bill to say, yeah, you have to say where these ads come from and how they're paid for, and stop the unbelievable practice where we still have 11 states that don't have backup paper ballots.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is my bipartisan bill.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I am so close to getting it done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar

sentence: But just like I have won statewide and mayor, I have all appreciation for your good work as a local official, and you did not when you tried, I also have actually done this work.

sentence: If you want to join us and if you believe that our work doesn't end on Election Day, but begins on Inauguration Day, join us, amyklobuchar.com.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Let me make the case to the American people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As a wise judge said, the president is not king in America, the law is king.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what James Madison once said when he was speaking out at the Constitutional Convention -- and, by the way, I think he's a pretty good size for a president, he was five-foot-four.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what he said, he said the reason that we have these impeachment articles in the Constitution, that the provisions are in there, is because he feared that a president would betray the trust of the American people for a foreign power.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is what happened here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Watergate -- this is a global Watergate.

sentence: In the case of Watergate, a paranoid president facing election looked for dirt on a political opponent.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He did it by getting people to break in.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This president did it by calling a foreign leader to look for dirt on a political opponent.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I would make this case: as we face this trial in the Senate, if the president claims that he is so innocent, then why doesn't he have all the presidents men testify?

sentence: We should be hearing from Mulvaney, who is the one under oath.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We should hear from Bolton who told his own staff to go see a lawyer after they met with the president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is the case.

sentence: If President Trump thinks he should not be impeached, he should not be scared to put forward his own witnesses.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have a different view.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I'll go with my friend, Sherrod Brown, who has voted against every trade agreement that's come in front of him, and he's voting for this, and I am, too.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the reason I am voting for it is that I believe that we have a change with this agreement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would not have voted for the agreement that President Trump put forward, but we've got better labor standards, better environmental standards, and a better deal when it comes to the pharmaceutical provision, which I also opposed.

sentence: Ninety-five percent of our customers are outside of our borders.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we have to make sure that we have trade agreements that are more fair, because if we can encourage work made in America, every time you hold something in your hand that says "Made in America," it is the ingenuity of our workers, it is the quality of a product, it is equality of our workers, and it is the hopes and dreams of the American people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think this agreement -- while Senator Sanders is correct, there are some issues with it -- is much better than the one originally proposed.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And for those farmers in the Midwest and for those people that have been hurt by the fact that we will not have a trade segment with Mexico and with Canada and the United States, I think that this is a much better deal.

sentence: Well, I don't -- I very much hope we're not going to have to relocate entire cities, but we will probably have to relocate some individual residents.

sentence: And the problem right now is that this climate change is an existential crisis.

sentence: And you are seeing it here in California with the fires that you just had.

sentence: You saw it in Northern California, as was mentioned with Paradise.

sentence: And the most moving video from that to me was the 30-second video of that dad driving his little girl through the lapping fires with his neighborhood burning behind him and singing to her to calm her down.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We cannot wait to act.

sentence: There is an Ojibway saying that great leaders make decisions not for this generation, but seven generations from now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This president doesn't keep his decisions for seven minutes.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So what I think we need to do, get back into the international climate change agreement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will do that on day one.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day two, bring back the clean power rules.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: On day three, the gas mileage standards.

sentence: I see the governor of California, who's been working so hard to get those done, defied every step of the way by the Trump administration.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then introduce sweeping legislation to put a price on carbon and build a fridge to the next century, which means we must upgrade our buildings and our building standards.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yeah, I want to add to what Elizabeth said.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So the way we tackle corruption is by winning big in this election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the way we take on climate change in a big way is by, yes, talking about what's happening on the coasts, as I just did, but also talking about what's happening in the Midwest, where I'm from.

sentence: It's not flyover country to me.

sentence: And when we make these changes, we have to make clear to people that when we put a price on carbon, that that money is going to come back to those areas where people are going to be hurt, where jobs are going to change, and to make them whole with their energy bills.

sentence: When you make the case like that, you bring in the Midwestern votes.

sentence: You win big.

sentence: And I think the best way to do it is by putting someone at the top of the ticket who is from the Midwest.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You're looking at it.

sentence: And we are not going to be able to succeed in the world if we do not invite everyone to be part of our economy.

sentence: Our Constitution says that we strive for a more perfect union.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, that's what we are doing right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And to me, that means, one, that everyone can vote, and that includes our communities of color.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This action that's been taken by this president and his people and his governors all over the country is wrong.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They have made it harder for African-Americans to vote, as one court said, discriminated with surgical precision.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: What would I do?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As one of the leaders on voting in the U.S.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Senate, one, stop the purging.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As Stacey Abrams said, you know, you do not stop having your right to assemble if you don't go to a meeting for a year.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Because you don't go to a church or a synagogue or a mosque for three months, you don't lose your right to worship.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You shouldn't lose your right to vote.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would pass as president my bill to register every kid in this country when they turn 18 to vote.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That would make all of these discriminatory actions in these states go away.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I would stop the gerrymandering, in addition to the agenda of economic opportunity, because as Martin Luther King said, what good is it to integrate a lunch counter if you can't afford a hamburger?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When it comes to foreign policy, I think we need to keep our promises and keep our threats.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And this president has done neither.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: In a country like China, their leaders, they watch that and they know.

sentence: He has stood with dictators over innocents.

sentence: He has stood with tyrants over free leaders.

sentence: And I have a little different take than some of my colleagues when it comes to what happened at that conference with NATO.

sentence: Yeah, they were making fun of them, some of the foreign leaders.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I've heard senators make more fun of other senators than that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The point of it was that he couldn't even tolerate it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He is so thin-skinned that he walked.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He quit.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: America doesn't quit.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So if we want to send a message to the Chinese, we stand with our allies.

sentence: We stand with them firmly.

sentence: We have a very clear and coherent foreign policy when it comes to human rights.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: returning to sanity.

sentence: Could I respond?
