sentence: OK.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just want to make very clear, Mayor, that the freedom of the press is deep in my heart.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My dad was a newspaperman.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I am the one that asked every attorney general candidate we've had under Donald Trump, both of whom I opposed, about their respect for the First Amendment.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And they have refused, they have refused to follow the rules that Attorney General Holder put in place when it came to protecting our journalists.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They would not commit that they wouldn't put a journalist in jail for doing their job.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So this is not just talking points to me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is the real world.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think that experience that I will bring to the White House, with protecting the First Amendment, is worth more than any talking points.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you for asking a woman this question.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: First of all, we have not had enough women in our government.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When I was on Trevor Noah's show once, I explained how in the history of the Senate, there was something like 2,000 men and only 50 women in the whole history.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And he said if a nightclub had numbers that bad, they would shut it down.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: However, it is not just about numbers.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's about what you get done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is my argument.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If you look at the poll -- the state that knows me best, and that is the state of Minnesota, it showed in the state that Hillary had her lowest margin of victory, it showed that I'd beat Donald Trump by 18 points.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I beat him with men more than anyone on this stage.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I think what matters in this election is, can you bring in those rural and suburban areas, particularly in the Midwest?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And number two, what will you do when you get there?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I am someone that has passed over 100 bills, with men and women, with Republicans and with Democrats, including changing the sexual harassment laws for the United States Congress, a bill I led so taxpayers are no longer going to have to pay for people that harass other people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have passed a law for drug shortages.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have done work in our rural areas.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think that's what most matters to people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would be so proud to be the first woman president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But mostly I want to be a president that gets things done and improves people's lives.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Judy -- Judy...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I did not come here to listen to this argument.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I came here to make a case for progress.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have never even been to a wine cave.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I've been to the wind cave in South Dakota, which I suggest you go to.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So what is making a case for progress about?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is what unites us up here instead of what divides us, which is campaign finance reform.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That means passing a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It means making the first bill we pass when I am president will be H.R. 1, which is the ethics reform passed in the House, which is currently sitting on Mitch McConnell's desk, along with 400 bills.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And if you don't think we can get this done, well, we can, but only if we win this election big.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Not by arguing with each other, but by finding what unites us and getting this done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I came to make a case for progress.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I address...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I address immigration reform?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I started my day-to-day with a group of immigrants who were there talking to me about housing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I thought about this president and what he's done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He has used our immigrants as political pawns.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Every single day, he tries to draw a wedge.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will be a different president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My view on this comes from experience.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When I got to the Senate, Senator Kennedy asked me to be one of the two new senators that was in the group to work on the immigration reform package.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We got so close to passing that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I voted for it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Not everyone did.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But most of the Democrats did.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Then I was on the Judiciary Committee when President Obama was president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we worked very hard on that immigration reform.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We actually passed that with Republican votes.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Then I was in the small group that worked on the compromise on the Dreamers that would have solved that problem.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We didn't get that done because this president gut-punched us.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will take my views.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will take this experience.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will get this done because immigrants don't diminish America.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They are America.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I respond?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, I was -- I was harkening back.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I made my case on immigration to what the mayor said about Washington.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I look at this a different way.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When we were in the last debate, Mayor, you basically mocked the hundred years of experience on the stage.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And what do I see on this stage?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I see Elizabeth's work starting the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and helping 29 million people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I see the vice president's work in getting $2 billion for his cancer moon shot.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I see Senator Sanders' work -- working to get the veterans bill passed across the aisle.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I see what I've done, which is to negotiate three farm bills and be someone that actually had major provisions put in those bills.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So while you can dismiss committee hearings, I think this experience works.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have not denigrated your experience as a local official.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have been one.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just think you should respect our experience when you look at how you evaluate someone who can get things done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Oh, I don't think we have bigger fish to fry than picking a president of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have been -- I certainly respect your military experience.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's not what this is about.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This is about choosing a president.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I know my view of this is I know you ran to be chair of the Democratic National Committee.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's not something that I wanted to do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I want to be president of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the point is, we should have someone heading up this ticket that has actually won and been able to show that they can gather the support that you talk about of moderate Republicans and independents, as well as a fired-up Democratic base, and not just done it once, I have done it three times.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think winning matters.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think a track record of getting things done matters.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I also think showing our party that we can actually bring people with us, have a wider tent, have a bigger coalition, and, yes, longer coattails, that matters.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Again, I would -- Mayor, if you -- if you had won in Indiana, that would be one thing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You tried and you lost by 20 points.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I'm sorry.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's just the math.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I respond after Bernie?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I answer the question?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Of course.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I want to make it clear that I have opposed many, many judges.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think everyone will remember what happened at the Kavanaugh hearing when that nominee went after me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I stood my ground and he had to apologize.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I have been very strong on these judges.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As for the judge you just referred to, there was actually -- the judge that wrote the opinion was a judge that went through the Senate unanimously, with support by Senator Sanders, with support by President Obama, with support by then-Senator Kennedy.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I think it is very important, when we look at these judges, to acknowledge that there are some of these judges that you think are going to be OK and they aren't.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But what would I do as president?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would appoint judges that are in the vein of people like Elena Kagan and Justice Breyer and Sonia Sotomayor, and let's not forget the notorious RBG.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what I would do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And if you look at my record as a lawyer and a member of the Judiciary Committee, look at the judges that I recommended to President Obama, people like Mimi Wright, who is a superstar, and Susan Richard Nelson.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Look who I've put in as the first openly gay marshal in the history of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I did that because I knew they were qualified people to take those jobs.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And you need to do it not only with the right judges and have that know-how, but you also have to do it right away.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is one thing that we all learned from when President Obama was in, and that was that he was dealing with an economic crisis and it was hard to do it right away, but we have to immediately start putting judges on the bench to fill vacancies so that we can reverse the horrific nature of these Trump judges.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: No, that's not right.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: OK.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Whoa, guys, hey.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: OK, that's true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I'll say this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: First of all, Bernie, I promise, when I am your president, I will get our pharmaceutical bills done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we have worked together on this time and time again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I agree with you on that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But where I disagree is, I just don't think anyone has a monopoly on bold ideas.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think you can be progressive and practical at the same time.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is why I favor a public option, which is a nonprofit option, to bring the cost down.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And, yes, it does bring the costs down immediately for 13 million people, and then we'll expand coverage to 12 million people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But here's the political problem.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This fight that you guys are having isn't real.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Your fight, Bernie, is not with me or with Vice President Biden.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is with all those -- bunch of those new House members, not every one by any means, that got elected in that last election in the Democratic Party.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is with the new governor, Democratic governor of Kentucky, that wants to build on Obamacare.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the way I look at it, if you want to bridge -- build -- if you want cross a river over some troubled waters, you build a bridge, you don't blow one up.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think that we should build on the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Oh.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would never do that to you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would never, never, never.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Well, I would ask for forgiveness any time any of you get mad at me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I can be blunt.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But I am doing this because I think it is so important to pick the right candidate here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think when you see what's going on around the country, yes, it's the economic check that Elizabeth and Bernie have so well pointed out on this stage, but there's something else going on here, and it is a decency check.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is a values check.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is a patriotism check.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When you see people -- and we've all had this happen -- that come to our meetings and say, you know, yeah, I voted for Donald Trump, but I don't want to do it again, because I want my kids to be able to watch the president on TV and not mute the TV.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have to remember as Democrats, and if I get worked up about this, it's because I believe it so much in my heart, that we have to bring people with us and not shut them out.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is the gift we can give America in this election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have had quite a debate tonight, but I want to debate Donald Trump.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This primary comes down to some simple questions.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Who has the best ideas, the best experience?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Mostly, who can beat Donald Trump, and how will she do it?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So Donald Trump built his fortune on, over time, over $413 million that he got from his dad.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My grandpa, he was an iron ore miner, a union member, who worked 1,500 feet underground, and he saved money in a coffee can in the basement to send my dad to a community college.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's my family trust.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I figure if you are given opportunity, you don't go into the world with a sense of entitlement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You go into it with a sense of obligation, an obligation to lift people up instead of hoarding what you have for yourself.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Our politics right now, because of Donald Trump, are toxic.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need a leader who can bring people together and who can win that way.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So if you are tired of the extremes in our politics and the noise and the nonsense, you have a home with me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: If you want a bigger tent and a wider coalition and longer coattails, join me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We will win at amyklobuchar.com.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you, Wolf.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have been very clear that I respect the mayor's experience very much in the military.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I just have different experience.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I've been in the U.S.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Senate for over 12 years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think what you want in a president is someone who has dealt with these life-and-death issues and who has made decisions.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will look at my position on the Iraq war first.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I wasn't in the Senate for that vote, but I opposed that war from the very beginning.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: In my first campaign for Senate, I ran against a Republican who ran ads against me on it, but I stood my ground.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: When I got to the Senate, I pushed to bring our troops home.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Then I have dealt with every issue, from Afghanistan to keeping our troops with good health care after what we saw with Walter Reed and being part of an effort to improve the situation for our troops in a very big way with our education and with their jobs and also with their health care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think right now what we should be talking about, though, Wolf, is what is happening right now with Donald Trump.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Donald Trump is taking us pell-mell toward another war.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have a very important resolution.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We just found out today that four Republicans are joining Democrats to go to him and say: You must have an authorization of military force if you're going to go to war with Iran.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is so important, because we have a situation where he got us out of the Iranian nuclear agreement, something I worked on for a significant period of time.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As president, I will get us back into that agreement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will take an oath...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... to protect and defend our Constitution.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I will mean it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would leave some troops there, but not in the level that Donald Trump is taking us right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Afghanistan, I have long wanted to bring our troops home.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would do that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Some would remain for counterterrorism and training.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: In Syria, I would not have removed the 150 troops from the border with Turkey.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think that was a mistake.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think it made our allies and many others much more vulnerable to ISIS.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then when it comes to Iraq, right now, I would leave our troops there, despite the mess that has been created by Donald Trump.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: At the briefing we had last week, I was the only person on this stage that asked a question of both the secretary of defense and the secretary of state.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I asked them about imminent threat, but I also asked them what their alternatives were.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And they gave very vague, vague answers.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I asked them, where is the surge of diplomacy that we would be seeing if I was president?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I asked them where they were going to leave the Iraqi people.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Time and time again, you see that this president puts his own interests, his private interests, in front of our country's.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would put our country's interests first as commander-in-chief.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would start negotiations again.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I won't take that as a given, given that our European partners are still trying to hold the agreement together.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My issue is that, because of the actions of Donald Trump, we are in a situation where they are now starting  Iran is starting to enrich uranium again in violation of the original agreement.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So what I would do is negotiate.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would bring people together, just as President Obama did years ago, and I think that we can get this done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But you have to have a president that sees this as a number-one goal.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And in answer to the original question you asked the mayor, I would not allow Iran to have a nuclear weapon.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then you have to get an agreement in place.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think there are changes you can make to the agreement that are sunset, some changes to the inspections, but overall, that is what we should do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I am the one person on this debate stage, on the first night of the very first debate, when we were asked what we saw as the biggest threat to our world, I said China on the economy, but I said Iran, because of Donald Trump.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Because I feared that exactly what happened would happen: enrichment of uranium, escalation of tensions, leaving frayed relations with our allies.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We can bring them back, understanding this is a terrorist regime that we cannot allow to have a nuclear weapon.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Brianne, I want to hit reality here.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I serve on the Agriculture Committee, and I will never forget going to Crawfordsville here in Iowa  and thank you for bringing up Iowa, Brianne, since that is where we are  and I went to this plant and there was one worker left in that plant.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That plant had been shut down because of Donald Trump's trade policies and because of what he had done to those workers with giving secret waivers to oil companies and ruining the renewable fuel standard.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That worker brought out a coat rack of uniforms and he said, these are my friends, they don't work anymore.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And their names were embroidered on those uniforms, Derek, Mark, Salvador.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that guy started to cry.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: These are real people hurt by Donald Trump's trade war.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So what we should do, and I support the USMCA, I am glad that these improvements were made that are supported by people like Richard Trumka and Sherrod Brown on labor and environment and on pharma, the sweetheart deal...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... because I think we need a big trading block...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... with North America to take on China.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the way you are stronger...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: China is with our allies.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you, Elizabeth.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I would like to point out...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Oh, OK.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I thought it was such an open-end  I wasn't at the meeting, so I can't comment, but I was going to say...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I hear that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: People have said it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's why I've addressed it from this stage.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I point out that you don't have to be the tallest person in the room.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: James Madison was 5'4".

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You don't have to be the skinniest person in the room.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You don't have to be the loudest person.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You have to be competent.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when you look at the facts, Michigan has a woman governor right now and she beat a Republican, Gretchen Whitmer.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Kansas has a woman governor right now and she beat Kris Kobach.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And her name is  I'm very proud to know her, and her name is Governor Kelly.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Third, I would add to this, you have to be competent to win and you have to know what you're doing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And when you look at what I have done, I have won every race, every place, every time.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have won in the reddest of districts.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have won in the suburban areas, in the rural areas.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have brought people with me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That is why I have the most endorsements of current Iowa legislators and former Iowa legislators in this race.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Because they know I bring people with me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And finally, every single person...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... that I have beaten, my Republican opponents, have gotten out of politics for good.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think  I think that sounds pretty good.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think that sounds pretty good with the guy we have in the White House right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Sen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Sanders and I have worked together on pharmaceuticals for a long, long time.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And we agree on this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But what I don't agree with is that we  his position on health care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This debate isn't real.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I was in Vegas the other day and someone said "Don't put your chips on a number on the wheel that isn't even on the wheel."

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's the problem.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Over two-thirds of the Democrats in the U.S.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Senate are not on the bill that you and Sen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Warren on on.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You have numerous governors that are Democratic that don't support this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You have numerous House members that put Nancy Pelosi in as speaker.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The answer is a non-profit public option.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The answer is  the real debate we should be having is how do we make it easier for people to get coverage for addiction and mental health.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have a plan for that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And then, finally, what should we do about long-term care?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The elephant that doesn't even fit in this room.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need to make it easier for people to get long-term care insurance.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We need to make it easier for them to pay for their premiums.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My own dad, I know when his long-term care insurance ends, and then we have some savings for him.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He's in assisted living.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: He got married three times  whole other story  so there isn't much there.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But then we go to Medicaid, and I've already talked to Catholic Elder Care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They're willing to take him in.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Our story is better than so many other families.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We have to make it easier for long-term care.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's not just for seniors.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It's also for the sandwich generation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: People trying to help their parents.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Again, I think it is much better to build on the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And if you want to be practical and progressive at the same time and have a plan and not a pipedream, you have to show how you're going to pay for it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I would also note practically that the Affordable Care Act right now is 10 points more popular than the president of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I think the answer is to build on it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And, yes, I think you should show how you're going to pay for things, Bernie.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: This president is treating people out there like poker chips in one of his bankrupt casinos the way he is adding to our debt.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I am the one person up here who has on her website in her plan a plan to actually start taking on the deficit, by taking part of that money from that corporate tax cut that they put in there and putting it in a fund to pay back the deficit.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have shown how I'm going to pay for every single plan...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... capital gains tax going to the personal level, getting rid of oil giveaways.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Doing something about the hedge fund loophole.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You can go through...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: ... and we can get the money to pay for things.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Sen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Warren, you acknowledged that Medicare for all  that you couldn't get there right away.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You got on the bill that said on page eight, which is why I didn't get on it, that you would kick 149 million Americans off their current health insurance.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Then, a few months ago, you said, no, you're going to wait a while to get there.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think that was some acknowledgment that maybe what we're talking about is true.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I don't buy that it's not enough.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is a big, big step to say to people making $100,000 that your premiums will be cut in half, which is what the nonprofit public option will do.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And as you talk, Mayor Buttigieg, about Medicare and having negotiation, I actually have led that bill for years.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have 34 cosponsors.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: As president, I can get it done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That would allow Medicare to finally negotiate and lift the ban that big pharma got into law that says they can't negotiate for better prices for our seniors.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I will get it done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I am open to looking at it, but I would try these things first.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Number one, I mention the Medicare negotiation.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Number two, I have a plan, 137 things I've found that a president can do herself in the first 100 days without Congress  that are legal.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And one of those things is that you can start bringing in less expensive drugs from other countries.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Bernie and I had an amendment on this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We got 14 Republican votes on it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It was at midnight.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They might have not known what they were voting for.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: But we got that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I now have an actual bill with Sen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Grassley that does that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have a bill to get at what Elizabeth was talking about, which is to stop generics from taking money from big pharmaceuticals to keep their products off the market.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: The issue here is that there are two pharma lobbyists for every member of the Congress.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They think they own Washington.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They don't own me.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And as president, I will get this done.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Yeah, you know, I appreciate your thoughts, Elizabeth, but I want to step back.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I actually think that some of our colleagues who want free college for all aren't actually thinking big enough.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar

sentence: Everyone that was afraid, they were afraid of being blacklisted, Joseph Welch, he stood up and looked at McCarthy and said, have you no sense of decency, sir?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar

sentence: So if you want to do something about racial justice and immigration reform and climate change and gun safety, we need a candidate who is actually going to bring people with her.

sentence: And when I look at a state like New Hampshire that had a very, very close election last time in 2016, I see a state that, yes, has a high voter turnout, fired-up Democrats just like my state, which by the way, Bernie, when I led the ticket, had the highest voter turnout of any state in the country.

sentence: And that is why it's going to be really important when you look at the overwhelming public support for funding Planned Parenthood, for making sure women have access to contraception, to making sure that they have a right to choose, that we make this case strongly and loudly.

sentence: Yes I did, because I think in addition to the economic argument we're making here with the sad, sad stories of a woman walking into a maternity room in New Orleans and saying her hand are swollen and walking out without her baby, and 30% of African American kids being living in poverty, we know that there are economic solutions here, to invest in those communities, housing, childcare.

sentence: But there's something else insidious going on that we haven't addressed, and that is the systematic racism when it comes to voting.

sentence: That is, moves across the country to limit people's right to vote, and that is why I have been leading on these bills to automatically register every kid to vote in this country when they turn 18.

sentence: There is no reason that we can't do that across this country.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: To stop the gerrymandering by setting up independent commissions in every single state, and yes, to stop the voting purges.

sentence: Because what is going on right now in the words of one North Carolina court is that they are discriminating with surgical precision against African American voters, and we are not going to be able to get any of these things done if we don't give people the right to vote.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So I can't stand the big money in politics, and one of my major focuses is going to be on passing that constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United.

sentence: I didn't come from money, and I just simply think people don't look at the guy in the White House and say "Can we get someone richer?"

sentence: My grandpa was an iron ore miner, he worked 1500 feet underground in the mines his whole life.

sentence: He couldn't even graduate from high school because he had to raise his nine brothers and sisters.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: My grandpa saved money in a coffee can to send my dad to a two year community college.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And no, I am not a billionaire, but I stand before you today as granddaughter of an iron ore miner, the daughter of a teacher and a newspaperman, the first woman elected to the US Senate from the state of Minnesota, someone who has passed over 100 bills as a lead Democrat in that gridlock in Washington, DC, and that is because we live in a country of shared dreams.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar

sentence: Because there were some major improvements in this trade agreement when it comes to labor inspections, when it comes to getting rid of a sweetheart pharma deal that was in place and when it comes to climate change, I think we have to have a North American trading block.

sentence: We have to have Mexico and Canada and America working together and the best way to take on climate change as president, yes, I'll work to make this a part of every future trade agreement, but the best way to take on climate change is by getting back into the international climate change agreement, which I will do on day one.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is bringing back the clean power rules.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is bringing back the gas mileage standards and it is introducing sweeping legislation to put a price on carbon and you cannot divorce trade from that, and in future trade agreements, that should be part of our negotiations.

sentence: But I'm telling you right now, having no trade agreement with Canada and Mexico puts us at such a disadvantage when it comes to dealing with China and pushing China to do better when it comes to climate change.

sentence: So my point here is that when we have opportunities to work with our allies, and New Hampshire is such a great example of this, New Hampshire, Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, with senators like Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassen, who believe we need to work with NATO and the rest of the world who sees it as a smaller state, but a state that is a piece of the world.

sentence: And there is a way, it's actually based on a National Academy of Science report and I've used that to put together a plan to reduce child poverty in half in 10 years and eradicate it in a generation.

sentence: That is what his campaign said because we should "pave the way" for him to become the nominee.

sentence: You know, I have been told as a woman, as someone that maybe no one thought was still going to be standing up on this stage, but I am because of pure grit and because of the people out there, I've been told many times to wait my turn and to step aside.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I'm not going to do that now, and I'm not going to do that because a campaign memo from Mayor Bloomberg said this morning that the only way that we get a nominee is if we step aside for him.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think we need something different than Donald Trump.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I don't think you look at Donald Trump and say we need someone richer in the White House.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have an idea -- I have an idea of how we can stop sexism on the internet.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: We could nominate a woman for candidate for president of the United States.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I think that might go a long way if we showed our stuff as a party.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the other thing I'm going to talk about is really what is at the core of this issue between Senator Sanders and the Culinary Union, and that is this.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: These are hard-working people, housekeepers like Elizabeth and I met with last night, who have health care plans that have been negotiated over time, sweat and blood.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that is the truth for so many Americans right now.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: There are 149 million Americans that would lose their current health insurance under Senator Sanders' bill.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That's what it says on page 8.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I don't think we should forget that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: OK.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I must say, I take personal offense since Post-It notes were invented in my state, so...

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: OK.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: So my plan is a public option.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And according to all the studies out there, it would reduce premiums for 12 million people immediately.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It would expand coverage for about that same number.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is a significant thing.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is what Barack Obama wanted to do from the very beginning.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the way I look at it, since we're in Vegas, when it comes to your plan, Elizabeth and Bernie's, on Medicare for all, you don't put your money on a number that's not even on the wheel.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And why is Medicare for all not on the wheel?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Why is it not on the wheel?

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Because two-thirds of the Democratic senators are not even on that bill, because a bunch of the new House members that got elected see the problems with blowing up the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: They see it right in front of them.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the truth is that when you see some troubled waters, you don't blow up a bridge, you build one.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And so we need to improve the Affordable Care Act, not blow it up.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: OK, that's it.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: First, I'll start with that case.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It is very clear that any evidence, if there is new evidence, even old evidence, it should be reviewed by that office and by the county attorney.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: That must happen.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I have called for that review.

sentence: This was a case involving an 11-year-old African-American girl named Tyesha Edwards who was shot doing her homework at her kitchen table.

sentence: Three people were convicted.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: One of the cases is the one that is being investigated, was investigated by a journalist.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I think it's very important that that evidence come forward.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: In terms of the police shootings that you noted, those went to a grand jury, every single one of them.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I have made very clear for months now that, like so many prosecutors, I think those cases in my time, they were all going to the grand jury.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: It was thought that was the best way to handle them in many, many jurisdictions.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Did -- I actually did speak up on something very similar.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And that was when our police chief in Minneapolis tried to take the investigations of police shootings into his own hands.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And I strongly said I disagreed with that.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Now I do believe also that a prosecutor should make those decisions herself.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: And the last thing I will say, because you asked the question about voting, I have the support of African-Americans in my community in every election.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: I had strong support and strong support of leadership.

sentence: And that's because I earned it.

sentence: And this is going to be on me to earn it.

sentence: You earn it with the -- what you stand for when it comes to equal opportunity.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: You earn it with the work that I have done, the leadership I've shown on voting rights, and, yes, you earn it with the work that must be done on criminal justice reform.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: Could I comment on that...

sentence: OK, yeah, I'm just looking at my husband in the front row that has to, like, do our taxes all the time.

sentence: You lost by over 20 points to someone who later lost to my friend, Joe Donnelly.

sentence: He was asked on a debate stage about the Mexican cartels, which are bad, bad criminal organizations.

sentence: I don't think that would be good for our security coordination with Mexico, and I think you got that wrong.

sentence: I have made it very clear that we have to review all of the permits that are out there right now for natural gas and then make decisions on each one of them and then not grant new ones until we make sure that it's safe.

sentence: And I want to add something that really hasn't been brought up by my colleagues.

sentence: This is a crisis, and a lot of our plans are very similar to get to carbon neutral by 2045, 2050, something like that.

sentence: I'm looking at these incredible senators from Nevada -- Catherine Cortez Masto and Jacky Rosen -- and I'm thinking that they know how important this is.

sentence: And the president can do this herself without Congress, as well as the gas mileage standard.

sentence: But when it comes to putting a price on carbon -- this is very important, Chuck -- we have to make sure that that money goes back directly as dividends to the people that are going to need help for paying their bills.

sentence: I believe in capitalism, but I think our -- the goal of someone in government and a president of the United States should be a check on that.

sentence: I'm not going to limit what people make, but I think right now our tax code is so tilted against regular people and that is what's wrong.

sentence: We should have universal childcare.

sentence: And we have not been talking enough about Donald Trump and -- let's just talk about Donald Trump, because he signed that tax bill that helped the wealthy, and he went down to Mar-a-Lago and he said to all his friends, "You just got a lot richer."

sentence: That is Exhibit A.

sentence: And I can tell you, the hard-working people in Nevada were not in that room.

sentence: So the key to me is to not limit what people can make, but make sure that we have a government that is fair for everyone.

sentence: And back then, he just went to Canada for a night and came back and he was a permanent citizen, because they needed him to serve in World War II.

sentence: And the best way we can get this done is to beat Donald Trump, but it is to pass comprehensive immigration reform, which creates a path to citizenship to so many hard-working people, will bring down the deficit by $158 billion, and will bring peace for these Dreamers.

sentence: And what I want everyone out there watching to remember is that what unites us is so much bigger than what divides us and that we need a candidate that can bring people with her.

sentence: In fact, just on "60 Minutes" this weekend, he said he wasn't going to rattle through the nickels and the dimes.

sentence: What I think we should do is make things more affordable, nonprofit public option, make sure we're paying for long-term care better, take on the pharmaceuticals, like you and I have done together...

sentence: Instead of a bunch of broken promises that sound good on bumper stickers.

sentence: I was talking about all your programs.

speaker: Amy Klobuchar
sentence: All I know...

sentence: ... if we spend the next four months tearing our party apart, we're going to watch Donald Trump spend the next four years tearing our country apart.

sentence: So, my argument here is that we need to get back to what's happening right now.

sentence: We have a clear choice of who's going to lead this party.

sentence: And I am the only one in the New Hampshire debate, when asked, if we had a problem with a socialist leading the ticket, that raised my hand.

sentence: I like Bernie.

sentence: But I do not think that this is the best person to lead the ticket.

sentence: And if you want to talk about getting things done and make a comparison, according to Vanderbilt University in Tennessee, last Congress, I was the most effective Democrat in the U.S.

sentence: Senate on 15 metrics.
