sentence: And one of the reasons for that is a horrific war on drugs.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: So I do believe that, on day one, we will change the Federal Controlled Substance Act, which, if you can believe it, now equates heroin with marijuana.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That's insane.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We're going to take marijuana out of that and effectively legalize marijuana in every state in the country.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: What we are also going to do is move to expunge the records of those people who were arrested for possession of marijuana.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And I'll tell you what else we're going to do.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We're going to provide help to the African-American, Latino, Native American community to start businesses to sell legal marijuana, rather than let a few corporations control the legalized marijuana market.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: In the White House today -- in the White House today, we have a self-described "great genius" -- self-described -- and this "great genius" has told us that this Coronavirus is going to end in two months.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: April is the magical day that this great scientist we have in the White House has determined -- I wish I was kidding; that is what he said.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: What do we have to do?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Whether or not the issue is climate change, which is clearly a global crisis requiring international cooperation, or infectious diseases like Coronavirus, requiring international cooperation, we have to work and expand the World Health Organization.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Obviously, we have to make sure the CDC, the NIH, our infectious departments, are fully funded.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: This is a global problem.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We've got to work with countries all the over the world to solve it.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Can I say one word on...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: I have opposed authoritarianism all over the world and I was really amazed at what Mayor Bloomberg just said a moment ago.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: He said that the Chinese government is responsive to the politburo, but who the hell is the politburo responsive to?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Who elects the politburo?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: You have got a real dictatorship there.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Of course you have a dictatorship in Cuba.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: What I said is what Barack Obama said in terms of Cuba, that Cuba made progress on education.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Yes, I think...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Really?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Really?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Literacy programs are bad?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: What Barack Obama said is they made great progress on education and health care.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That was Barack Obama.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Occasionally...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Excuse me, occasionally it might be a good idea to be honest about American foreign policy, and that includes the fact that America has overthrown governments all over the world in Chile, in Guatemala, in Iran.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And when dictatorships, whether it is the Chinese or the Cubans do something good, you acknowledge that.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But you don't have to trade love letters with them.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That is untrue, categorically untrue.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: I have condemned authoritarianism, whether it is the people in Saudi Arabia that the United States government...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: ... has loved for years.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Cuba, Nicaragua, authoritarianism of any stripe is bad.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But that is different than saying that governments occasionally do things that are good.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That's what Barack Obama said.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Let us be clear, do we think health care for all, Pete, is some kind of radical communist idea?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Do we think raising the minimum wage to a living wage...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: ... do we think building the millions of units of affordable housing that we need...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: ... do we think raising taxes on billionaires is a radical idea?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Do you think criminal justice reform is a radical idea?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Do you think immigration reform?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: The truth is, Pete...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: ... the American people support my agenda.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That is why I am beating Trump in virtually every poll that is done, and why I will defeat him.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Can I respond?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Amy used the word alienating.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Hey, Amy, my favorability nationally I believe are the highest up here, as a matter of fact.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: All right.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But the point is -- the point is the way we are going to beat Trump, which is what everybody up here wants, is we need a campaign of energy and excitement.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We need to have the largest voter turnout in the history of the United States.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We need to bring working people back in to the Democratic Party.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We need to get young people voting in a way they have never done before.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: That is what our campaign is about.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Let me just -- the answer is, it's something that we would take into consideration.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But here -- excuse me.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But here is the point.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: I am very proud of being Jewish.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: I actually lived in Israel for some months.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: But what I happen to believe is that, right now, sadly, tragically, in Israel, through Bibi Netanyahu, you have a reactionary racist who is now running that country.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And I happen to believe -- I happen to believe that what our foreign policy in the Mideast should be about is absolutely protecting the independence and security of Israel, but you cannot ignore the suffering of the Palestinian people.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We have got to have a policy that reaches out to the Palestinians and the Americans.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And in answer to your question, that will come within the context of bringing nations together in the Mideast.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Can I respond?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Misconception?

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Misconception -- and you're hearing it here tonight, is that the ideas I'm talking about are radical.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: They're not.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: In one form or another, they exist in countries all over the world.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Health care is a human right.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We have the necessity, the moral imperative, to address the existential threat of climate change.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: Other countries are doing that.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: We don't need more people in jail, disproportionately African-American, than any other country on earth -- not a radical idea.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: The motto, the saying that -- that moves me the most is from Nelson Mandela.

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And Mandela said, "Everything is impossible until it happens."

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: And that means, if we have the guts to stand up to powerful special interests who are doing phenomenally well; if we can bring working people together, black and white and Latino, we can create a nation...

speaker: Bernie Sanders
sentence: ... where all people have a good standard of living.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: This economy has got to work for everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And right now, we know that it isn't.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And it's going to take all of us coming together to make sure that it does.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Right now, we have a system that favors those who can pay for access and outcomes.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's how you explain an economy that is rigged to corporations and to the very wealthiest.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: A $2 trillion tax cut that favored corporations while they were sitting on record piles of cash and the very wealthiest in this country at a time of historic wealth inequality.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: A new democracy that is revived because we've returned power to the people, no PACs, no gerrymandering, automatic and same-day voter registration to bring in more voters, and a new Voting Rights Act to get rid of the barriers that are in place now . . .

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's how we each have a voice in our democracy and make this economy work for everybody.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I would support a tax rate and a tax code that is fair to everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Tax capital at the same right . . .

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: . . . that you - you tax ordinary income.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Take that corporate tax rate up to 28 percent.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You would generate the revenues . . .

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: . . . you need to pay for the programs we're talking about.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: My goal is to ensure that every American is well enough to live to their full potential because they have health care.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In Laredo, Texas, I met a young man, 27 years old, told me that he'd been to a doctor once in his life.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And on that visit, he was told he had diabetes, he was told he had glaucoma, and he was told untreated -- because he doesn't have health care -- he'll be dead before the age of 40.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So getting to guaranteed, high-quality, universal health care as quickly and surely as possible has to be our goal.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The ability to afford your prescriptions and go to a primary care provider, to be -- the ability to see a mental health care provider.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In Texas, the single largest provider of mental health care services is the county jail system today.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And health care also has to mean that every woman can make her own decisions about her own body and has access to the care that makes that possible.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Our plan says that if you're uninsured, we enroll you in Medicare.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If you're insufficiently insured, you can't afford your premiums, we enroll you in Medicare.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But if you're a member of a union that negotiated for a health care plan that you like because it works for you and your family, you're able to keep it.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We preserve choice by making sure everybody has care.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: No.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I think the choice is fundamental to our ability to get everybody cared for...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's right.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So for those for whom it's not working, they can choose Medicare.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: For the...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... who I listen to...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... they're able to keep them.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Tonight in this country, you have 2.3 million of our fellow Americans behind bars.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It's the largest prison population on the face of the planet.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Many are there for nonviolent drug crimes, including possession of marijuana, at a time that more than half the states have legalized it or decriminalized it.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And yet despite what Purdue Pharma has done, their connection to the opioid crisis and the overdose deaths that we're seeing throughout this country, they've been able to act with complete impunity and pay no consequences, not a single night in jail.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Unless there's accountability and justice, this crisis will continue.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In my administration, we will hold them to account.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We will make sure that they pay a price, and we will help those who've been victims of this malfeasance in this country get them treatment and long-term care.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: (SPEAKING IN SPANISH) We would not turn back Valeria and her father, Oscar.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would accept them into this country and follow our own asylum laws.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would not build walls.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would not put kids in cages.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In fact, we would spare no expense to reunite the families that have been separated already...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... and we would not criminally prosecute any family who is fleeing violence and persecution...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would make sure...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would not detain any family fleeing violence, in fact, fleeing the deadliest countries on the face of the planet today.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We would implement a family case management program so they could be cared for in the community at a fraction of the cost.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And then we would rewrite our immigration laws in our own image, free Dreamers forever from any fear of deportation by making them U.S. citizens here in this country, invest in solutions in Central America, work with regional stakeholders so there's no reason to make that 2,000 mile journey to this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Let me respond to this very briefly.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As a member of a Congress, I helped to introduce legislation that would ensure that we don't criminalize those who are seeking asylum and refuge in this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If you're fleeing -- if you're fleeing desperation, then I want to make sure...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I want to make sure you are treated with respect.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But you're looking at just one small part of this.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I'm talking about a comprehensive rewrite of our immigration laws.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And if you do that, I don't think it's asking too much for people to follow our laws when they come to this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Here's how we have that conversation in Texas.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I shared with them what I learned from those students who survived the Santa Fe high school shooting, a young student named Bree.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Her friend, Marcel, who survived another shooting, the mother of a victim who lost her life, Rhonda Hart, they talked about universal background checks, where you close every loophole.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We know that they save lives.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We talked about ending the sales of assault weapons into our communities.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Those weapons of war were designed to kill people as effectively and as efficiently as possible.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They should belong on the battlefield and not in our communities.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Red flag laws, so if someone poses a danger to themselves or to someone else, they're stopped before it's too late.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And what I found in each one of those 254 counties is that Democrats and independents and Republicans, gun-owners and non-gun-owners alike, agreed.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But this effort must be led by the young people that you referenced at the beginning of this issue.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Those students from Marjory Stoneman Douglas led the charge here in Florida, and they've been able to change those laws.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They're making our democracy work, ensuring that our values and our interests and our priorities are reflected in the laws that we pass.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I think you've got to bring everybody in to the decisions and the solutions to the challenges that we face.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's why we're traveling everywhere, listening to everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We were in Pacific Junction, a town that had never meaningly flooded before, just up against the Missouri River in Iowa.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And every home in that community had flooded.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: There were farms just outside of Pacific Junction that were effectively lakes, those farmers already underwater in debt, their markets closed to them by a trade war under this administration, and now they don't know what to do.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We in our administration are going fund resiliency in those communities, in Miami, in Houston, Texas, those places that are on the front lines of climate change today.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We're going to mobilize $5 trillion in this economy over the next 10 years.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We're going to free ourselves from a dependence on fossil fuels, and we're going to put farmers and ranchers in the driver's seat, renewable and sustainable agriculture, to make sure that we capture more carbon out of the air and keep more of it in the soil, paying farmers for the environmental services that they want to provide.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If all of us does all that we can, then we're going to be able to keep this planet from warming another 2 degrees Celsius, and ensure that we match what this country can do and live up to our promise and our potential.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: John, appreciate the question.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The answer is yes, but that action should always be undertaken with allies and partners and friends.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: When the United States presents a united front, we have a much better chance of achieving our foreign policy aims and preventing the kind of genocide to which you refer, the kind of genocide that we saw in Rwanda, the kind of genocide we want to stop going forward.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But unfortunately, under this administration, President Trump has alienated our allies and our friends and our alliances.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: He's diminished our standing in the world and he's made us weaker as a country, less able to confront challenges, whether it's Iran or North Korea or Vladimir Putin in Russia, who attacked and invaded our democracy in 2016, and who President Trump has offered another invitation to do the same.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: He's embraced strongmen and dictators at the expense of the great democracies.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As president, I will make sure that we live our values in our foreign policy.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I will ensure that we strengthen those alliances and partnerships and friendships and meet any challenge that we face together.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That makes America stronger.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Our existential threat is climate change.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We have to confront it before it's too late.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Yes, and I'll tell you why.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: One of the most powerful pieces of art in the United States Capitol is the Trumbull painting of General George Washington resigning his commission to the Continental Congress, at the height of his power, submitting to the rule of law and the will of people.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That has withstood the test of time for the last 243 years.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If we set another precedent now that a candidate who invited the participation of a foreign power, a president who sought to obstruct the investigation into the invasion of our democracy, if we allow him to get away with this with complete impunity, then we will have set a new standard, and that is that some people, because of the position of power and public trust that they hold, are above the law.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we cannot allow that to stand.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So we must begin impeachment now so that we have the facts and the truth and we follow them as far as they go and as high up as they reach and we save this democracy.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And if we've not been able to do that in this year or the year that follows, and under my administration, our Department of Justice will pursue these facts and ensure that there are consequences, there is accountability, and there is justice.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It's the only way that we save this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Our daughter, Molly, turned 11 this week.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I'm on this stage for her, for children across this country, including some her same age who've been separated from their parents and are sleeping on concrete floors under aluminum blankets tonight.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If we're going to be there for them, if we're going to confront the challenges that we face, we can't return to the same old approach.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We're going to need a new kind of politics, one directed by the urgency of the next generation, those climate activists, who are fighting not just for their future but for everyone's, those students marching not just for their lives but for all of ours.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We'll need a movement like the one that we led in Texas.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It renewed our democracy by bringing everyone in and writing nobody off.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's how we beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's how we bring this great country together again.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Join us.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: This is our moment.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And the generations that follow are counting on us to meet it.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I'm running for president because I believe that America discovers its greatness at its moments of greatest need.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: This moment will define us forever, and I believe that in this test America will be redeemed.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In the face of cruelty and fear from a lawless president, we will choose to be the nation that stands up for the human rights of everyone, for the rule of law for everyone, and a democracy that serves everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Whatever our differences, we know that, before we are anything else, we are Americans first, and we will ensure that each one of us is well enough and educated enough and paid enough to realize our full potential.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We will meet these challenges here at home, and we will lead the world in those that we face abroad, successfully confronting endless war and climate change.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: At this moment of truth, let us pursue our national promise and make a more perfect union of everyone, by everyone, and for everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The answer is no.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The middle class will not pay more in taxes in order to ensure that every American is guaranteed world-class health care.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I think we're being offered a false choice, some who want to improve the Affordable Care Act at the margins, others who want a Medicare for All program that will force people off of private insurance, I have a better path.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Medicare for America.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Everyone who is uninsured is enrolled in Medicare tomorrow.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Those who are insufficiently insured are enrolled...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... in Medicare...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And those who have employer-sponsored insurance...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Jake, this is important.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You have some.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Governor Bullock, who's said that we will improve the Affordable Care Act at the margins with a public option.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You have others to my right who are talking about taking away people's choice for the private insurance they have or members of unions.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I was listening to Dee Taylor in Nevada...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Every estimate that I've seen of expanding ACA even through a public option still leaves millions of people uninsured and also means that people are not guaranteed the health care that they need, as the example that Senator Warren showed us.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Our plan ensures that everyone is enrolled in Medicare or can keep their employer-sponsored insurance.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: When we listen to the American people -- and this is what they want us to do -- they want everyone covered, but they want to be able to maintain choice...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... and our plan does that.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I do, because, in my administration, after we have waived citizenship fees for green card holders, more than 9 million of our fellow Americans; freed DREAMers from any fear of deportation; and stopped criminally prosecuting families and children for seeking asylum and refuge; end for-profit detention in this country; and then assist...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... those countries in Central America so that no family ever has to make that 2,000-mile journey, than I expect that people who come here follow our laws, and we reserve the right to criminally prosecute them if they do not.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: How else can we explain that we lose nearly 40,000 people in this country to gun violence, a number that no other country comes even close to, that we know what all the solutions are, and yet nothing has changed?

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It is because, in this country, money buys influence, access, and, increasingly, outcomes.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The Centers for Disease Control prevented from actually studying the issue in the first place.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As president, we will make sure that we ban political action committee contributions to any member of Congress or any candidate for federal office.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We will listen to people, not PACs, people, not corporations, people, not special interests.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Bernie was talking about some of the battleground states in which we compete -- there is a new battleground state, Texas and it has 38 electoral college votes.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And the way that we put it in play was by going to each one of those 254 counties.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: No matter how red or rural, we did not write you off.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: No matter how blue, or urban -- we did not take you for granted.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we didn't trim our sails, either.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We had the courage of our convictions, talking about universal health care, comprehensive immigration reform, and confronting the challenge of climate before it is too late.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We brought everyone in...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... and now we have a chance to beat Donald Trump with Texas.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You know, I think a big part of leadership and showing our commitment to the American people is delivering on our commitments.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As a member of Congress, when I learned that the El Paso V.A. had the worst wait times for mental health care in the country, meaning that care delayed functionally became care denied, and was related to the suicide epidemic, we made it our priority and we turned around the V.A. in El Paso.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We took that lesson nationally and I worked with Republican and Democratic colleagues to expand medical health care to veterans, and we got it signed into law by the one person with whom I agree on almost nothing -- Donald Trump -- to show that, at the end of the day, we will put the American people first...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... before party, before any other concern.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I've listen to the sciences on this, and they're very clear.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We don't have more than 10 years to get this right, and we won't meet that challenge with half-steps or half-measures or only half the country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We've got to bring everyone in.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The people of Detroit and those that I listened to in Flint last week, they want the challenge.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They want those jobs.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They want to create the future for this country and the world.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Those community college students that I met in Tucumcari, New Mexico understand that wind and solar jobs are the fastest-growing jobs in the country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And those farmers in Iowa say pay me for the environmental services of planting cover crops and keeping more land in conservation easements.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's how we meet the challenge.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We do it with everyone in this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We bring everyone in to the solution.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We'll call his racism out for what it is, and also talk about its consequences.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It doesn't just offend our sensibilities to hear him say "send her back," about a member of Congress, because she's a woman color, because she's a Muslim-American doesn't just offend our sensibilities when he calls Mexican immigrants "rapists and criminals," or seeks to ban all Muslims from the shores of a country that's comprised of people from the world over, from every tradition of faith.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It is also changing this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Hate crimes are in the rise -- every single one of the last three years, on the day that he signed his executive order attempting to ban Muslim travel, the mosque in Victoria, Texas was burned to the ground.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So we must not only stand up against Donald Trump and defeat him in this next election, but we must also ensure that we don't just tolerate or respect our differences, but we embrace them.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's what we've learned in El Passo, Texas -- my hometown.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: One of the safest cities in the United States of America, not despite, but because it's a city of immigrants and asylum seekers, and refugees.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We will show that our diversity --

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I want to acknowledge something that we're all touching on, which is the very foundation of this country, the wealth that we have built, the way we became the greatest country on the face of the planet was literally on the backs of those who were kidnapped and brought here by force.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The legacy of slavery and segregation and Jim Crow and suppression is alive and well in every aspect of the economy and in the country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Today, as president, I will sign into law a new Voting Rights Act.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I will focus on education, address health care disparities, but I will also sign into law Sheila Jackson Lee's reparations bill so that we can have the national conversation we've waited too long in this country to have.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You know, the question was about tariffs.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And they're a huge mistake.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They constitute the largest tax increase on the American consumer, hitting the middle class and the working poor especially hard, and farmers in Iowa and across the country are bearing the brunt of the consequences.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: When have we ever gone to war, including a trade war, without allies and friends and partners?

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As president, we will hold China accountable, but we will bring our allies and friends, like the European Union, to bear, and we'll also negotiate trade deals that favor farmers and American workers and protect human rights and the environment and labor, not just here in the United States...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I support free two-year college, earn that associate's degree, realize your full potential, debt-free four-year college.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But unlike some of the other candidates on the stage, that's not just for tuition.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That is room and books and board, the full cost of being able to better yourself so that you can better this country, and then for that schoolteacher who, in many places like Texas, is working a second or a third job, full forgiveness for her outstanding student loan debt, forgiveness for that person willing to work at the V.A. and serve our former service members.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we do not do that at the expense of unions.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We elevate them as well and make it easier to join an apprenticeship to learn a skill or a trade that you can command for the rest of your life.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I would in my first term in office.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Agree that there is nothing about perpetuating this war, already in its 18th year, that will make it any better.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We've satisfied the reasons for our involvement in Afghanistan in the first place.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And it's time to bring those servicemembers back home from Afghanistan, but also from Iraq, also from Yemen, and Somalia, and Libya, and Syria.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: There is no reason for us to be at war all over the world tonight.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As president, I will end those wars, and we will not start new wars.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We will not send more U.S. servicemembers overseas to sacrifice their lives and to take the lives of others in our name.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We can resolve these challenges peacefully and diplomatically.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We are as divided and polarized as a country as we have ever been.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And right now we have a president who uses fear to try to drive us further apart.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: To meet this challenge, we have to have hope in one another and a faith in a future of the country that includes everyone.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: My whole life, I've been including people in the success of this country, starting a small business with high-value, high-wage, high-skilled jobs in the third poorest urban county in America, serving on City Council and holding town hall meetings every single week to remind myself who it is that I serve at the end of the day, and in Congress, being in the minority but working with Democrats and Republicans alike to deliver for my constituents and this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And then in Texas, this last year, traveling to every county, not writing anybody off, not taking anyone for granted, and at the end of the day, winning more votes than any Democrat had in the history of the state, winning independents for the first time in decades, and winning nearly half-a-million Republicans, and those 38 Electoral College votes in Texas are now in play and I can win them.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That is how we defeat Donald Trump in November of 2020 and how we bring this divided country together again in January of 2021.

sentence: Thank you.

sentence: It's an honor to be on this debate stage.

sentence: It is wonderful to be back in Texas, in Houston, back here at TSU.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: On Aug. 3, in El Paso, Texas, two things became crystal clear for me, and I think produced a turning point for this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The first is just how dangerous Donald Trump is, the cost and the consequence of his presidency.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: A racism and violence that had long been a part of America was welcomed out into the open and directed to my hometown of El Paso, Texas, where 22 people were killed, dozens more grievously injured by a man carrying a weapon he should never have been able to buy in the first place, inspired to kill by our president.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The second is how insufficient our politics is to meet the threat that we have right now.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The bitterness, the pettiness, the smallness of the moment, the incentives to attack one another and try to make differences without distinctions, mountains out of mole hills, we have to be bigger.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We have to see clearly, we have to speak honestly, and we have to act decisively.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's what I want to do for you as president of the United States.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Listen, I'm grateful that we all agree about the urgency of this challenge and the fact that Donald Trump is undermining the limited protections that we have right now.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But I also think we're being offered a false choice between those who propose an all-or-nothing gambit, forcing tens of millions off of insurance that they like, that works for them, to force them onto Medicare, and others who want to, as the vice president does, incrementally improve what we have, which will still leave many, maybe millions uninsured and uncared for.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In a state like Texas, where the largest provider of mental health care services is the county jail system, we've got to do better.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In my proposal, Medicare for America, says everyone who's uninsured will be enrolled in Medicare.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Everyone who's insufficiently insured, cannot afford it, can move over to Medicare.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And those, like members of unions who've fought for the health care plans that work for them and their families, are able to keep them.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: This is the best possible path forward.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You know, I called this out in no uncertain terms on August 3rd and every day since then.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And I was talking about it long before then, as well.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Racism in America is endemic.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It is foundational.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We can mark the creation of this country not at the Fourth of July, 1776, but August 20, 1619, when the first kidnapped African...

sentence: ... was brought to this country against his will and in bondage and as a slave built the greatness and the success and the wealth that neither he nor his descendants would ever be able to fully participate in and enjoy.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We have to be able to answer this challenge.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And it is found in our education system, where in Texas, a 5-year-old child in kindergarten is five times as likely to be disciplined or suspended or expelled based on the color of their skin.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In our health care system, where there's a maternal mortality crisis three times as deadly for women of color, or the fact that there's 10 times the wealth in white America than there is in black America.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I'm going to follow Sheila Jackson Lee's lead and sign into law a reparations bill that will allow us to address this at its foundation.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But we will also call out the fact that we have a white supremacist in the White House and he poses a mortal threat to people of color all across this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's all right.

sentence: Beto's good.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Thank you.

sentence: I am, if it's a weapon that was designed to kill people on a battlefield...

sentence: If the high impact, high velocity round, when it hits your body, shreds everything inside of your body, because it was designed to do that, so that you would bleed to death on a battlefield and not be able to get up and kill one of our soldiers.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: When we see that being used against children, and in Odessa, I met the mother of a 15-year-old girl who was shot by an AR-15, and that mother watched her bleed to death over the course of an hour because so many other people were shot by that AR-15 in Odessa and Midland, there weren't enough ambulances to get to them in time, hell, yes, we're going to take your AR-15, your AK-47.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We're not going to allow it to be used against our fellow Americans anymore.

sentence: And I want to say this.

sentence: I'm listening to the people of this country.

sentence: And you might be surprised, there was some common ground there, folks who said, I would willingly give that up, cut it to pieces, I don't need this weapon to hunt, to defend myself.

sentence: It is a weapon of war.

sentence: So, let's do the right thing, but let's bring everyone in America into the conversation, Republicans, Democrats, gun-owners, and non-gun owners alike.

sentence: And if you read the rest of that article in The Washington Post, I talked about harmonizing our entry/exit system with Mexico in the same way that we do with Canada.

sentence: I think that could help us to keep a handle on visa over-stays.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But I think the larger question that we're trying to get at is, how do we rewrite this country's immigration laws in our own image?

sentence: Make sure that there is accountability and justice for the seven lives lost under our care and our custody, but also face the fact that Democrats and Republicans alike voted to build a wall that has produced thousands of deaths of people trying to cross to join family or to work a job.

sentence: That we have been part of deporting people, hundreds of thousands just in the Obama administration alone, who posed no threat to this country, breaking up their families.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That we invest here in Houston, Texas, with pre-disaster mitigation grants to protect those communities that are vulnerable to flooding given the fact that this town has seen three 500-year floods in just five years, you'd like to think you're good for 1,500 years, but you're not.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They're coming faster and larger and more devastating than ever.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We're also going to make sure that we free ourselves from a dependence on fossil fuels and embrace renewable wind and solar energy technology, as well as the high-paying, high-skill, high-wage jobs that come along with that.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And that we're going to pay farmers for the environmental services they want to provide.

sentence: Planting cover crops, keeping more land under conservation, using no-till farming, regenerative agriculture can pull carbon out of the air and can drive it and sequester it into the soil.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's the way that we're going to meet this challenge and we're going to bring everyone into the solution.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Thank you, George.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Everything that I've learned about resilience I've learned from my hometown of El Paso, Texas.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: In the face of this act of terror that was directed at our community, in large part by the president of the United States, that killed 22 people and injured many more, we were not defeated by that, nor were we defined by that.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: The very thing that drew that killer to us is the very thing that helps us set the example for the rest of this country.

sentence: We don't see our differences as disqualifying or dangerous.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We see them as foundational to our success, to our strength, and to our security, and to our safety.

sentence: He's still healing from his wounds in the hospital, but from his hospital bed, he's still trying to coach the Fusion girls soccer team.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Those two men, Jessica and Marcella, their wives, they exemplify resilience to me.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And when we end this scourge of gun violence in this country, when we finally confront the racism that exists in America, when we're defined not by our fears, but instead by our aspirations and our ambitions, it will be, in large part, I think, thanks to the example that El Paso has set.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: You know, I think about everyone who's ever served this country in uniform.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We have two examples here on this stage tonight in Mayor Buttigieg and Congresswoman Gabbard, those who have willingly sacrificed their lives to defend this country and our Constitution.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We are the inheritors of their service and their sacrifice.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we have a responsibility to be fearless in the face of this president's criminality and his lawlessness.

sentence: The fact that as a candidate for the highest office in the land, he invited the participation, the invasion of a foreign power in our democracy.

sentence: As president, he lied to investigators, obstructed justice, fired James Comey, head of the FBI, tried to fire Mueller, head of the investigation, then invited President Zelensky to involve himself in our politics, as well as China, in exchange for favorable trade terms in an upcoming trade deal.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If we do not hold him to account, if there is not justice, not only have we failed this moment, our Constitution and our country, but we have failed everyone who has sacrificed and laid their lives down on the line.

sentence: And we cannot do that.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I've met with these members of the UAW who are striking outside of facilities in Cincinnati, in Lordstown, Ohio, which has just been devastated, decimated by GM and their malfeasance, paying effectively zero in taxes last year.

sentence: What they want is a shot.

sentence: And they want fairness in how we treat workers in this country, which they are not receiving today.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: If we complement that with investment in world-class pre-K through 12 public education, get behind our world-class public school educators, if we make sure that cost is not an object to be able to attend college, and if we elevate the role of unions in this country, and create more than 5 million apprenticeships over the next eight years, we will make sure that every single American has a shot.

sentence: They don't want a handout.

sentence: They don't want a job guarantee.

sentence: But I think we need to be focused on lifting people up.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And sometimes I think that Senator Warren is more focused on being punitive and pitting some part of the country against the other instead of lifting people up and making sure that this country comes together around those solutions.

sentence: Yes.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We must be unafraid in ensuring that we hold Russia accountable for invading the world's greatest democracy and being able to do it thanks to Donald Trump functionally with impunity so far, so much so that they are invading this democracy right now as we speak, still at the invitation of this president.

sentence: So if there are not consequences, we will continue to see this problem going forward.

sentence: But in addition, y ademas, to answer the previous question that you asked, how do we stand up to Russia on the global stage, we do that by renewing our alliances and our friendships.

sentence: And the Kurds are case in point.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Look, we're going to make sure that the priority is saving the lives of our fellow Americans.

sentence: I think almost everyone on this stage agrees that it's not right and as president would seek to ban the sale of AR-15s and AK-47s.

sentence: So if the logic begins with those weapons being too dangerous to sell, then it must continue by acknowledging, with 16 million AR-15s and AK-47s out there, they are also too dangerous to own.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So I expect my fellow Americans to follow the law, the same way that we enforce any provision, any law that we have right now.

sentence: If someone does not turn in an AR-15 or an AK-47, one of these weapons of war, or brings it out in public and brandishes it in an attempt to intimidate, as we saw when we were at Kent State recently, then that weapon will be taken from them.
