sentence: Listening to my fellow Americans, to those moms who demand action, to those students who march for our lives, who, in fact, came up with this extraordinary bold peace plan...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... that calls for mandatory buybacks, let's follow their inspiration and lead and not be limited by the polls and the consultants and the focus groups.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Let's do what's right...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's a mischaracterization.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Anderson, I've got to answer this.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Never took you or anyone else on who disagrees with me on this issue.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: But when you, Mayor Buttigieg, described this policy as a shiny object, I don't care what that meant to me or my candidacy, but to those who have survived gun violence, those who've lost a loved one to an AR-15, an AK-47, marched for our lives, formed in the courage of students willing to stand up to the NRA and conventional politics and poll-tested politicians, that was a slap in the fact to every single one of those groups and every single survivor of a mass casualty assault with an AR-15 and an AK-47.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We must buy them back.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Yes, it is, for many of the reasons that Mr.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Yang just described.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And also just from some personal experiences I've had as a member of Congress where constituents of mine have come forward, in some cases publicly, at a town hall meeting to describe their addictions.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I remember a veteran telling me that he bought heroin off the street because he was originally prescribed an opioid at the V.A.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Now, imagine if that veteran, instead of being prescribe an opioid, had been prescribed marijuana because we made that legal in America, ensured the V.A....

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... could prescribe it, expunge the arrest records for those who've been arrested for possession, and make sure that he was not prescribed something to which he would become addicted.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I also want to agree with Senator Klobuchar.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Until we hold those responsible accountable for their actions, Purdue Pharma, Johnson & Johnson, we're going to continue to have this problem going on again.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So that veteran that I met, and anyone with drug addiction today, is not a problem for the criminal justice system.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They're an opportunity for our public health system in America.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Yeah, we need to set very tough, very clear, transparent rules of the road, the kind of rules that we do not have today, that allow these social media platforms, where we, the people, have become the product, to abuse that public trust, and to do so at extraordinary profits.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Right now, we treat them functionally as a utility, when, in reality, they're more akin to a publisher.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: They curate the content that we see.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Our pictures and personal information that they share with others, we would allow no publisher to do what Facebook is doing, to publish that ad that Senator Warren has rightfully called out, that CNN has refused to air because it is untrue and tells lies about the vice president, treat them like the publisher that they are.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's what I will do as president.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we will be unafraid to break up big businesses if we have to do that, but I don't think it is the role of a president or a candidate for the presidency to specifically call out which companies will be broken up.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: That's something that Donald Trump has done, in part because he sees enemies in the press and wants to diminish their power.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It's not something that we should do.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So tough rules of the road, protect your personal information, privacy, and data, and be fearless in the face of these tech giants.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: There was some talk about getting big things done.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: When I was first elected to Congress, I found that El Paso, Texas, had the worst wait times in the country to see a mental health care provider at the V.A.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I don't know how sensational or exciting that was to everyone in the country or even most people in El Paso, but it was important to those veterans who I serve.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: So we set about turning around the V.A., hiring up the psychiatrists and psychologists and therapists to take care of those women and men who had put their lives on the line for this country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And we were able to do that, and we took what we learned, and we applied it to a national law as a member of the minority working with Republicans and Democrats alike to expand mental health care access for veterans nationally.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And then in Texas, one of what was thought to be the reddest states in the country, going to every single county...

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: ... talking about this progressive agenda, and winning more votes than any Democrat has ever won, that's the way that we defeat Donald Trump in November of 2020.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I've always tried to bring people in to the solutions that we have to our common challenges, regardless of the differences.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I did that as a small-business owner more than 20 years ago, making sure that we could get a small tech company off the ground in El Paso, Texas.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Did it as a member of the City Council, where I saw my colleagues not as Republicans or Democrats, but my fellow El Pasoans who had a responsibility to deliver for our community.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: As a member of Congress, I remember being in San Antonio.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I was visiting the V.A. there, March of 2017.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Found that my flight had been snowed in, in Washington, D.C.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I happened to be in the elevator with a Republican member of Congress, Will Hurd.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And on a whim, I said, do you want to just rent a car and drive from San Antonio to Washington?

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And he called my bluff.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We got in that Chevy Impala, last car on the lot.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: It was spring break.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Drove 1,600 miles across the country.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: Live streamed the conversation, a Republican and a Democrat finding out what we had in common.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: By the end of that trip, not only had we formed a friendship, but we had formed trust.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We worked with each other on each other's bills.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I got Will to work with me on an immigration bill, showing party leaders from either side that Republicans and Democrats could work together on an otherwise contentious issue.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: And then across Texas, I mentioned winning more votes than any Democrat.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: We won independents and Republicans in record numbers, as well.

speaker: Beto O'Rourke
sentence: I will bring people in and together to face the common challenges that we have and to make sure that America rises to this opportunity.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Well, we've been addressing income inequality in New York City by raising wages, by raising benefits, by putting money back in the hands of working people, $15 minimum wage, paid sick days, pre-K for all, things that are making a huge difference in working people's lives.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But let me tell you, what we're hearing here already in the first round of questions is that battle for the heart and soul of our party.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I want to make it clear.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: This is supposed to be the party of working people.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yes, we're supposed to be for a 70 percent tax rate on the wealthy.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yes, we're supposed to be for free college, free public college, for our young people.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We are supposed to break up big corporations when they're not serving our democracy.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: This Democratic Party has to be strong and bold and progressive.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And in New York, we've proven that we can do something very different, we can put money back in the hands of working people.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And let me tell you, every time you talk about investing in people and their communities, you hear folks say there's not enough money.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: What I say to them every single time is, there's plenty of money in this world, there's plenty of money in this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It's just in the wrong hands.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Democrats have to fix that.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Wait, wait, wait.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Congressman O'Rourke, Congressman O'Rourke, private insurance is not working for tens of millions of Americans when you talk about the co-pays, the deductibles, the premiums, the out of pocket expenses.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It's not working.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: How can you defend a system that's not working?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Congressman...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: ... you've got to start by acknowledging the system is not working for people.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Why are you defending private insurance to begin with?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We have to change the discussion about in this country...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: ... because look at the bottom line here.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Those tragic -- that tragic photo of those -- that parent, that child -- and I'm saying this as a father.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Every American should feel that in their heart, every American should say that is not America, those are not our values.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But we have to get under the skin of why we have this crisis in our system, because we're not being honest about the division that's been fomented in this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The way that American citizens have been told that immigrants somehow created their misery and their pain and their challenges, for all the American citizens out there who feel you're falling behind or feel the American dream is not working for you, the immigrants didn't do that to you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The big corporations did that to you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The 1 percent did that to you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We need to be the party of working people, and that includes a party of immigrants.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But first we have to tell working people in America who are hurting that we're going to be on their side every single time against those big corporations who created this mess to begin with.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And remind people we're all in this together.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: If we don't change that debate, that politics that's holding us back, we won't get all these reforms people are talking about.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That's what we need to do as Democrats.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Hey, but wait a minute...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Rachel, I am chief executive of the nation's largest city, and I also wanted to just say something quick on the gun issue and come to your question.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Look, I run the largest police force in America, too, and if we're going to stop these shootings, we want to get these guns off the street, we have to have a very different relationship between our police and our community.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I also want to say there's something that sets me apart from all my colleagues running in this race, and that is, for the last 21 years, I have been raising a black son in America.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And I have had to have very, very serious talks with my son, Dante, about how to protect himself on the streets of our city and all over this country, including how to deal with the fact that he has to take special caution because there have been too many tragedies between our young men and our police, too, as we saw recently in Indiana.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: So we need to have a different conversation in this country about guns, but also a different conversation about policing that brings policing community together.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We've done that in New York City and we've driven down crime while we've done it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But to your question about Mitch McConnell, there is a political solution that we have to come to grips with.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: If the Democratic Party would stop acting like the party of the elites and be the party of working people again, and go into states, including red states, to convince people we're on their side, we can put pressure on their senators to actually have to vote for the nominees that are put forward...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But what about the War Powers Act?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: What about the War Powers Act being a part of that equation?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: With deep respect to the congressman, look, we've learned painful lessons as Americans that we've gone to war without congressional authorization.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And look, this is very personal for me.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I know the cost of war.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: My dad served in the Pacific in World War II in the U.S.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Army, Battle of Okinawa, had half his leg blown off, and he came home with scars, both physical and emotional, and he did not recover.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: He spiraled downward and he ultimately took his own life.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And that battle didn't kill him, but that war did.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And, look, even in the humanitarian crisis -- and I think we should be ready, Congressman, to intervene, God forbid there is genocide -- but not without congressional approval.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Democrats and Republicans both in the Congress have not challenged presidents and have let them get away with running the military without that congressional approval.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We learned a lesson in Vietnam we seem to have forgotten, that decisions have to be made by the United States Congress...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Russia, because they're trying to undermine our democracy and they've been doing a pretty damn good job of it, and we need to stop them.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It matters.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It matters in this fight for the heart and soul of our party that we nominate a candidate who has seen the face of poverty and didn't just talk about it, but gave people $15 minimum wage.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It matters that we nominate a candidate who saw the destruction wrought by a broken health care system and gave people universal health care.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It matters that we choose someone who saw the wasted potential of our children denied pre-K and gave it to every single one of them for free.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: These things really matter.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And these are the things that I've done in New York and I want to do the same for this whole country, because putting working people first, it matters.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We need to be that party again.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Let's work together.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: With your help, we can put working people first again in America.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: To the working people of America, tonight I bring you a message of hope.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We can make change in this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I know from personal experience it can be done.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: When I became the mayor of the nation's largest city, I set us on a path of bold change.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They said it couldn't be done, but we gave pre-K to every child for free.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We got rid of stop-and-frisk and we lowered crime.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We raised the minimum wage to $15 an hour.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yes, it can be done.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Now, tonight we have to get to the heart and soul of who we are as Democrats.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: There are good people on this stage, but there are real differences.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Joe Biden told wealthy donors that nothing fundamentally would change if he were president.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Kamala Harris said she's not trying to restructure society.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Well, I am.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: For 40 years, working people have taken it on the chin in this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: For 40 years, the rich have gotten richer and they've paid less and less in taxes.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It cannot go on this way.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: When I'm president, we will even up the score and we will tax the hell out of the wealthy to make this a fairer country and to make sure it's a country that puts working people first.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I don't know what the vice president and the senator are talking about.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The folks I talk to about health insurance say that their health insurance isn't working for them.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: There's tens of millions of Americans who don't even have health insurance, tens of millions more who have health insurance they can barely make work because of the co-pays, the deductibles, the premiums, the out-of-pocket expenses.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: There's this mythology that somehow all of these folks are in love with their insurance in America.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: What I hear from union members and from hard-working, middle-class people is they wish they had better insurance and they're angry at private insurance companies that skim all the profits off the top and make it impossible for everyday people to get coverage like mental care...

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: ... dental care, the things that would be full coverage for all Americans.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yeah, I don't understand why Democrats on this stage are fearmongering about universal health care.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It makes no sense.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Ask the American people, they are sick of what the pharmaceutical companies are doing to them.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Ask them what they feel about the health insurance companies.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They feel it's holding back their families because they can't get the coverage they need.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They get a lot of noes.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They don't get a lot of help from health insurance companies.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Why are we not going to be the party that does something bold, that says we don't need to be dependent on private insurance?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We can have a system that actually covers everyone.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You know what?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Donald Trump won this state of Michigan by saying he was going to disrupt the status quo.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: How about we be the party that's going to disrupt the status quo for working people?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Certainly, with all due respect to Senator Bennet, what he's saying is absolutely inaccurate about taxes.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Americans right now are paying so much money for their health care, ask people about the reality of premiums, deductibles, co-pays, out-of-pocket expenses.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That's worse than any tax, and people are paying that right now.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Senator, if we as Democrats say we're done with private insurance, has only hurt the American people in so many ways, we're going to give them something that works for their family's full coverage that they can depend on.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: If we say that, then there's an election.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The American people get to decide.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The ultimate choice, Senator, is an election, and this should be the party that stands for universal health care and says we're not going to accept anything less.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Right now, in America, so many people don't have the health care they need.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That is a fact.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Tens of millions of people, including middle class people.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Give them a chance to make that decision through an election.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Two points.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: One, it's all kind of charade because there's 11 million people here, and everyone, in theory, has broken the law, but they're part of our communities now.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They're part of our economy.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They're our neighbors.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Why are we even discussing on one level whether it's a civil penalty or a criminal penalty, when it's an American reality?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And what we need is comprehensive immigration, once and for all, to fix it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Second, Vice President Biden, I didn't hear your response when the issue came up of all those deportations.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You were vice president of the United States.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I didn't hear whether you tried to stop them or not, using your power, your influence in the White House.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Do you think it was a good idea, or do you think it was something that needed to be stopped?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yes, I -- I agree with the congress member but I don't hear an answer from the vice president.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I'm confused.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I asked the vice president point blank, did he use his power to stop those deportations.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: He went right around the question.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Mr.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Vice President, you want to be president of the United States, you need to be able to answer the tough questions.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I guarantee you if you're debating Donald Trump he's not going to let you off the hook.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: So did you say those deportations were a good idea or did you go to the president and say this is a mistake, we shouldn't do it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Which one?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I still don't hear an answer.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Well, let me tell you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I know the Garner family.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They've gone through extraordinary pain.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: They are waiting for justice and are going to get justice.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: There's finally going to be justice.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I have confidence in that, in the next 30 days, in New York.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You know why?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Because for the first time, we are not waiting on the federal Justice Department, which told the city of New York that we could not proceed because the Justice Department was pursuing their prosecution.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And years went by, and a lot of the pain accrued.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And in the meantime, what I'm working on is making sure -- and I have for five years -- there will never be another tragedy, there will never be another Eric Garner, because we're changing fundamentally how we police.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But there's one last point I have to say about the Justice Department.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The vice president for two-and-a-half of those years, Mr.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Vice President, tell us, what did you do to try and spur on the Justice Department to act in the Garner case?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We have a huge problem, and it's decades old in New York.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But here's what we've done about it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We've declared the eradication of all lead, literally ending the notion of lead poisoning once and all as the goal of our administration, and we're doing something about it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Lead poisoning has gone down 90 percent since 2005, and we're going to literally bring it down to zero, because we're going to go into every place, buildings, schools, public housing, and take out that lead, remediate that lead once and for all, and that needs to be done all over this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Now, the federal government used to not take any responsibility for our public housing.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: For decades they've been disinvesting in the public housing that was supposed to be a federal responsibility.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That's part of why we have this lead crisis to begin with.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But I'll tell you what you do when you're actually in charge of something.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I'm in charge of the largest city in this nation.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You do not accept the status quo.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You fix it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And so we are going into every one of those apartments to make sure those children and those families are safe, and then we are going to eradicate that lead once and for all.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And there should be a federal mandate to do the same for Flint, for Detroit, for every place in this country.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It can be done.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Yeah, and I just want to ask this question of all the candidates, but particularly of Vice President Biden.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: President Trump is trying to sell NAFTA 2.0.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: He's got a new name for it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It's just as dangerous as the old NAFTA.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: It's going to take away American jobs like the old NAFTA, like it did to Michigan.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And we cannot have Democrats be party to a new NAFTA.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: So, Vice President, I believe you're the only person on the stage who voted for the original NAFTA.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Are you ready to say here and now that you will oppose a new NAFTA and that what you will believe in, which is a lot of us hope for, is trade treaties that empower organized labor across the boundaries of the world and give working people power again, not just multinational corporations.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I consider that a victory.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: You know what?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We believe in redemption, Joe.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We believe in redemption in this party.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We didn't talk about Iran.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We didn't talk about Iran.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We're on the march to war in Iran right now, and we blew by it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I respect the rules, but we have to stop this march to war in Iran.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And the Democratic Party has to stand up for it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: I think it's obvious at this point in our history that the president has committed the crimes worthy of impeachment.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: But I want to caution my fellow Democrats.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: While we move in every way we can for impeachment, we have to remember at the same time the American people are out there looking for us to do something for them in their lives.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And what they see when they turn on the TV or go online is just talk about impeachment.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We need more talk about working people and their lives.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: For example, are we really ready -- and I ask people on this stage this question -- are we ready to make sure that the wealthy pay their fair share in taxes?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That's something every American wants to know about.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: That's something they want answers to right now.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: So, yeah, move for impeachment, but don't forget to do the people's business and to stand up for working people, because that's how we're actually going to beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The best impeachment is beating him in the election of 2020.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: For the last three years, we've watched Donald Trump pit working people against each other, black versus white, citizen versus immigrant.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And why?

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: So that the wealthy and the powerful he represents can hold the American dream hostage from everyone else.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We can't let them get away with it.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: If we're going to beat Donald Trump, this has to be a party that stands for something.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: This has to be the party of labor unions.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: This has to be the party of universal healthcare.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: This has to be the party that's not afraid to say out loud we're going to tax the hell out of the wealthy.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: And when we do that, Donald Trump right on cue will call us socialists.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Well, here's what I'll say to him.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: Donald, you're the real socialist.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: The problem is, it's socialism for the rich.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We, here in this country, we don't have to take that anymore.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: We can fight back.

speaker: Bill de Blasio
sentence: If you agree that we can stand up to Donald Trump and we can stand up to the wealthy, then go to taxthehell.com and join us, so we can build a country that puts working people first.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I don't think I disagree.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I think we have a serious problem in our country with corporate consolidation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And you see the evidence of that in how dignity is being stripped from labor, and we have people that work full-time jobs and still can't make a living wage.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We see that because consumer prices are being raised by pharmaceutical companies that often have monopolistic holds on drugs.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And you see that by just the fact that this is actually an economy that's hurting small businesses and not allowing them to compete.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: One of the most aggressive bills in the Senate to deal with corporate consolidation is mine about corporate consolidation in the ag sector.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So I feel very strongly about the need to check the corporate consolidation and let the free market work.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'll tell you this.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I live in a low-income black and brown community.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I see every single day that this economy is not working for average Americans.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The indicators that are being used, from GDP to Wall Street's rankings, is not helping people in my community.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is about time that we have an economy that works for everybody, not just the wealthiest in our nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, again, I will single out companies like Halliburton or Amazon that pay nothing in taxes and our need to change that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And when it comes to antitrust law, what I will do is, number one, appoint judges that will enforce it, number two, have a DOJ and a Federal Trade Commission that will go through the processes necessary to check this kind of corporate concentration.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: At the end of the day, we have too much of a problem with corporate power growing.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We see that with everything from Citizens United and the way they're trying to influence Washington.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's about time that we have a president that fights for the people in this country . . .

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to have someone that's a champion for them.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I absolutely will.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: First of all, we're talking about this as a health care issue, but in communities like mine, low-income communities, it's an education issue, because kids who don't have health care are not going to succeed in school.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is an issue for jobs and employment, because people who do not have good health care do not succeed at work.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's even a retirement issue, because in my community, African-Americans have a lower life expectancy because of poorer health care.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so where I stand is very clear.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Health care -- it's not just a human right, it should be an American right.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I believe the best way to get there is Medicare for all.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But I have an urgency about this.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: When I am president of the United States, I'm not going to wait.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have to do the things immediately that are going to provide better care.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And on this debate, I'm sorry.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There are too many people profiteering off of the pain of people in America, from pharmaceutical companies to insurers.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Literally, the overhead for insurance that they charge is 15 percent, while Medicare's overhead is only at 2 percent.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We can do this better.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And every single day, I will be fighting to give people more access and more affordable costs until we get to my goal...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... which is every American having health care.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They should absolutely be held criminally liable, because they are liable and responsible.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is one of the reasons why well before I was running for president I said I would not take contributions from pharma companies, not take contributions from corporate PACs, or pharma executives, because they are part of this problem.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And this opioid addiction in our country, we in cities like mine have been seeing how we've tried to arrest our way out of addiction for too long.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is time that we have a national urgency to deal with this problem and make the solutions that are working to actually be the law of our land and make the pharmaceutical companies that are responsible help to pay for that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: (SPEAKING IN SPANISH) On day one, I will make sure that, number one, we end the ICE policies and the Customs and Border Policies that are violating the human rights.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: When people come to this country, they do not leave their human rights at the border.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Number two...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will make sure that we reinstate DACA, that we reinstate pathways to citizenship for DACA recipients, and to make sure that people that are here on temporary protective status can stay and remain here.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And then, finally, we need to make sure that we address the issues that made Oscar and Valeria come in the first place, by making major investments in the Northern Triangle, not like this president is doing, by ripping away the resources we need to actually solve this problem.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We cannot surrender our values and think that we're going to get border security.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We actually will lose security and our values.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We must fight for both.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: As my friend here said, I agree with him on that issue, but folks should understand that the separation of children from families doesn't just go on at our border.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It happens in our communities, as ICE are ripping away parents from their American children, spouses and the like, and are creating fear in cities all across this country where parents are afraid to even drop their kids off to school or go to work.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We must end those policies, as well.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, this is a related and brief point, because what we're talking -- what Secretary Castro and I are talking about is that we have the power to better deal with this problem through the civil process than the criminal process.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I have been to some of the largest private prisons, which are repugnant to me that people are profiting off incarceration, and their immigration lockups.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Our country has made so many mistakes by criminalizing things, whether it's immigration, whether it's mental illness, whether it's addiction.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We know that this is not the way to deal with problems.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There is a humane way that affirms human rights and human dignity and actually solves this problem.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Donald Trump isn't solving this problem.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We've seen under his leadership a surge at our border.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We solve this problem by making investments in the Northern Triangle to stop the reasons why people are being driven here in the first place, and we make sure we use our resources to provide health care to affirm the values and human dignity of the people that come here, because we cannot sacrifice our values, our ideals as a nation for border security.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We can have both by doing this the right way.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: May I address that?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: First and foremost, it was a mistake to pull out of that deal.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And one of the reasons why we're seeing this hostility now is because Donald Trump is marching us to a far more dangerous situation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Literally, he took us out of a deal that gave us transparency into their nuclear program and pushed back a nuclear breakout 10, 20 years.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And now we see Iran threatening to go further and who are pulled -- being pulled further and further into this crisis.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to renegotiate and get back into a deal, but I'm not going to have a primary platform to say unilaterally I'm going to rejoin that deal.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Because when I'm president of the United States, I'm going to do the best I can to secure this country and that region and make sure that if I have an opportunity to leverage a better deal, I'm going to do it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I want to say, my colleague and I both have been hearing this on the campaign trail.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But what's even worse is I hear gunshots in my neighborhood.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I think I'm the only one -- I hope I'm the only one on this panel here that had seven people shot in their neighborhood just last week.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Someone I knew, Shahad Smith, was killed with an assault rifle at the top of my block last year.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: For millions of Americans, this is not a policy issue.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is an urgency.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And for those that have not been directly affected, they're tired of living in country where their kids go to school to learn about reading, writing, and arithmetic, and how to deal with an active shooter in their school.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is something that I'm tired of.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'm tired of hearing people all, they have to offer is thoughts and prayers.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: In my faith, people say faith without works is dead.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So we will find a way.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But the reason we have a problem right now is we've let the corporate gun lobby frame this debate.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is time that we have bold actions and a bold agenda.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will get that done as president of the United States because this is not about policy.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is personal.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm going to use 20 of my seconds just to say there's one thing we don't all agree with when it comes to guns, and I think it's common sense, and over 70 percent of Americans agree with me.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If you need a license to drive a car, you should need a license to buy and own a firearm.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And not everybody in this field agrees with that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But in states like Connecticut that did that, they saw 40 percent drops in gun violence and 15 percent drops in suicides.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to start having bold agendas on guns.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: When it comes to the Supreme Court, very clearly, we -- I agree with my friend, Secretary Castro.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are going to get to 50 votes in the Senate.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is a team sport.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Whoever is our nominee needs to campaign in places like South Carolina, because we can elect Jamie Harrison.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They need to campaign in places like Iowa, because we can win a Senate seat there.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is about getting us back to having 50 votes in the Senate and more so that we cannot only balance the Supreme Court, but start to pass an aggressive agenda that, frankly, isn't so aggressive, because most of America agrees with the policy objectives of our party.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You know, when I got to the United States Senate, going back to what De Blasio said, as an African-American man in an African-American-dominated community, I knew one of the biggest issue was criminal justice reform, from police accountability to dealing with the fact that we have a nation that has more African-Americans under criminal supervision than all the slaves in 1850.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And when I got to the Senate, people told me we could not get a comprehensive criminal justice reform bill done.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: As my colleagues in the Senate know, I fought on that bill from the day I got to the Senate, built coalitions across the aisle, and today we passed the First Step Act.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's not as far as I want to go, but thousands of people will be liberated.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I have gotten -- I have taken on tough problems people said we cannot achieve, and I've been able to get things accomplished.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But it's not enough.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's not enough.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If I can add to this, it's very important.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's not enough.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, civil rights is someplace to begin, but in the African American civil rights community, another place to focus on was to stop the lynching of African-Americans.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We do not talk enough about trans Americans, especially African-American trans Americans...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... and the incredibly high rates of murder right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We don't talk enough about how many children, about 30 percent of LGBTQ kids, who do not go to school because of fear.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's not enough just to be on the Equality Act.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm an original co-sponsor.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to have a president that will fight to protect LGBTQ Americans every single day from violence in America.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Nuclear proliferation and climate change.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Gracias.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Fifty years ago this month, my family moved into the town I grew up in because after being denied a house because of the color of their skin, it was activists, mostly white activists, that stood up and fought for them.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's the best of who we are as America and why when I got out of law school, I moved into the inner city of Newark to fight as a tenant lawyer for other people's rights.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've taken on bullies and beat them.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've taken on tough fights and we've won.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we win those fights not by showing the worst of who we are, by rising to who's best.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Donald Trump wants us to fight him on his turf and his terms.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We will beat him, I will beat him by calling this country to a sense of common purpose again.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is a referendum on him and getting rid of him, but it's also a referendum on us, who we are, and who we must be to each other.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's time we win this election.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And the way I'll govern is by showing the best of who we are because that's what this country needs and deserves.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Thank you, Dana.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Last week the president of the United States attacked an American city, calling it "a disgusting, rat-infested rodent mess."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need a nation that understands that this tired old language, the...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will stand by.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Donald Trump, from Charleston to Baltimore to even the border, is using the tired, old language of demagogues, of fear-mongers, of racists, to try to divide our country against itself.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We know who Donald Trump is, but in this election, the question is who are we as a people?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have serious problems in America.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have deep wounds and seriously deeply rooted challenges.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We desperately need to heal as a nation and move forward.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Because we know in this country that our fates are united, that we have a common destiny.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The call of this election is the call to unite in common cause and common purpose.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's how we will beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's how I will beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And as your president, that's how I will govern and move us forward together.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, let me just say, that the person that's enjoying this debate most right now is Donald Trump, as we pit Democrats against each other, while he is working right now to take away Americans' healthcare.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There is a court case working through the system that's going to gut the Affordable Care Act and actually gut protections on preexisting conditions.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so, I was raised by two civil rights parents who told me, always keep your eyes on the prize.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And that is that in the United States of America, every Democrat should stand with the belief that everyone should have access to healthcare, that it's a human right.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And how we get there, it has to be to end this broken system, because we are on our way, just a handful of years of literally spending 20 percent of our economy, one out of every $5 spent on healthcare.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we spend more than every other nation, on everything from MRIs to insulin drugs, multiple mores than other countries - multiple more than other countries.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so, do you want to know what I'm going to do?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm going to work to get us to a point where Medicare for All - where everyone is covered.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But this pitting against progressives against moderates, saying one is unrealistic and the other doesn't care enough, that to me is dividing our party and demoralizing us in face of the real enemy here.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'm -

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: - going to keep fighting for that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I just want to say, again, tonight, we are playing into Republican hands who have a very different view, and they're trying to divide us against each other.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm listening to the language of my colleagues.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: No, Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President, we are not going to just let people cross the border.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: An unlawful crossing is an unlawful crossing, if you do it in the civil courts, or if you do in the criminal courts.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But the criminal courts is what is giving Donald Trump the ability to truly violate the human rights of people coming to our country, who no one surrenders their human rights.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so, doing it through the civil courts means that you won't need these awful detention facilities that I have been to; seeing children sleeping on pavement, people being put in cages, nursing mothers, small children.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is not necessary.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have seen, using the civil system, piloted programs that have 100 percent compliance with the civil courts, where people are evaluated.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If they have no justifiable reason to be here, they are returned.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If they are, like the people I met in Juarez, who were survivors of sexual assault, who we wouldn't even let come and present for asylum.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are butchering our values -

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: - and making ourselves less safe.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, a couple of things.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: First of all, Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President, you can't have it both ways.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You invoke President Obama more than anybody in this campaign.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You can't do it when it's convenient and then dodge it when it's not.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And the second thing that this really irks me because I heard the vice president say that if you got a PhD., you can come right into this country.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well that's playing into what the republicans want, to pit some immigrants against other immigrants.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: From are from shithole countries and some are from worthy countries.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to reform this whole immigration system and begin to be the country that says everyone has worth and dignity and this should be a country that honors for everyone.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Don't let the republicans divide this party against itself.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, my response is that this is a crisis in our country because we have treated issues of race and poverty, mental health and addiction with locking people up and not lifting them up.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President has said that, since the 1970s, every major crime bill -- every crime bill, major and minor, has had his name on it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And, Sir, those are your words, not -- not mine.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And this is one of those instances where the house was set on fire and you claimed responsibility for those laws.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And you can't just now come out with a plan to put out that fire.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have got to have far more bold action on criminal justice reform, like having true...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... marijuana justice, which means that we legalize it on a federal level...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... and reinvest the profits in communities that have been...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... disproportionately targeted by marijuana enforcement.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I'm grateful that he endorsed my presidency already.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But I'll tell you this, it's no secret that I inherited a criminal -- a police department with massive problems and decades-long challenges.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But the head of the ACLU has already said -- the head of the New Jersey ACLU -- that I put forth national standard-setting accountability.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President -- Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President, I didn't interrupt you.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Please show me that respect, sir.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have a system right now that's broken.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And if you want to compare records -- and, frankly, I'm shocked that you do...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I am happy to do that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Because all the problems that he is talking about, that he created, I actually led the bill that got passed into law that reverses the damage that your bills that you were, frankly -- to correct you, Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President -- you were bragging, calling it the Biden crime bill, up until 2015.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President, there's a saying in my community, you're dipping into the Kool-Aid and you don't even know the flavor.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You need to come to the city of Newark and see the reforms that we put in place.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The New Jersey head of the ACLU has said that I embraced reforms not just in action, but in deeds.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Sir, you are trying to shift the view from what you created.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There are people right now in prison for life for drug offenses because you stood up and used that "tough on crime" phony rhetoric that got a lot of people elected but destroyed communities like mine.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This isn't about the past, sir.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is about the present right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I believe in redemption.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm happy you evolved.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But you've offered no redemption to the people in prison right now for life.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I just want to take, first of all, a step back and say that I agree wholeheartedly with Governor Inslee.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's one of the reasons why Greenpeace ranks me and him at the top of this entire field of the candidates on climate.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm -- hey, hey.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I want to say very clearly -- thank you, man.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'll try harder.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, the reason why is because, first of all, this problem didn't start yesterday.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Science didn't become a reality yesterday.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This has been going on for years.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There was another president that would not join an international accord.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Then it was the Kyoto accords.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I was mayor then.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I stood up in national leadership joining with other mayors to say climate change is not a separate issue.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It must be the issue and the lens with which we view every issue.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Nobody should get applause for rejoining the Paris climate accords.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That is kindergarten.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have to go to far advances and make sure that everything from our trade deals, everything from the billions of dollars we spend to foreign aid, everything must be sublimated to the challenge and the crisis that is existential, which is dealing with the climate threat.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And, yes, the majority of this problem is outside the United States, but the only way we're going to deal with this is if the United States leads.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I -- I'm grateful -- I'm grateful.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Jake look, this is one of those times where we're not staring at the truth and calling it out.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And -- and this is a case for the Democratic Party, the truth will set us free.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We lost the state of Michigan because everybody from republicans to Russians were targeting the suppression of African American voters.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to say that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If the African American vote in this state had been like it was four years earlier, we would have won the state of Michigan.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to have a campaign that is ready for what's coming.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And all out of salt especially on the most valuable voter group in our -- in fact, the highest performing voter group in our coalition, which is black women.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so I will be a person that tries to fight against voter suppression and to activate and engage the kind of voters and coalitions who are going to win states like Michigan and Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I want to say very clearly that I will not do foreign policy by tweet as Donald Trump seems to do all the time.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: A guy that literally tweets out that we're pulling our troops out before his generals even know about it is creating a dangerous situation for our troops in places like Afghanistan.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so I will bring our troops home and I will bring them home as quickly as possible, but I will not set during a campaign an artificial deadline.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will make sure we do it, we do it expeditiously, we do it safely, to not create a vacuum that's ultimately going to destabilize the Middle East and perhaps create the environment for terrorism and for extremism to threaten our nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My response is exactly that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've read the report.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've read the redacted versions of the report.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have something that is astonishing going on in the United States of the America.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have a president that is not acting like the leader of the free world.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: He's acting like an authoritarian against the actual Constitution that he swore an oath to uphold.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so this is a difference with a lot of us on this debate stage.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I believe that we in the United States Congress should start impeachment proceedings immediately.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'll tell you this...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Debbie Stabenow now has joined my call for starting impeachment proceedings, because he is now stonewalling Congress, not allowing -- subjecting himself to the checks and balances.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We swore an oath to uphold the Constitution.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The politics of this be dammed.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: When we look back in history at what happened when a president of the United States started acting more like an authoritarian leader than the leader of the free world, the question is, is what will we have done?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I believe the Congress should do its job.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: First, I just want to give a lot of thanks to the city of Detroit.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They're hosting us today, and one of the reasons I respect this city is because it has the kind of defiant love that I find in many American cities, including the city of Newark.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And Detroit is turning around and Newark is turning around because we let no one divide us, no one demean or degrade us or underestimate or worth.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We pulled together and fought for common purpose and common cause.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's the history of this city.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My mom is sitting there who was born in the city of Detroit, born to a guy...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... that was a UAW worker, my grandfather, who pulled his family out of poverty in the Depression.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My grandmother joined him.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: She was really entrepreneurial, opened a pool hall and a laundromat right here in this city.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That is the American dream.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so many of us have stories like that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But the dream of this country is under threat right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: While, my mom's generation, 80 -- 95% of baby boomers did better than their parents.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's now just a coin toss for millennials.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have a real crisis in our country, and the crisis is Donald Trump, but not only Donald Trump.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I have a frustration that sometimes people are saying the only thing they want is to beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, that is the floor and not the ceiling.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The way we beat Donald Trump is not just focusing on him.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: He wants to take all the oxygen out of the room.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's when we start focusing on each other and understanding that our common bonds and our common purpose to address our common pain is what has saved us before.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's what's going to save us now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That is the kind of leader that I am going to be as president of the United States, not just uniting the Democratic Party but making sure that we put more "indivisible" back into this one nation under God.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And if you believe like I do, please go to corybooker.com and join the mission.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It was over 20 years ago that I was a law student and moved to inner-city Newark, New Jersey, to serve as a tenants rights lawyer to try to address the challenges in my community.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I was sobered by them - the gun violence, the substandard housing.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But it was my greatest mentor, a woman named Ms.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Virginia Jones, who challenged me.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: She said, "Boy, if all you see in this neighborhood is problems, that's all there's ever going to be.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But if you're stubborn and defiant and can put forth a vision that can unify people, then we can make transformative change."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: She was a church woman that said, "Without vision, the people will perish."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, that's exactly what we did.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We created extraordinary unity in our community, and we did things that other people think - thought was impossible.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's the story of America.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: At our best, we unify, we find common cause and common purpose.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The differences among us Democrats on the stage are not as great as the urgency for us to unite as a party, not just to beat Donald Trump, but to unite America in common cause and common purpose.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's why I'm running for president, and that's how I will lead this nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, there are a lot of people watching at home right now, listening to us that are afraid because they are in crisis.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They don't have health insurance.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Their health insurance doesn't go far enough.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They can't afford their prescription drugs.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, I'm clear in what I believe.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I believe in Medicare-for-all.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I believe it's the best way to rationalize the system.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But dear God, I know every one of my colleagues on this stage is in favor of universal health coverage and comes at this with the best of intentions.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'll tell you, there is an urgency right now in this nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Everybody feels it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And as a person who has an ideal, I know we cannot sacrifice progress on the altar of purity, because people in my community, they need help right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They have high blood pressure right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They have unaffordable insulin right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And this must be a moment where we as Democrats can begin to show that we cannot only stake and stand our ground, but find common ground, because we've got one shot to make Donald Trump a one-term president.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we cannot lose it by the way we talk about each other or demonize and degrade each other.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We can walk and chew gum at the same time.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If I am the leader, I will work towards the ideal of health insurance, health coverage being a right for all Americans.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But every single day, I'll join with other Democrats to make progress happen in our nation for the people that are struggling and suffering today.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first and foremost, I want to hit that point, because we know Donald Trump's a racist, but there is no red badge of courage for calling him that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Racism exists.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The question isn't who isn't a racist.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's who is and isn't doing something about racism.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And this is not just an issue that started yesterday.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's not just an issue that we hear a president that can't condemn white supremacy.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have systemic racism that is eroding our nation from health care to the criminal justice system.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And it's nice to go all the way back to slavery, but dear God, we have a criminal justice system that is so racially biased, we have more African-Americans under criminal supervision today than all the slaves in 1850.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have to come at this issue attacking systemic racism, having the courage to call it out, and having a plan to do something about it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If I am president of the United States, we will create an office in the White House to deal with the problem of white supremacy and hate crimes.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we will make sure that systemic racism is dealt with in substantive plans, from criminal justice reform to the disparities in health care to even one that we don't talk about enough, which is the racism that we see in environmental injustice in communities of color all around this country.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Our criminal justice system is so savagely broken.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There's no difference in America between blacks, whites and Latinos for using drugs or dealing drugs.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But if you are African-American, you are almost four times more likely to be arrested and incarcerated, destroying your lives.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so much of this comes down to privilege.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have a criminal justice system that Brian Stephenson says treats you better if you're rich and guilty than if you're poor and innocent.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so I have challenged this whole field.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We can specifically and demonstrably now show that there are 17,000 people unjustly incarcerated in America, and all of us should come forward and say, when we are president of the United States; when I am president of the United States, we will release them.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And let me be specific.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I joined together and led in the United States Senate the only major bipartisan bill to pass under this president, for criminal justice reform, that has already led to thousands of people coming out of jail.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If 87 members of the United States Senate says that these sentences are way too long, and we changed it, but we didn't make it retroactive, we could literally point to the people that are in jail unjustly right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Everyone on this stage should say that we are going to give clemency to these 17,000 people.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I challenge you.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Don't just say a big statement; back it up with details of the people in prison right now looking for one of the most sacrosanct ideals of this nation, which is liberty and freedom.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to reform this system and we must do it now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Every day we wait is too long.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So, background checks and gun licensing, these are agreed to by overwhelmingly the majority of Americans.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Eighty-three percent of Americans agree with licensing.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is the issue.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, I grew up in the suburbs.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It was about 20 years ago that I came out of my home when I moved to inner city Newark, New Jersey, and witnessed the aftermath of a shooting.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's one of the reasons why shooting after shooting after shooting in neighborhoods like mine for decades, this has been a crisis for me.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's why I was the first person to come out for gun licensing.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'm happy that people like Beto O'Rourke are showing such courage now and coming forward and also now supporting licensing.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But this is what I'm sorry about.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm sorry that it had to take issues coming to my neighborhood or personally affecting Beto to suddenly make us demand change.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is a crisis of empathy in our nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are never going to solve this crisis if we have to wait for it to personally affect us or our neighborhood or our community before we demand action.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You want to know how we get this done?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We get this done by having a more courageous empathy, where people don't wait for this hell to visit upon their communities.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: They stand up and understand the truth of what King said, that injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will lead change on this issue, because I have seen what the carnage creates in communities like mine, because we forget, national shootings, these mass shootings are tragedies, but the majority of the homicide victims come from neighborhoods like mine.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Nobody has ascended to the White House that will bring more personal passion on this issue.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will fight this and bring a fight to the NRA and the corporate gun lobby like they have never seen before.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You know, if that was the attitude when Strom Thurmond had the longest filibuster ever on civil rights, if it was this idea that we can't get it done because of the situation in the Senate, I'm looking to lead a movement.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The number-one reason why governments are formed is to protect the citizenry.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Think about this.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have had more people die due to gun violence in my lifetime than every single war in this country combined, from the Revolutionary War until now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is not a side issue to me.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is a central issue to me.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That is the kind of fight - because the majority of homicide victims - we have a mass shooting every single day in communities like mine.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We must awaken a more courageous empathy in this country so that we stand together and fight together and overwhelm those Republicans who are not even representing their constituency.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Because the majority of Americans, the majority of gun-owners agree with me, not the corporate gun lobby.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is time for a movement on this issue, and I will lead it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Sure.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There's one point we're really missing on the stage right now, which is the fact that Donald Trump's America first policy is actually an America isolated, an America alone policy.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: From trade to battling China to the global crisis of climate change, the challenges in the Middle East, he is pulling us away from our allies, out of the Iran deal, out of the Paris climate accords.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And on trade, he's deciding to take on China, while at the same time taking on tariff battles with all of our allies.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: You literally have him using a national security waiver to put tariffs on Canada.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Now, look, I'm the only person on this stage that finds Trudeau's hair very menacing, but they are not a national security threat.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We cannot go up against China alone.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is a president that has a better relationship with dictators, like Duterte and Putin, than he does with Merkel and Macron.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are the strongest nation on the planet Earth, and our strength is multiplied and magnified when we stand with our allies in common cause and common purpose.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's how we beat China.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's how we beat climate change on the planet Earth, and that's how American values are the ones that lead on issues of trade and workers' rights.

sentence: Um, you know, first of all, I want to say no.

sentence: Actually, I want to translate that into Spanish.

sentence: No.

sentence: Look, on - let's just be clear.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The factory farming going on that's assaulting this corporate consolidation of the agricultural industry, one of the reasons why I have a bill to put a moratorium on this kind of corporate consolidation is because this factory farming is destroying and hurting our environment.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And you see independent family farmers being pushed out of business because of the kind of incentives we are giving that don't line up with our values.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's what I'm calling for.

sentence: But I want to - I want to switch, because we don't have - a crowded debate stage, we were talking about Afghanistan and Iraq.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It annoys me that we had a conversation about our troops overseas and we didn't say one word about veterans in our country.

sentence: We have a shameful reality in America that we send people off to war and they often come home with invisible wounds, hurts and harms.

sentence: They're disproportionately homeless.

sentence: You hear stories about women waiting for months for gynecological care through the VA.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It is very important that, as we - as a country, understand that we are not going to solve every problem with this outrageous increased militarism, that we also make sure that we stand up for the people that stood for us.

sentence: We end our national anthem with "home of the brave."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It's about time we make this a better home for our bravest.
