sentence: Congressman O'Rourke, Hurricane Harvey hit this town two years ago.

sentence: And not only is the Amazon burning, Greenland is melting at a record pace.

sentence: And can we count on you to follow through if your donors are against it?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So, I'm hearing a lot of conversations on the stage that - and the way we talk about communities of color.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, I live in a black and brown community below the poverty line.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've lived in public housing projects almost for a decade and saw the anguish of parents who are just so deeply frustrated that they don't have a school that serves their genius.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I think I'm the only person on the stage - even though I had no formal authority as mayor to run a school system - I stepped up and took responsibility for our schools, and we produced results.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: A lot of folks here are talking about raising teacher salary.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We actually did it in Newark, New Jersey.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we didn't stop there.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Yeah, we closed poor-performing charter schools, but, dagnabbit, we expanded high-performing charter schools.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We were a city that said we need to find local solutions that work for our community.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The results speak for themselves.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We're now the number-one city in America for Beat the Odds schools, from high poverty to high performance.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Strategies like investing in our children work.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'll tell you this.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I am tired of us thinking about these problems isolated, disconnected from other issues.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That's why my friend, Secretary Castro, is 100 percent right.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are in the reality we are right now because, Mr.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Vice President, of overtly racist policies, not 400 years ago, just in my lifetime, that were red-lining communities, disinvesting in communities, and more than just that, my kids are not only struggling with racial segregation and housing and the challenges of underfunded schools, but they're also struggling with environmental injustice.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If you've talked to someone who's a parent of a child has had permanent brain damage because of lead, you'll know this is a national problem, because there's over 3,000 jurisdictions in America where children have more than twice the blood lead levels of Flint, Michigan.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so if I'm president of the United States, it is a holistic solution to education, from raising teacher salary, fully funded special education, but combating the issues of poverty, combating the issues of racial segregation, combating the issues of a criminal justice system...

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: ... that takes parents away from their kids, and dealing with environmental justice as a major pillar of any climate policy.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So my biggest professional setback is embarrassing because a lot of folks know about it.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I, with a bunch of tenant leaders in Newark, New Jersey, in 2002 took on the political machine and, boy, did they fight back.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I had tires on my car slashed.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Our campaign offices were broken into.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My phones were tapped.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It became a spectacle.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And we lost that election.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And here's a bit of advice to everybody.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: If you're going to have a spectacular failure, have a documentary team there to capture it, because it made for an Oscar-nominated documentary called "Street Fight."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But then, unfortunately, another setback.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It lost in the Oscars to a movie called "March of the Dagnab Penguins," for crying out loud.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The people in my community, living in the projects, told me, don't give up on the people and the people won't give up on you.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Create bigger and bolder coalitions, and you're going to win.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And you know what?

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We came back four years later and won the largest lopsided victory in our city's history.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But more than that, the lesson was there.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We didn't give up.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We were taking on America's toughest problems, from crime to poverty, and we transformed our city, creating tens of thousands of new jobs, the biggest economic expansion in our city, and as I said before, turned around our school system.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There's more work to do, but I haven't given up on the people.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I still live in that community.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But this is a big lesson.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My staff and my friends and my community told me, if you want to go fast, you may have won the mayor's race, but that's not what life is about.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: There's an old African saying that says, if you want to go fast, go alone.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But if you want to go far, go together.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: The lesson I learned of resilience is to trust people, because the power of the people is always greater than the people in power.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And the test of America right now is not a referendum on Donald Trump, it's a referendum on us and who we are and who we're going to be together.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We need to use this moment in history to unite in common cause and common purpose, and then there's nothing we can't do together as a nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So, first of all, we must be fair.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are talking about ongoing proceedings to remove a sitting president for office.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This has got to be about patriotism and not partisanship.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Look, I share the same sense of urgency of everybody on this stage.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I understand the outrage that we all feel.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But we have to conduct this process in a way that is honorable, that brings our country together, doesn't rip us apart.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Anybody who has criticisms about a process that is making all the facts bare before the American public, that works to build consensus, that's what this nation needs, in what is a moral moment and not a political one.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So I swore an oath to do my job as a senator, do my duty.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This president has violated his.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I will do mine.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I'm happy to get in finally.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I just want to say, as a great -- as a great New Jersian, Yogi Berra, said, "I am having deja vu all over again."

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm having deja vu all over again, first of all, because I saw this play in 2016's election.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are literally using Donald Trump's lies.

sentence: And the second issue we cover on this stage is elevating a lie and attacking a statesman.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: That was so offensive.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: He should not have to defend ourselves.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And the only person sitting at home that was enjoying that was Donald Trump seeing that we're distracting from his malfeasance and selling out of his office.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'm having deja vu all over again.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I'm having deja vu all over again because we have another health care debate, and we're not talking about the clear and existential threat in America that we're in a state that has had two Planned Parenthoods close.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We are seeing all over this country women's reproductive rights under attack.

sentence: It is not just because women are our daughters and our friends and our wives.

sentence: And people deserve to control their own bodies.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, the one point I wanted to make about the UBI conversation -- and I hope that my friend, Andrew Yang, will come out for this -- doing more for workers than UBI would actually be just raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It would put more money in people's pockets than giving them $1,000 a month.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have to start putting the dignity back in work.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And, number one, you start having trade deals, not like this thing that the president is trying to push through Congress right now that gives pharmaceutical companies and other corporations benefits and doesn't put workers at the center of every trade deal.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We must make sure we are not giving corporate tax incentives for people to move jobs out of our country, but start to put the worker at the center of that and make sure that they have the resources to succeed.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But it's more than that.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I stood with these workers because we're seeing this trend all over our country.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I stood with unions because, right now, unions in America are under attack.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: As union membership has gone down, we have seen a stratification of wealth and income in this country.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So the other thing that I'll do as president of the United States is begin to fight again to see union strength in this country spread, to make sure we have sectoral bargaining so that unions from the auto workers all the way to fast food workers can ensure that we improve workers' conditions and make sure that every American has a living wage in this country.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, first of all, I just want to be respond by -- you know, we've got one shot to make Donald Trump a one-term president.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And how we talk about each other in this debate actually really matters.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I've had the privilege of working with or being friends with everybody on this stage, and tearing each other down because we have a different plan to me is unacceptable.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I have seen this script before.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: It didn't work in 2016, and it will be a disaster for us in 2020.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so I have a different plan than Elizabeth Warren.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I have a different plan than many people on this stage.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And it involves, again, fair taxes for the richest.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have a lot of work to do there.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: But we've had 20 years of presidential debates, and we have never talked about the violence in America of child poverty.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We have got to begin to talk more eloquently and persuasively and urgently about doing the things not just to make sure fair taxes are paid by people on the top, but that we deal with the moral obscenity of having the highest levels of child poverty in the industrial world.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: My plan will focus on that, and these are some of the issues we should be talking about, not defining ourselves just by what we're against, but we need to win this election by talking about who and what we are for.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: So, first of all, understand that this president is turning the moral leadership of this country into a dumpster fire.

sentence: We literally have great generals like Mattis who said on the world stage, the United States of America, there can be no better friend than the United States of America and no better -- no greater enemy than the United States of America.

sentence: This president has turned that upside down and now is doing things to undermine our critical alliances and partner with Russia.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And so clearly, to your question, number one, we cannot allow the Russians to continue to grow in influence by abandoning the world stage.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We cannot allow Russia to not only interfere in the democracies of the Ukraine, and Latvia, and Lithuania, but even not calling them out for their efforts to interfere in this democracy are unacceptable.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Russia and Putin understand strength, and this president time and time again is showing moral weakness.

sentence: He makes promises to the American people that he's going to protect this nation.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: Well, instead of doing something to defeat ISIS, he's now given them a foothold again.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is an American president that even right now is lying to the American public and saying he's bringing our troops home, at the same time he's increasing troop presence with the Saudis, while they're involved in an unjust war that is killing tens of thousands of children in Yemen.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This president is making us less safe.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: He is partnering more with Putin than he is with Merkel and Macron.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And as president of the United States, I will stop this and restore American integrity abroad.

sentence: Well, look, I again, worry about how we talk to each other and about each other and what this last week has shown.

sentence: There was a young man in my neighborhood, I watched him grow up.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I lived in some high-rise projects with him named Shahad, and he was murdered on my block last year with an assault rifle.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: I'm living with a sense of urgency on this problem, because when I go home to my community, like millions of Americans, we live in communities where these weapons, where these gun shots are real every single day.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: And I know where the American public is.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is not about leadership.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: This is why when I talk about things like gun licensing and point out the differences between us, I'm not attacking people or their character or their courage on these issues.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We all have courage.

sentence: But it's frustrating that when the American people, 77 percent of Americans agree on licensing, we don't need leadership right now.

speaker: Cory Booker
sentence: We just need folks that are going to stand up and follow where the people already are, because there are millions of Americans where this is a daily nightmare, where we're surrendering our freedoms...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I think of it this way.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Who is this economy really working for?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's doing great for a thinner and thinner slice at the top.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's doing great for giant drug companies.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's just not doing great for people who are trying to get a prescription filled.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's doing great for people who want to invest in private prisons, just not for the African Americans and Latinx whose families are torn apart, whose lives are destroyed, and whose communities are ruined.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's doing great for giant oil companies that want to drill everywhere, just not for the rest of us who are watching climate change bear down upon us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When you've got a government, when you've got an economy that does great for those with money and isn't doing great for everyone else, that is corruption, pure and simple.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to call it out.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to attack it head on.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we need to make structural change in our government, in our economy, and in our country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So the way I understand this, it's there is way too much consolidation now in giant industries in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That hurts workers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It hurts small businesses.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It hurts independent farmers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It hurts our economy overall.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And it helps constrict real innovation and growth in this economy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Now, look, we've had the laws out there for a long time to be able to fight back.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What's been missing is courage, courage in Washington to take on the giants.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's part of the corruption in this system.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It has been far too long that the monopolies have been making the campaign contributions, have been funding the super PACs, have been out there making sure that their influence is heard and felt in every single decision that gets made in Washington.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Where I want to start this is I want to return government to the people, and that means calling out the names of the monopolists and saying I have the courage to go after them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So we've had an industrial policy in the United States for decades now, and it's basically been let giant corporations do whatever they want to do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Giant corporations have exactly one loyalty, and that is to profits.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And if they can save a nickel by moving a job to Mexico or to Asia or to Canada, they're going to do it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So here's what I propose for an industrial policy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Start with a place where there's a real need.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: There's going to be a worldwide need for green technology, ways to clean up the air, ways to clean up the water.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we can be the ones to provide that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to go tenfold in our research and development on green energy going forward.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And then we need to say any corporation can come and use that research.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They can make all kinds of products from it, but they have to be manufactured right here in the United States of America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And then we have to double down and sell it around the world.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: There's a $23 trillion market coming for green products.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We should be the leaders and the owners, and we should have that 1.2 million manufacturing jobs here in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can do this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm with Bernie on Medicare for all.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And let me tell you why.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I spent a big chunk of my life studying why families go broke.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And one of the number-one reasons is the cost of health care, medical bills.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And that's not just for people who don't have insurance.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's for people who have insurance.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look at the business model of an insurance company.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's to bring in as many dollars as they can in premiums and to pay out as few dollars as possible for your health care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That leaves families with rising premiums, rising copays, and fighting with insurance companies to try to get the health care that their doctors say that they and their children need.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Medicare for all solves that problem.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I understand.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: There are a lot of politicians who say, oh, it's just not possible, we just can't do it, have a lot of political reasons for this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What they're really telling you is they just won't fight for it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Well, health care is a basic human right, and I will fight for basic human rights...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... point, though, and that is that the insurance companies last year alone sucked $23 billion in profits out of the health care system, $23 billion.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And that doesn't count the money that was paid to executives, the money that was spent lobbying Washington.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a giant industry that wants our health care system to stay the way it is, because it's not working for families, but it's sure as heck working for them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's time for us to make families come first.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I would make certain that every woman has access to the full range of reproductive health care services, and that includes birth control, it includes abortion, it includes everything for a woman.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I want to add on that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's not enough for us to expect the courts to protect us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Forty-seven years ago, Roe v.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Wade was decided, and we've all looked to the courts all that time, as state after state has undermined Roe, has put in exceptions, has come right up to the edge of taking away protections...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We now have an America where most people support Roe v.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Wade.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to make that a federal law.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, in this period of time that I have been running for president, I've had more than 100 town halls.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've taken more than 2,000 unfiltered questions.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the single hardest questions I've gotten, I got one from a little boy and I got one from a little girl, and that is to say, when you're president, how are you going to keep us safe?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's our responsibility as adults.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Seven children will die today from gun violence, children and teenagers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And they won't just die in mass shootings.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They'll die on sidewalks, they'll die in playgrounds, they'll die in people's backyards.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Gun violence is a national health emergency in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we need to treat it like that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So what can we do?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can do the things that are sensible.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can do the universal background checks.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can ban the weapons of war.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But we can also double down on the research and find out what really works, where it is that we can make the differences at the margins that will keep our children safe.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to treat this like the virus that's killing our children.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What I think we need to do is we need to treat it like a serious research problem, which we have not done.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, guns in the hands of a collector who's had them for decades, who's never fired them, who takes safety seriously, that's very different from guns that are sold and turned over quickly.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can't treat this as an across-the-board problem.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to treat it like a public health emergency.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That means bring data to bear and it means make real change in this country, whether it's politically popular or not.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to fight for our children.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We are democracy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
