sentence: What this is about is making sure that we have the most efficient way possible to pay for health care for everyone in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Insurance companies last year sucked $23 billion in profits out of the system.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: How did they make that money?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Every one of those $23 billion was made by an insurance company saying no to your health care coverage.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So let's start by framing the problem the right way.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a gun violence problem in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The mass shootings are terrible, but they get all the headlines.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Children die every day on streets, in neighborhoods, on playgrounds.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People die from violence, from suicide and domestic abuse.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a gun violence problem in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we agree on many steps we could take to fix it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: My view on this is, we're going to - it's not going to be one and done on this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We're going to do it, and we're going to have to do it again, and we're going to have to come back some more until we cut the number of gun deaths in this country significantly.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But here's the deal.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The question we need to ask is, when we've got this much support across the country, 90 percent of Americans want to see us do - I like registration - want to see us do background checks, want to get assault weapons off the streets, why doesn't it happen?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the answer is corruption, pure and simple.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a Congress that is beholden to the gun industry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And unless we're willing to address that head-on and roll back the filibuster, we're not going to get anything done on guns.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was in the United States Senate when 54 senators said let's do background checks, let's get rid of assault weapons, and with 54 senators, it failed because of the filibuster.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Until we attack the systemic problems, we can't get gun reform in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We've got to go straight against the industry and we've got to change Congress, so it doesn't just work for the wealthy and well-connected, so it works for the people.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Well, I start with a statement of principles, and that is, in this country, immigration does not make us weaker, immigration makes us stronger.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to see us expand legal immigration and create a pathway to citizenship for our DREAMers, but also for their grandparents, and for their cousins, for people who have overstayed student visas, and for people who came here to work in the fields.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to have a system that is a path to citizenship that is fair and achievable.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Down at the border, we've got to rework this entirely.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: A system right now that cannot tell the difference in the threat posed by a terrorist, a criminal, and a 12-year-old girl is not a system that is keeping us safer, and it is not serving our values.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need - I want to add one more part on this, because I think we have to look at all the pieces.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Why do we have a crisis at the border?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: In no small part because we have withdrawn help from people in Central America who are suffering.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to restore that help.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to help establish and re-establish the rule of law so that people don't feel like they have to flee for their lives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a crisis that Donald Trump has created and hopes to profit from politically.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to have the courage to stand up and fight back.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, yes - oh, I'm sorry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Did you me or...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Oh, he said it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Okay.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Sorry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So our trade policy in America has been broken for decades, and it has been broken because it works for giant multinational corporations and not for much of anyone else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: These are giant corporations that, shoot, if they can save a nickel by moving a job to a foreign country, they'll do it in a heartbeat.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And yet for decades now, who's been whispering in the ears of our trade negotiators?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Who has shaped our trade policy?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's been the giant corporations.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's been their lobbyists and their executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The way we change our trade policy in America is, first, the procedures.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Who sits at the table?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to negotiate trade with unions at the table.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to negotiate it with small farmers at the table.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to negotiate it with environmentalists at the table.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to negotiate with human rights activists at the table.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And you asked the question about leverage.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: If I can just respond to that one, the leverage, are you kidding?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Everybody wants access to the American market.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That means that we have the capacity to say right here in America, you want to come sell goods to American consumers?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Then you got to raise your standards.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You've got to raise your labor standards.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You've got to raise your environmental standards...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... so our companies can compete on a level playing field.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can use trade not to undermine American workers and not to undermine American farms and not to undermine small businesses in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can use trade to help build a stronger economy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I'll tell you why.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What we're doing right now in Afghanistan is not helping the safety and security of the United States.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is not helping the safety and security of the world.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is not helping the safety and security of Afghanistan.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to bring our troops home.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And then we need to make a big shift.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We cannot ask our military to keep solving problems that cannot be solved militarily.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We're not going to bomb our way to a solution in Afghanistan.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to treat the problem of terrorism as a worldwide problem, and that means we need to be working with all of our allies, our European allies, our Canadian allies, our Asian allies, our allies in Africa and in South America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to work together to root out terrorism.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It means using all of our tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It means economic investment.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It means expanding our diplomatic efforts instead of hollowing out the State Department and deliberately making it so we have no eyes and ears in many of these countries.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need a foreign policy that is about our security and about leading on our values.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was in Afghanistan with John McCain two years ago this past summer.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think it may have been Senator McCain's last trip before he was sick.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I talked to people - we did - we talked to military leaders, American and local leaders, we talked to people on the ground and asked the question, the same one I ask on the Senate Armed Services Committee every time one of the generals comes through: Show me what winning looks like.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Tell me what it looks like.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And what you hear is a lot of, "Uh," because no one can describe it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the reason no one can describe it is because the problems in Afghanistan are not problems that can be solved by a military.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have three older brothers who all served in the military.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I understand firsthand the kind of commitment they have made.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They will do anything we ask them to do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But we cannot ask them to solve problems that they alone cannot solve.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to work with the rest of the world.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to use our economic tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to use our diplomatic tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to build with our allies.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we need to make the whole world safer, not keep troops bombing in Afghanistan.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to work on every front on climate change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is the threat to every living thing on this planet and we are running out of time.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Every time the scientists go back, they say, we have less and less time than we thought we had.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But that means we've got to use all the tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: One of the tools we need to use are our regulatory tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have proposed following Governor Inslee, that we, by 2028, cut all carbon emissions from new buildings.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: By 2030, carbon emissions from cars.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And by 2035, all carbon emissions from the manufacture of electricity.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That alone, those three, will cut our emissions here in the United States by 70 percent.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can do this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We also need to help around the world to clean, but understand this one more time.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Why doesn't it happen?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: As long as Washington is paying more attention to money than it is to our future, we can't make the changes we need to make.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to attack the corruption head-on so that we can save our planet.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I think I'm the only person on this stage who has been a public school teacher.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I had wanted to be a public school teacher since I was in second grade.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And let's be clear in all the ways we talk about this, money for public schools should stay in public schools, not go anywhere else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've already made my commitment.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I will - we will have a secretary of education who has been a public school teacher.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think this is ultimately about our values.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have proposed a two-cent wealth tax on the top one-tenth of one percent in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That would give us enough money to start with our babies by providing universal child care for every baby age zero to five, universal pre-K for every three-year-old and four-year-old in this country...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... raise the wages of every child-care worker and preschool teacher in this country, cancel student loan debt for 95 percent of the folks who've got it...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... and strengthen our unions.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is how we build an America that reflects our values, not just where the money comes from with the billionaires and corporate executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I mentioned earlier, I've known what I wanted to be since second grade.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I wanted to be a public school teacher.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I invested early.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I used to line my dollies up and teach school.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I had a reputation for being tough but fair.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: By the time I graduated from high school, my family didn't have money for a college application, much less to send me off to four years at a university.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And my story, like a lot of stories, has a lot of twists and turns.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Got a scholarship, and then at 19, I got married, dropped out of school, took a minimum wage job, thought my dream was over.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I got a chance down the road at the University of Houston.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I made it as a special needs teacher.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I still remember that first year as a special needs teacher.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I could tell you what those babies looked like.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I had 4- to 6-year-olds.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But at the end of that first year, I was visibly pregnant.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And back in the day, that meant that the principal said to me - wished me luck and hired someone else for the job.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, there I am, I'm at home, I got a baby, I can't have a job.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What am I going to do?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Here's resilience.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I said, I'll go to law school.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the consequence was - I practiced law for about 45 minutes and then went back to my first love, which was teaching.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But it let me get into fights.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It gave me new tools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the reason I'm standing here today is because I got back up, I fought back.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I know what's broken.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to be in the fight to fix it in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's why I'm here.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Because sometimes there are issues that are bigger than politics.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I think that's the case with this impeachment inquiry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When I made the decision to run for president, I certainly didn't think it was going to be about impeachment.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But when the Mueller report came out, I read it, all 442 pages.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And when I got to the end, I realized that Mueller had shown, too, a fare-thee-well, that this president had obstructed justice and done it repeatedly.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And so at that moment, I called for opening an impeachment inquiry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Now, that didn't happen.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And look what happened as a result.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Donald Trump broke the law again in the summer, broke it again this fall.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, we took a constitutional oath, and that is that no one is above the law, and that includes the president of the United States.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Impeachment is the way that we establish that this man will not be permitted to break the law over and over without consequences.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is about Donald Trump, but, understand, it's about the next president and the next president and the next president and the future of this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The impeachment must go forward.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I have made clear what my principles are here, and that is costs will go up for the wealthy and for big corporations, and for hard-working middle-class families, costs will go down.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, the way I see this is, I have been out all around this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've done 140 town halls now, been to 27 states and Puerto Rico.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Shoot, I've done 70,000 selfies, which must be the new measure of democracy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And this gives people a chance to come up and talk to me directly.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I have talked with the family, the mom and dad whose daughter's been diagnosed with cancer.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have talked to the young woman whose mother has just been diagnosed with diabetes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've talked to the young man who has MS.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And here's the thing about all of them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They all had great health insurance right at the beginning.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But then they found out when they really needed it, when the costs went up, that the insurance company pulled the rug out from underneath them and they were left with nothing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, the way I see this, it is hard enough to get a diagnosis that your child has cancer, to think about the changes in your family if your mom has diabetes, or what it means for your life going forward if you've been diagnosed with MS.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But what you shouldn't have to worry about is how you're going to pay for your health care after that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So the way I see this, it is about what kinds of costs middle-class families are going to face.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So let me be clear on this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Costs will go up for the wealthy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They will go up for big corporations.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And for middle-class families, they will go down.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I will not sign a bill into law that does not lower costs for middle-class families.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, let's be clear.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Whenever someone hears the term Medicare for all who want it, understand what that really means.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's Medicare for all who can afford it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And that's the problem we've got.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Medicare for all is the gold standard.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is the way we get health care coverage for every single American, including the family whose child has been diagnosed with cancer, including the person who's just gotten an MS diagnosis.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's how we make sure that everyone gets health care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can pay for this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've laid out the basic principles.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Costs are going to go up for the wealthy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They're going to go up for big corporations.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They will not go up for middle-class families.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I will not sign a bill into law that raises their costs, because costs are what people care about.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've been studying this, you know, for the biggest part of my life...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... why people go bankrupt.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Sure.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'd like to be able to respond...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So my view on this, and what I have committed to, is costs will go down for hardworking, middle-class families.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I will not embrace a plan like Medicare for all who can afford it that will leave behind millions of people who cannot.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I will not embrace a plan that says people have great insurance right up until you get the diagnosis and the insurance company says, "Sorry, we're not covering your expensive cancer treatments, we're not covering your expensive treatments for MS."

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: "We're not covering what you need."

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I didn't spend most of my time in Washington.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I spent most of my time studying one basic question, and that is why hardworking people go broke.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And one of the principal reasons for that is the cost of health care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And back when I was studying it, two out of every three families that ended up in bankruptcy after a serious medical problem had health insurance.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The problem we've got right now is the overall cost of health care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And, look, you can try to spin this any way you want.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've spent my entire life on working on how America's middle class has been hollowed out and how we fight back.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I've put out nearly 50 plans on how we can fight back and how we can rebuild an America that works.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And a part is that is we have got to stop...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Americans from going bankrupt over health care costs.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So the data show that we have had a lot of problems with losing jobs, but the principal reason has been bad trade policy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The principal reason has been a bunch of corporations, giant multinational corporations who've been calling the shots on trade, giant multinational corporations that have no loyalty to America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They have no loyalty to American workers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They have no loyalty to American consumers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They have no loyalty to American communities.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They are loyal only to their own bottom line.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have a plan to fix that, and it's accountable capitalism.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It says, you want to have one of the giant corporations in America?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Then, by golly, 40 percent of your board of directors should be elected by your employees.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That will make a difference when a corporation decides, gee, we could save a nickel by moving a job to Mexico, when there are people on the board in the boardroom saying, no, do you know what that does to our company, do you know what that does to our community, to what it does to our workers?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We also need to make it easier to join a union and give unions more power when they negotiate.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to restructure strength in this economy, and that's where it starts.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I understand that what we're all looking for is how we strengthen America's middle class.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And actually, I think the thing closest to the universal basic income is Social Security.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's one of the reasons that I've put forward a plan to extend the solvency of Social Security by decades and add $200 to the payment of every person who receives Social Security right now and every person who receives disability insurance right now.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That $200 a month will lift nearly 5 million families out of poverty.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And it will sure loosen up the budget for a whole lot more.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It also has a provision for your wife, for those who stay home to do caregiving for children or for seniors, and creates an opportunity for them to get credit on their Social Security.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So after a lifetime of hard work, people are entitled to retire with dignity.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I see this as an important question about just -- I want to understand the data on this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I want to make sure we're responding to make this work.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I think this is about our values as a country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Show me your budget, show me your tax plans, and we'll know what your values are.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And right now in America, the top 0.1 percent have so much wealth -- understand this -- that if we put a 2 cent tax on their 50 millionth and first dollar, and on every dollar after that, we would have enough money to provide universal childcare for every baby in this country, age zero to five, universal pre-K for every child, raise the wages of every childcare worker and preschool teacher in America, provide for universal tuition-free college, put $50 billion into historically black colleges and universities...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... and cancel -- no, let me finish, please, and cancel student loan debt for 95 percent of the people who have it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: My question is not why do Bernie and I support a wealth tax.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's why is it does everyone else on this stage think it is more important to protect billionaires than it is to invest in an entire generation of Americans?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So understand, taxing income is not going to get you where you need to be the way taxing wealth does, that the rich are not like you and me.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The really, really billionaires are making their money off their accumulated wealth, and it just keeps growing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need a wealth tax in order to make investments in the next generation.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, I understand that this is hard, but I think as Democrats we are going to succeed when we dream big and fight hard, not when we dream small and quit before we get started.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I'm really shocked at the notion that anyone thinks I'm punitive.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, I don't have a beef with billionaires.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: My problem is you made a fortune in America, you had a great idea, you got out there and worked for it, good for you.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But you built that fortune in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I guarantee you built it in part using workers all of us helped pay to educate.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You built it in part getting your goods to markets on roads and bridges all of us helped pay for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You built it at least in part protected by police and firefighters all of us help pay the salaries for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And all I'm saying is, you make it to the top, the top 0.1 percent, then pitch in two cents so every other kid in America has a chance to make it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's what this is about.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But that is...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That is the point.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is universal childcare for every baby in this country, early educational opportunities for every child, universal pre-K no matter where you live for every 3-year-old and 4-year-old.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Raising the wages -- no, raising the wages of every childcare worker and preschool teacher in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is about universal college, about investment in our HBCUs, about making sure that we get rid of the student loan debt burden that is crushing...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, look, I think that we ought to get out of the Middle East.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I don't think we should have troops in the Middle East.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But we have to do it the right way, the smart way.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What this president has done is that he has sucked up to dictators, he has made impulsive decisions that often his own team doesn't understand, he has cut and run on our allies, and he has enriched himself at the expense of the United States of America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: In Syria, he has created a bigger-than-ever humanitarian crisis.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: He has helped ISIS get another foothold, a new lease on life.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I sit on the Armed Services Committee.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I talk with our military leaders about this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was in Iraq and went through the neighborhoods that ISIS destroyed.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to get out, but we need to do this through a negotiated solution.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: There is no military solution in this region.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, look, I want to get what works done.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to use the method we used, for example, with machine guns.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We registered them, we put in a huge penalty if you didn't register them, and a huge tax on them, and then let people turn them in, and it got machine guns out of the hands of people.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But the problem here that we need to focus on is, first, how widespread gun violence is.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: As you've rightly identified, it's not just about mass shootings.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's what happens in neighborhoods all across this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is about suicide, and it is about domestic violence.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is not going to be a one and done, that we do one thing or two things or three things and then we're done.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to reduce gun violence overall.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the question we have to ask is, why hasn't it happened?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You say we're so close.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have been so close.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I stood in the United States Senate in 2013...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... when 54 senators voted in favor of gun legislation and it didn't pass because of the filibuster.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have got to attack the corruption and repeal the filibuster or the gun industry will always have a veto over what happens.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Well, I say, I will out-work, out-organize, and outlast anyone, and that includes Donald Trump, Mike Pence, or whoever the Republicans get stuck with.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, the way I see this, the way we're going to win is by addressing head-on what millions of Americans know in their bones, and that is that the wealthy and the well-connected have captured our democracy, and they're making it work for themselves and leaving everyone else behind.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And political pundits and Washington insiders and, shoot, people in our own party don't want to admit that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They think that running some kind of vague campaign that nibbles around the edges of big problems in this country is a winning strategy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They are wrong.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: If all Democrats can promise is after Donald Trump it will be business as usual, then we will lose.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Democrats win when we call out what's broken and we show how to fix it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Democrats will win when we fight for the things that touch people's lives, things like childcare and health care and housing costs.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Democrats will win when we give people a reason to get in the fight.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, I'm not willing to give up and let a handful of monopolists dominate our economy and our democracy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's time to fight back.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Think about it this way.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When you talk about how it works in competition, about 8 percent, 9 percent of all retail sales happen at bricks and sticks stores, happen at Walmart.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: About 49 percent of all sales online happen in one place: that's Amazon.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It collects information from every little business, and then Amazon does something else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It runs the platform, gets all the information, and then goes into competition with those little businesses.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, you get to be the umpire in the baseball game, or you get to have a team, but you don't get to do both at the same time.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to enforce our antitrust laws, break up these giant companies that are dominating, big tech, big pharma, big oil, all of them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, look, I don't just want to push Donald Trump off Twitter.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to push him out of the White House.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's our job.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But let's figure -- no.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Let's figure out...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... why it is that we have had laws on the books for antitrust for over a century, and yet for decades now, we've all called on how the big drug companies are calling the shots in Washington, big ag, how the gun industry, big tech -- you know, we really need to address the elephant in the room, and that is how campaigns are financed.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I announced this morning -- I announced this morning that I'm not going to take any money from big tech executives, from Wall Street executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We've already agreed, Bernie and I, we're not taking any money from big pharma executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You can't go behind closed doors and take the money of these executives and then turn around and expect that these are the people who are actually finally going to enforce the laws.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need campaign finance rules and practices...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... that support us all.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, I think all of the rules should apply across the board.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I don't have a problem with that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What I do have a problem with is that if we're going to talk seriously about breaking up big tech, then we should ask if people are taking money from the big tech executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: If we're going to talk seriously about breaking up big drug companies, we should ask if people are financing their campaigns by taking money from big drug executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: If we are going to talk about Wall Street and having some serious regulation over Wall Street, we should ask if people are funding their campaigns by taking money from those executives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think there are a number of options.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think, as Mayor Buttigieg said, there are many different ways.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People are talking about different options, and I think we may have to talk about them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But on Roe v.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Wade, can we just pause for a minute here?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I lived in an America where abortion was illegal, and rich women still got abortions, because they could travel, they could go to places where it was legal.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What we're talking about now is that the people who are denied access to abortion are the poor, are the young, are 14-year-olds who were molested by a family member.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we now have support across this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Three out of four Americans believe in the rule of Roe v.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Wade.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When you've got three out of four Americans supporting it, we should be able to get that passed through Congress.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We should not leave this to the Supreme Court.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We should do it through democracy, because we can.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So you started this question with how you got something done.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, following the financial crash of 2008, I had an idea for a consumer agency that would keep giant banks from cheating people.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And all of the Washington insiders and strategic geniuses said, don't even try, because you will never get it passed.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And sure enough, the big banks fought us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The Republicans fought us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Some of the Democrats fought us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But we got that agency passed into law.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It has now forced big banks to return more than $12 billion directly to people they cheated.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I served in the Obama administration.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I know what we can do by executive authority, and I will use it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: In Congress, on the first day, I will pass my anti-corruption bill, which will beat back the influence of money...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... and repeal the filibuster.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the third, we want to get something done in America, we have to get out there and fight...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... for the things that touch people's lives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I am deeply grateful to President Obama, who fought so hard to make sure that agency was passed into law, and I am deeply grateful to every single person who fought for it and who helped pass it into law.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But understand...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But understand this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It was a dream big, fight hard.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People told me, go for something little, go for something small, go for something that the big corporations will be able to accept.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I said, no, let's go for an agency that will make structural change in our economy.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And President Obama said, I will fight for that, and he sometimes had to fight against people in his own administration.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to be willing to make good, big, structural change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Now, people who are struggling to pay health care are fighting today.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People who are getting crushed by student loans are in a fight today.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People who are getting stopped by the police or paid less because of the color of their skin are in a fight today.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And anyone who doesn't understand that Americans are already in these fights is not someone who is likely to win them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: For me, this is about knowing what's broken, knowing how to fix it, and, yes, I'm willing to get out there and fight for it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You ask about a surprising friend.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: For me, it would be Charles Fried.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Twenty-seven years ago, when I was under consideration for a job, he was someone who had been George Bush, the first, solicitor general, a deeply principled Republican.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we didn't agree on much.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was far more liberal than he was.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But he also was willing to listen to my work about what's happening to America's middle class.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And Charles engaged with it over and over and ultimately is the person who made sure I got the job.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I grew up out in Oklahoma.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have three elder brothers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They all served in the military.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Two of the three are still Republicans.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I love all three of my brothers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And there are a lot of things that we're divided on, but there are core things that we believe in together.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We want to see all of our children get a good start in life.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We don't want to see any of our friends or neighbors not get covered by health care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We're willing to get out there for the things we believe in.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, people across this country, whether they're Democrats, independents, or Republicans, they know what's broken.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They know that we have an America that's working better and better and better for a thinner and thinner and thinner slice at the top and leaving everyone else behind.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: People across this country, regardless of party, are ready to say no more, we want an America that works for everyone. 2020 is our moment in history.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It is a deep honor to be here, to be in this fight.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I know what's broken.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I know how to fix it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we are building a grassroots movement to get it done that includes everyone.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Of course I will.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the obvious answer is to say, first, read the Mueller report, all 442 pages of it, that showed how the president tried to obstruct justice, and when Congress failed to act at that moment, and that the president felt free to break the law again and again and again.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And that's what's happened with Ukraine.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to establish the principle: no one is above the law.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a constitutional responsibility, and we need to meet it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But I want to add one more part based on today's testimony, and that is, how did Ambassador Sondland get there?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, this is not a man who had any qualifications, except one: He wrote a check for a million dollars.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And that tells us about what's happening in Washington, the corruption, how money buys its way into Washington.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I raised this months ago about the whole notion that donors think they're going to get ambassadorships on the other side.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I've taken a pledge.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Anyone who wants to give me a big donation, don't ask to be an ambassador, because I'm not going to have that happen.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I asked everyone who's running for president to join me in that and not a single person has so far.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I hope what we saw today during the testimony means lots of people will sign on and say we are not going to give away these ambassador posts to the highest bidder.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I think the way we achieve our goals and bring our country together is we talk about the things that unite us, and that is that we want to build an America that works for the people, not one that just works for rich folks.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I have proposed a two cent wealth tax.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That is a tax for everybody who has more than $50 billion in assets, your first $50 billion is free and clear.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But your 50 billionth and first dollar, you've got to pitch in 2 cents.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And when you hit a billion dollars, you've got to pinch in a few pennies more.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Here's the thing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Doing a wealth tax is not about punishing anyone.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's about saying, you built something great in this country?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Good for you.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But you did it using workers all of us helped pay to educate.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You did it using -- you're getting your goods on roads and bridges all of us helped pay for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You did it protected by police and firefighters all of us helped pay the salaries for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So when you make it big, when you make it really big, when you make it top one tenth of one percent big, pitch in two cents so everybody else gets a chance to make it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And here's the thing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's something that Democrats care about, independents care about, and Republicans care about, because regardless of party affiliation, people understand across this country, our government is working better and better for the billionaires, for the rich, for the well-connected, and worse and worse for everyone else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We come together when we acknowledge that and say we're going to make real change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Sure.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So let me just tell you what we can do with that two cent wealth tax.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Two cents on the top one-tenth of one percent in this country, and we can provide universal child care for every baby in this country ages zero to five.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That is transformative.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can provide universal pre-K for every 3-year-old and 4-year-old in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can stop exploiting the women, largely black and brown women, who do this work.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we can raise the wages of every childcare worker and pre-schoolteacher in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can put $800 billion new federal dollars into all of our public schools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can make college tuition-free for every kid.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can put $50 billion into historically black colleges and universities.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we can cancel student loan debt for 95 percent of the folks who've got it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Two cent wealth tax and we can invest in an entire generation's future.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Sure.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I just -- the idea behind what is fair, today, the 99 percent in America are on track to pay about 7.2 percent of their total wealth in taxes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The top one-tenth of one percent that I want to say pay two cents more, they'll pay 3.2 percent in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm tired of freeloading billionaires.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think it's time that we ask those at the very top to pay more so that every single one of our children gets a real...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I look out and I see tens of millions of Americans who are struggling to pay their medical bills, 37 million people who decided not to have a prescription filled because they just can't afford it, people who didn't take the tests the doctor recommended because they just can't afford it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So here is my plan.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Let's bring as many people in and get as much help to the American people as we can as fast as we can.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: On day one as president, I will do -- bring down the cost of prescription drugs on things like insulin and EpiPens.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's going to save tens of millions, hundreds of millions of dollars for people.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm going to defend the Affordable Care Act from the sabotage of the Trump administration.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And in the first 100 days, I want to bring in 135 million people into Medicare for all at no cost to them.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Everybody under the age of 18, everybody who has a family of four income less than $50,000.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to lower the age of Medicare to 50 and expand Medicare coverage to include vision and dental and long-term care.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And then in the third year, when people have had a chance to feel it and taste it and live with it, we're going to vote and we're going to want Medicare for all.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Think of it this way.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Our housing problem in America is a problem on the supply side, and that means that the federal government stopped building new housing a long time ago, affordable housing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Also, private developers, they've gone up to McMansions.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: They're not building the little two bedroom, one bath house that I grew up in, garage converted to be a bedroom for my three brothers.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I've got a plan for 3.2 million new housing units in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Those are housing units for working families, for the working poor, for the poor poor, for seniors who want to age in place, for people with disabilities, for people who are coming back from being incarcerated.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's about tenants' rights.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But there's one more piece.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Housing is how we build wealth in America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The federal government has subsidized the purchase of housing for decades for white people and has said for black people you're cut out of the deal.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That was known as red-lining.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When I built a housing plan, it's not only a housing plan about building new units.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's a housing plan about addressing what is wrong about government-sponsored discrimination, how we need to address it, and we need to say we're going to reverse it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was also named in that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's a sorry, not sorry.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Yes, I think it should be.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, all three of my brothers served in the military.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: One was career military.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The other two also served.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I think it's an important part of who we are as Americans.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I think the notion of shared service is important.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's how we help bring our nation together.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's how people learn to work together from different regions, people who grew up differently.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's also about how families share that sacrifice.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I remember what it was like when I was a little girl.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: My brother, my oldest brother, who served five-and-a-half years off and on in combat in Vietnam, what it was like for my mother every day to check the mailbox, had we heard from Don Reed?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: How is he doing?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And if there was a letter, she was brighter than the day.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And if there wasn't, she would say, well, maybe tomorrow.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: This is about building for our entire nation.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I believe we should do that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I also believe we should have other service opportunities in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, for example, what I want to do is for our federal lands, I want to bring in 10,000 people who want to be able to serve in our federal lands to be able to help rebuild our national forests and national parks as a way to express both their public service and their commitment to fighting back against climate change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can do this as a nation.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Could I respond on this?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So I think it is really important that we actually talk about what we're willing to get in the fight for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I just want to give one example around this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Senator Harris rightly raised the question of economic justice.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Let me give a specific example, and that is student loan debt.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Right now in America, African-Americans are more likely to borrow money to go to college, borrow more money while they're in college, and have a harder time paying that debt off after they get out.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Today in America, a new study came out, 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94 percent of them have paid off their student loan debt, 5 percent of African-Americans have paid it off.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I believe that means everyone on this stage should be embracing student loan debt forgiveness.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It will help close the black-white wealth gap.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Let's do something tangible and real to make change in this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: If there are parts of the wall that are not useful in our defense, of course we should do it.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The real point here is that we need to stop this manmade crisis at the border.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Trump is the one who has created this crisis, and he has done it in no small part by helping destabilize the governments even further in Central America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: He has withdrawn aid.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That means that families have to flee for their lives, have to flee for any economic opportunity.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, when I found out that our government was actually taking away children from their families, I went down to the border.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I went down there immediately.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I was in McAllen, Texas, and I just hope everyone remembers what this looks like.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: There's like a giant Amazon warehouse filled with cages of women, cages of men, and cages of little girls and little boys.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I spoke to a woman who was in the cage of nursing mothers, and she told me she'd given a drink to a police officer and that the word had come down from the gangs that she was helping the police.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: She knew what that meant.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: She wrapped up her baby and she ran for the border.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to treat the people who come here with dignity and with respect.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: A great nation does not separate children from their families.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We need to live our values at the border every single day.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So would we all.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Look, I believe that abortion rights are human rights.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I believe that they are also economic rights.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And protecting the right of a woman to be able to make decisions about her own body is fundamentally what we do and what we stand for as a Democratic Party.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Understand this.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When someone makes abortion illegal in America, rich women will still get abortions.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's just going to fall hard on poor women.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It's going to fall hard on girls, women who don't even know that they're pregnant because they have been molested by an uncle.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I want to be an America where everybody has a chance.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And I know it can be a hard decision for people.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But here's the thing.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: When it comes down to that decision, a woman should be able to call on her mother, she should be able to call on her partner, she should be able to call on her priest or her rabbi.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But the one entity that should not be in the middle of that decision is the government.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have made clear what I think the Democratic Party stands for.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm not here to try to drive anyone out of this party.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm not here to try to build fences.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But I am here to say, this is what I will fight for as president of the United States.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The women of America can count on that.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, thank you.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, I've listened to this debate tonight and I hear a lot of really good ideas.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But I take a look at the issues we've talked about.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We've talked about climate change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We've talked about defense spending.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We've talked about private health insurance.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We should have talked about gun violence.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What do these issues have in common?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Well, first, they touch people all over this country in their everyday lives.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And what is the second thing they have in common?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We know what we need to do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a lot of good ideas for how to fix it, and the majority of Americans are with us on it, and yet we don't make change.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Why not?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Because of corruption.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Because we have a government that works better for big drug companies than it does for people trying to fill a prescription.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It works better for a giant defense industry than it does for everyone who worries about the money that goes into arms instead of into our public schools.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a government that works for those at the top and not for anyone else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I have the biggest anti-corruption plan since Watergate.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: It involves ending lobbying as we know it, blocking the revolving door between industry and Washington, making everyone who runs for federal office put their tax returns online.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to have the courage not to make just individual changes, not to fight for little pieces.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We want to make real progress on climate.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Then we have to start by attacking the corruption that gives the oil industry and other fossil fuel industries a stranglehold over this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I am so grateful to be here and I am grateful to an America that gave the daughter of a janitor a chance to become a public school teacher, a chance to become a college professor, a chance to become a United States senator...

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: ... and a chance to become candidate for president of the United States.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: So, I see this as a constitutional moment.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Last night, the president was impeached, and everyone now in the Senate who has taken a constitutional oath to uphold our Constitution -- and that doesn't mean loyalty to an individual, it doesn't mean loyalty to a political party, it means loyalty to our country -- and that vote will play out over the next several weeks.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: But the way I see this is we've now seen the impact of corruption, and that's what's clearly on the stage in 2020, is how we are going to run against the most corrupt president in living history.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: You know, this president has made corruption originally his argument that he would drain the swamp, and, yet, he came to Washington, broke that promise, and has done everything he can for the wealthy and the well-connected, from tax breaks to ambassadorships.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have to prosecute the case against him, and that means we need a candidate for president who can draw the sharpest distinction between the corruption of the Trump administration and a Democrat who is willing to get out and fight not for the wealthy and well-connected but to fight for everyone else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: That's why I'm in this race.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I do.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Well, I want to answer this question.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Because here's the problem.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm proud to stand on a stage with Democrats who understand that a rise in GDP, rise in corporate profits is not being felt by millions of families across this country.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: I'm proud to stand on a stage with people who see that America's middle class is being hollowed out and that working families and poor people are being left behind.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: What we need to talk about, though, is why that has happened.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And the answer is we've got a government that works great for those with money and doesn't work for much of anyone else.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We have a government that works great for giant drug companies, just not for someone trying to fill a prescription.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Works great for people who want to make money on private prisons and private detention centers at our border, just not for the people whose lives are torn apart.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Works great for giant oil companies that want to drill everywhere, but not for the rest of us who see climate change bearing down upon us.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And when you see a government that works great for the wealthy and the well-connected and for no one else, that is corruption, pure and simple.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: And we need to call it out for what it is.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Oh, they're just wrong.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: Let's start with a wealth tax.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: The idea of a two-cent tax on the great fortunes in this country, $50 million and above.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: For two cents, what can we do?

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can invest in the rest of America.

speaker: Elizabeth Warren
sentence: We can provide universal childcare, early childhood education for every baby in this country, age 0 to 5, universal pre-K for every 3-year-old and 4-year-old, and raise the wages of every childcare worker and preschool teacher.
