sentence: We created the American dream for millions of people like myself, the grandson of immigrants, the son of a union electrician who went on to become a successful business leader and create thousands of jobs.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But we did these things with real solutions, not with impossible promises.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And those are the roots that we have to get back to.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm running for president to solve these problems, to build infrastructure, to fix our broken health care system, to invest in communities that have been left behind, to improve public education.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I just don't want to be your president to be your president.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I want to be your president to do the job.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This is not about me.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This is about getting America working again.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Folks, we have a choice.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can go down the road that Senator Sanders and Senator Warren want to take us, which is with bad policies like Medicare for all, free everything and impossible promises that will turn off independent voters and get Trump re-elected.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's what happened with McGovern.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's what happened with Mondale.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's what happened with Dukakis.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Or we can nominate someone with new ideas to create universal health care for every American with choice, someone who wants to unify our country and grow the economy and create jobs everywhere.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And then we win the White House.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm the product of the American dream.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I believe in it.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm the grandson of immigrants, the son of a construction worker.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: My wife April and I have four amazing daughters.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I was the youngest CEO in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, created thousands of jobs and then served in Congress.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's the type of background -- and my platform is about real solutions, not impossible promises, that can beat Trump and govern.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Well, I'm right about this.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can create a universal health care system to give everyone basic health care for free, and I have a proposal to do it.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But we don't have to go around and be the party of subtraction, and telling half the country, who has private health insurance, that their health insurance is illegal.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: My dad, the union electrician, loved the health care he got from the IBEW.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: He would never want someone to take that away.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Half of Medicare beneficiaries now have Medicare Advantage, which is private insurance, or supplemental plans.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's also bad policy.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It'll underfund the industry, many hospitals will close...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... and it's bad policy.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But now he's talking about a different issue.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: What I'm talking about is really simple.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We should deal with the tragedy of the uninsured and give everyone health care as a right.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But why do we got to be the party of taking something away from people?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's what they're running on.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: They're running on...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... telling half the country that your health insurance is illegal.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It says it right in the bill.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We don't have to do that.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can give everyone health care...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... and allow people to have choice.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's the American way.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So I was -- I'm the only one on this stage who actually has experience in the health care business.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And with all due respect, I don't think my colleagues understand the business.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We have the public option, which is great.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: The public option is great, but it doesn't go far enough.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It doesn't go far enough.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm proposing universal health care, where everyone gets health care as a basic human right for free, but they have choices.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: My plan, BetterCare, is fully paid for without raising middle class tax options.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So when we think about this debate...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: There's Medicare for All, which is extreme...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I was interrupted.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So the bill that Senator Sanders drafted, by definition will lower quality in healthcare, because it says specifically that the rates will be the same as current Medicare rates.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And the data is clear, Medicare does not cover the cost of healthcare, it covers 80 percent of the costs of healthcare in this country.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And private insurance covers 120 percent, so if you start underpaying all the healthcare providers, you're going to create a two tier market where wealthy people buy their healthcare with cash, and the people who are forced -- like my dad, the union electrician --

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Will have that healthcare plan taken away from him --

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: They will be forced into an underfunded system.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I've done the math, it doesn't add up.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Listen, his math is wrong.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's all I'm saying -- that his math is wrong, it's been well-documented that if all the bills were paid at Medicare rate, which is specifically -- I think it's in section 1,200 of their bill, then many hospitals in this country would close.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I've been going around rural America, and I ask rural hospital administrators one question, "If all your bills were paid at the Medicare rate last year, what would happen?"

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And they all look at me and say, "We would close."

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But the question is, why do we have to be so extreme?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Why can't we just give everyone health care as a right, and allow them to have choice?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm starting to think this is not about health care...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This is an anti-private-sector...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... strategy.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So -- so I think Democrats win when we run on real solutions, not impossible promises, when we run on things that are workable, not fairy tale economics.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Look at the story of Detroit, this amazing city that we're in.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This city is turning around because the government and the private sector are working well together.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That has to be our model going forward.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We need to encourage collaboration between the government, the private sector, and the nonprofit sector, and focus on those kitchen table, pocketbook issues that matter to hard-working Americans: building infrastructure, creating jobs, improving their pay...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... creating universal health care, and lowering drug prices.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can do it.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: When we created Social Security, we didn't say pensions were illegal, right?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can have big ideas to transform the lives.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I mean, I started two companies and took them public before I was 40.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm as big of a dreamer and an entrepreneur as anyone.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But I also believe we need to have solutions that are workable.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Can you imagine if we tried to start Social Security now but said private pensions are illegal?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's the equivalent of what Senator Sanders and Senator Warren are proposing with health care.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's not a big idea.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's an idea that's dead on arrival.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That will never happen.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So why don't we actually talk about things, big ideas that we can get done?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: The stakes are too high.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Well, first of all, because it ties its progress to other things that are completely unrelated to climate, like universal health care, guaranteed government jobs, and universal basic income.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So that only makes it harder to do.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: My plan, which gets us to net zero by 2050, which we absolutely have to do for our kids and our grandkids, will get us there.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I put a price on carbon, take all the money, give it back to the American people in a dividend.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That was introduced by me on a bipartisan basis.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's the only significant bipartisan climate bill in the Congress.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm going to increase the Department of Energy research budget by fivefold, because we fundamentally have to innovate our way out of this problem.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm going to create a market for something called direct air capture, which are machines that actually take carbon out of the atmosphere, because I don't think we'll get to net zero by 2050 unless we have those things.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm going to increase investment in renewables and I'm going to create something called the Climate Corps.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That is a plan that's realistic.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's a bet on the U.S. private innovation economy and creates the incentives to get us to net zero by 2050 for our kids.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So, listen.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This is what I don't understand.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: President Trump wants to build physical walls and beats up on immigrants.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Most of the folks running for president want to build economic walls to free trade and beat up on President Obama.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I'm the only one running for president who actually supports the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: President Obama was right about that.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We should be getting back in that.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Senator Warren just issued a trade plan...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... that would prevent the United States from trading with its allies.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can't go and -- we can't isolate ourselves from the world.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We have to engage...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... with fair, rules-based trade.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That was the TPP.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: So that was the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think President Obama was right.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: He did include environmental standards.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: He did include labor standards.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We would be in an entirely different position with China if we had entered the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can't isolate ourselves from the world.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can't isolate ourselves from Asia.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Senator Warren's plan, basically, that she put out, we would not be able to trade with the United Kingdom.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We would not be able to trade with the E.U.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It is so extreme that it will isolate...

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... the American economy from the world.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think wealthy Americans have to pay more.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Listen, I grew up in a blue-collar family.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: First in my family to go to college.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Became a successful entrepreneur.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Created thousands of jobs.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Supported thousands of entrepreneurs all around this country.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And I've done well financially.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think I should pay more in tax.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think wealthy Americans should pay more in tax.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But we have to have a real solution.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: The real solution is to raise the capital gains rates.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: There is no reason why people who invest for a living should pay less than people who work for a living.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's ridiculous.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's the biggest loophole in our tax code.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We act like wealthy individuals are endangered species and if we don't raise -- if we raise their taxes, they won't invest.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's crazy.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That's how we get more revenues from wealthy individuals, we roll back the Trump tax cuts to wealthy individuals.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think the wealth tax will be fought in court forever.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's arguably unconstitutional.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And the countries that have had it have largely abandoned it because it's impossible to implement.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But here again, real solutions, not impossible promises.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Raise the capital gains tax.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Roll back the taxes on wealthy Americans.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: That we can do in our first few months as president.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: This is not about whether wealthy -- this is not about whether wealthy Americans should pay more.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I think we're all in agreement on that.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: It's a question of, do you have a real solution to make it happen?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can raise the capital gains rate to match the ordinary income.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: You know the last president to do that was actually Ronald Reagan.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can do that in our first year.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I've called for that to be done (inaudible).

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I've called for the expansion of universal pre-K so that every American has pre-K.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And I do it through a -- through an additional tax on high net worth individuals.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: ... will be fought in court for years.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Thank you, Jake.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: John F.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Kennedy famously said we should not seek the Republican answer, we should not seek the Democratic answer, we should seek the right answer.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: He was right when he said it and he's right today, as well.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Donald Trump is the symptom of a disease.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And the disease is divisiveness.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And I'm the only one on the stage talking about curing that disease, which -- with big ideas like national service, by focusing on actually solving problems.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: If we work together, we can fix health care and build infrastructure.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can invest in not just technology, but people and entrepreneurs, whether they be in Storm Lake, Iowa, or Detroit, Michigan, or Baltimore, Maryland.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: We can fight climate change and reimagine our education system.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: But we have to do it with real solutions, not impossible promises.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Isn't it time we had a president who was a leader in both the private sector and in government, to lead us into the future?

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: I promise, as president, I will restore vision, unity, and leadership, and decency to this country.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: And that's why I'm running for president.

speaker: John Delaney
sentence: Thank you.

sentence: I believe that we need leadership that understands that we need to move forward as one nation, with one destiny.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Our destiny in the years to come is to be the smartest, the healthiest, the fairest and the most prosperous nation on Earth.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: If you want to help me build that America for the future, I hope you'll go to juliancastro.com.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And on January 20th, 2021, we'll say together, "Adios to Donald Trump."

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, you know, I also want to recognize the work that Bernie has done on this.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, of course, we owe a debt of gratitude to President Barack Obama.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Of course, I also worked for President Obama, Vice President Biden, and I know that the problem with your plan is that it leaves 10 million people uncovered.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Now, on the last debate stage in Detroit, you said that wasn't true, when Senator Harris brought that up.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: There was a fact check of that, and they said that was true.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, I grew up with a grandmother who had type 2 diabetes, and I watched her condition get worse and worse.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But that whole time, she had Medicare.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I want every single American family to have a strong Medicare plan available.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: If they choose to hold on to strong, solid private health insurance, I believe they should be able to do.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But the difference between what I support and what you support, Vice President Biden, is that you require them to opt in and I would not require them to opt in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They would automatically be enrolled.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They wouldn't have a buy in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: That's a big difference, because Barack Obama's vision was not to leave 10 million people uncovered.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He wanted every single person in this country covered.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: My plan would do that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Your plan would not.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You just said that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You just said that two minutes ago.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You just two minutes ago that they would have to buy in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You said they would have to buy in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Are you forgetting what you said two minutes ago?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Are you forgetting already what you said just two minutes ago?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I mean, I can't believe that you said two minutes ago that they had to buy in and now you're saying they don't have to buy in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You're forgetting that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I mean, look, look, we need a health care system...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: It automatically enrolls people regardless of whether they choose to opt in or not.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: If you lose your job, for instance, his health care plan would not automatically enroll you.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You would have to opt in.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: My health care plan would.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: That's a big difference.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm fulfilling the legacy of Barack Obama, and you're not.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Yeah, that's called the Democratic primary election, Pete.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: That's called an election.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: That's an election.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: This is what we're here for.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: It's an election.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Look, you know, I want to commend Beto for how well he has spoken to the passion and the frustration and the sadness after what happened in his hometown of El Paso.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He's done a great job with that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Look, a few weeks ago, a shooter drove 10 miles inspired by this - 10 hours inspired by this president to kill people who look like me and people who look like my family.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: White supremacy is a growing threat to this country, and we have to root it out.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm proud that I put forward a plan to disarm hate.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm also proud that I was the first to put forward a police reform plan, because we're not going to have any more Laquan McDonalds or Eric Garners or Michael Browns or Pamela Turners or Walter Scotts or Sandra Bland, here from the Houston area.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to root out racism, and I believe that we can do that, because that doesn't represent the vast majority of Americans who do have a good heart.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They also need a leader to match that, and I will be a president that matches that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I mean, look...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Jorge, thank you very much for that question.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, look, I agree that Barack Obama was very different from Donald Trump.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Donald Trump has a dark heart when it comes to immigrants.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He built his whole political career so far on scapegoating and fearmongering and otherizing migrants, and that's very different from Barack Obama.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But my problem with Vice President Biden - and Cory pointed this out last time - is every time something good about Barack Obama comes up, he says, oh, I was there, I was there, I was there, that's me, too, and then every time somebody questions part of the administration that we were both part of, he says, well, that was the president.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I mean, he wants to take credit for Obama's work, but not have to answer to any questions.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I mean...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Let me just say...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Let me just say...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Jorge, let me just say that I would - I was the first candidate in early April to put forward an immigration plan.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know why?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Because I'm not afraid of Donald Trump on this issue.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm not going to back pedal.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm not going to pretend like I don't have my own vision for immigration.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: So we're not going to give up DACA.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We're not going to give up protections for anybody.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I believe that on January 20, 2021, we're going to have a Democratic president, we're going to throw out Mitch McConnell and John Cornyn and have a Democratic Senate, and a Democratic House, and we're going to pass immigration reform within the first 100 days.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, look, I agree with those who have said that this erratic, haphazard trade war is hurting American families.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: As Senator Klobuchar said, 300,000 American jobs.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: It's estimated that it's cost $600 to the average American family.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Just a couple of days ago, 60 percent of Americans said that they believe that we're in for a recession next year.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: So when I become president, I would immediately begin to negotiate with China to ratchet down that trade war.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We have leverage there.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I also believe, though, that we need to return to a leader when it comes to things like human rights.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We have millions of Uighurs, for instance, in China that right now are being imprisoned and mistreated.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And in North Korea, this president is elevating a dictator.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to stop that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to return to ensuring that America leads again on human rights.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: When it comes to this trade war, I would immediately begin ratcheting that trade war down.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We have leverage in that discussion.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Sure, thank you, Jorge.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'll call Maduro a dictator, because he is a dictator.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And what we need to do is to, along with our allies, make sure that the Venezuelan people get the assistance that they need, that we continue to pressure Venezuela so that they'll have free and fair elections, and also, here in the United States, offer temporary protected status, TPS, to Venezuelans.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: That is something that the Trump administration has failed to do.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: For all of his big talk about supporting the Venezuelan-American community, he has failed.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I will not.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I also believe that we need to do things like a 21st century Marshall plan for Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: ... so that people can find safety and opportunity at home instead of having to make the dangerous journey to the United States.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And under my administration, we're going to put renewed focus on Latin America.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: It makes sense.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They're our neighbors and we have a lot of things in common.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: It also makes sense that, because we have a country like China that is going around the world to places like Africa and Latin America, making their own relationships, strengthening those, the United States needs to strengthen its partnerships in Latin America immediately.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And I will

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, that's - that's quite a lot.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But, you know - I grew up in one of those neighborhoods that folks have talked about and a neighborhood that was grappling with the legacy of segregation.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: In fact, in two public school districts that were involved in a 1973 Supreme Court case challenging how Texas financed its schools.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And I know that today our schools are segregated because our neighborhoods are segregated.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Now, I have an education plan, like a lot of folks up here, that would pay teachers more, that would recruit diverse ranks of teachers, that would invest in our public schools, but I also believe that we have to connect the dots to uplift the quality of life to invest in housing opportunity, to invest in job opportunity, to invest in community schools that offer resources like parents able to go back and get their GED, and health care opportunities, and those things that truly ensure that the entire family can prosper.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Those are the types of things that we need to do, in addition to lifting up our public schools.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You asked a second ago about charter schools.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Look, it is a myth that charter schools are better than public schools.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They're not.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And so while I'm not categorically against charter schools, I would require more transparency and accountability from them than is required right now.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And thank you, George, to Jorge, to Linsey, and to David, and to all of y'all for tuning in tonight.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: In many ways, I shouldn't be here on this stage.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, Castro is my mother's name and was my grandmother's name before her.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I grew up in a single-parent household on the west side of San Antonio, going to the public schools.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Eventually, my brother, Joaquin, and I became the first in our family to become professionals.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And when I got home, I took a job at the biggest law firm in town.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I was making $100,000 a year in the year 2000.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: A few months later, I got elected to the San Antonio City Council.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And the city council at the time was only paying $1,040 a year, so everybody had another job.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And my job was at the law firm.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, a few months after I got elected, the law firm got a client and the client wanted those of us on the city council to vote for a land deal.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: The land deal was that they wanted to build a golf course over our water supply, because we relied on an underground aquifer.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I didn't think the environmental protection plan was strong enough, so I wanted to vote against it and my constituents wanted me to vote against it.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But under the ethics rules for lawyers in Texas - because believe it or not, lawyers have ethics rules - you can't just go against the interest of a client.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: So I was stuck.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: On the one hand, I wanted to do the right thing.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: On the other hand, my livelihood, my student loans, my new house payment, my car payment, depended on me shutting up, being conflicted out.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: So, one day, I walked into my law firm and I quit my job.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And then I went and I voted against that land deal on the city council.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, you know, it was the first test that I had, and I think back to that, because oftentimes we think of politics and you think of politics as dirty or corrupting.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I wondered, before I went in it, whether it was change who I was.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And I was proud that when that first test came that I stood up for the people that I was there to represent, and not for big special interests.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: There's nobody that gets tested more in a position of public trust than the president of the United States.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: This president has failed that test.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But I want you to know that if you elect me president, I won't.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I won't serve anybody except you and your family.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And together, we can create an American that's better than ever.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Not at all.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We can walk and chew gun at the same time.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And all of us are out there every single day talking about what we're going to do to make sure that more people cross a graduation stage, that more families have great health care, that more folks are put to work in places like Ohio, where Donald Trump has broken his promises, because Ohio, Michigan, and Pennsylvania actually in the latest jobs data have lost jobs, not gained them.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Not only that, what we have to recognize is that not only did the Mueller Report point out 10 different instances where the president obstructed justice or tried to, and he made that call to President Zelensky of the Ukraine, but he is in ongoingly - in an ongoing way violating his oath of office and abusing his power.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We have to impeach this president.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And the majority of Americans not only support impeachment, they support removal.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He should be removed.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, I think -- I think what folks have said is that that is only part of the issue, right?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, I believe that we need to address communities that are being impacted by automation.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I'm even willing to pilot something like UBI and to see how that would work.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But I think we need to focus on making sure that we spark job opportunity for people across this country.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, here in Ohio, in the latest job data, Ohio is losing jobs under Donald Trump.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He has broken his promises to Ohio and the industrial Midwest.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I would invest in infrastructure to put people back to work.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I would invest in a Green New Deal to unleash millions of new jobs in a clean energy economy.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I was in Newton, Iowa, a few weeks ago and I visited a place called TPI.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Newton, Iowa, had a Maytag washing machine manufacturing facility, and then it closed down.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: TPI manufactures wind turbines.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They're putting hundreds of people to work at decent-paying jobs and creating a better future for those families.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: On top of that, let me just say this.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to support working families.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to invest in things like...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: ... universal childcare, so that people can afford childcare instead of having to pay 20 percent of their income for it.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Thanks a lot, Erin.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And you see that everybody has their own plans.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And let me just say that the way that I view this is born out of my own experience.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I grew up like I bet a lot folks in this room grew up and folks that are watching on TV.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I grew up with my twin brother, Joaquin, in a single-parent household where my mom was working hard to support us and also her mom, my grandmother.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And we knew what it was like to wonder whether we were going to be able to pay the rent at the first of the month or sometimes have the electricity turned off.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And when I was a kid, to look at the grocery list that seemed to get shorter and shorter, and that's what's happening to a lot of families these days.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I was in Las Vegas a few months ago, and I visited people who were homeless, who are living in storm drainage tunnels under the Las Vegas strip in the shadow of hotels and casinos that are worth hundreds of millions of dollars, where people from around the world are spending so much money on vacations.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We can do better than that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I believe that wealth and equality tax, as I've proposed, is part of the answer, but also I've proposed an inheritance tax, raising the top marginal tax rate...

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: ... and investing in things like universal childcare and affordable housing.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, I mean, you asked the question of, how are we going to get people to trust us again?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: The first thing is we got to boot Donald Trump out of the Oval Office so that people will trust us again.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, I also want people to think -- the folks this week that saw those images of ISIS prisoners running free to think about how absurd it is that this president is caging kids on the border and effectively letting ISIS prisoners run free.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He has made a tremendous mistake, a total disaster there in Syria.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And just to connect the dots for a second, if you're Kim Jong-un, for instance, why in the world would you believe anything that this president says to contain your nuclear weapons program, when he tore up an Iran nuclear agreement that we just signed four years ago, which was the strongest agreement to contain Iran's nuclear weapons program, and now he's abandoned the very people that we gave our word to?

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I would make sure that we work with our allies to pressure Syria to stop the aggression, and I support efforts at stronger sanctions than this president has announced.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Thank you very much for the question.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, I grew up in neighborhoods where it wasn't uncommon to hear gunshots at night.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And I can remember ducking into the back seat of a car when I was a freshman in high school, across the street from my school, my public school, because folks were shooting at each other.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, in the neighborhoods -- let me answer this question about voluntary versus mandatory.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: There are two problems I have with mandatory buybacks.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Number one, folks can't define it.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And if you're not going door to door, then it's not really mandatory.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: But also, in the places that I grew up in, we weren't exactly looking for another reason for cops to come banging on the door.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And you all saw a couple days ago what happened to Atatiana Jefferson in Fort Worth.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: A cop showed up at 2:00 in the morning at her house when she was playing video games with her nephew.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: He didn't even announced himself.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And within four seconds, he shot her and killed her through her home window.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: She was in her own home.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And so I am not going to give these police officers another reason to go door to door in certain communities, because police violence is also gun violence, and we need to address that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Yes, I am.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: They need to be held accountable, not only financially, but also with criminal penalties.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, you know, you can draw a straight line between making sure that we hold executives accountable, whether it's these drug manufacturers or Wall Street executives that should have been held accountable a decade-and-a-half ago.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Yeah, I think that we're on the right track in terms of updating how we look at monopolistic practices and setting, as Congressman O'Rourke said, rules for the road that match the challenges that we face today.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And, you know, whether that's Amazon that is leveraging its size I think to help put small businesses out of business, and then at the same time shortchanging a lot of its workers, not paying them as they should, not giving them the benefits that they should, or it's a number of other companies, big tech companies.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We need to take a stronger stance when it comes to cracking down on monopolistic trade practices, and that's what I would do as president.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I don't think it is.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I wouldn't pack the court.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, I think the plan that Mayor Pete mentioned is an interesting one, but I actually believe, if we were selecting from one of those things, that the smarter move might be to look at term limits or having people cycle off from the appellate courts so that you would have a replenishment of perspective.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I would also make sure that I appoint as president people who respect the precedent of Roe v.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Wade, that we codify Roe v.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Wade, and that we do away with things like the Hyde amendment, because you shouldn't only be able to have reproductive freedom if you have money.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: We have to think about people who do not, people who are poor.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And we have to concern ourselves not only with reproductive freedom, but also reproductive justice and invest in the ability of every woman to be able to make a choice and to be able to have her health care needs met.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Well, first of all, thank you to Marc, thank you, Anderson, and thank you, Erin, and CNN, and New York Times and everybody who is here tonight.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: You know, some of the most interesting friendships that I've had have been with people different from me, either people older than me that had a lot to teach me, or people who grew up very different from me.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Also, teachers, as I was growing up, people that had a life experience that when I was growing up was beyond mine.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And sometimes also -- and this goes to the heart of your question, I think -- people who thought differently from me, folks that I considered and have considered friends, and I think that there's a value to that.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I think that that should be reflected more in our public life.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I also believe, to just speak about the incident last week with Ellen and George W.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Bush, I completely understood what she was saying about being kind to others.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I believe that we should be more kind to other folks.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I also believe that we should hold people to account for what they've done, especially public servants who have a record of having done something or not done something.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And I think that we can do both of those things.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: I think that we can be kind to people and also hold them accountable for their actions.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: And there are people, whether it's our former president, George W.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Bush, or others that should be held accountable.

speaker: Julian Castro
sentence: Just as we should be kind, we shouldn't be made to feel shameful about holding people accountable for what they've done.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Well, let me tell you something.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I hear that question, but where was that question when the Republicans and Donald Trump passed a tax bill that benefits the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations in this country?

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Contributing at least $1 trillion to the debt of America, which middle-class families will pay for one way or another.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Working families need support and need to be lifted up.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And frankly, this economy is not working for working people.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: For too long, the rules have been written in the favor of the people who have the most and not in favor of the people who work the most, which I why I am proposing that we change the tax code, so for every family that is making less than $100,000 a year, they will receive a tax credit that they can collect up to $500 a month, which will make all the difference between those families being able to get through the end of the month with dignity and with support or not.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And on day one, I will repeal that tax bill that benefits the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations of America.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Hey, guys, you know what?

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: America does not want to witness a food fight, they want to know how we are going to put food on their table.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: So on that point, part of the issue that is at play in America today, and we have all been traveling around the country, I certainly have, I'm meeting people who are working two and three jobs.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: You know, this president walks around talking about and flouting his great economy, right, my great economy, my great economy.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: You ask him, well, how are you measuring this greatness of this economy of yours?

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And he talks about the stock market.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Well, that's fine if you own stocks.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: So many families in America do not.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: You ask him, how are you measuring the greatness of this economy of yours?

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And they point to the jobless numbers and the unemployment numbers.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Well, yeah, people in America are working.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: They're working two and three jobs.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: So when we talk about jobs, let's be really clear.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: In our America, no one should have to work more than one job to have a roof over their head and food on the table.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I'd like to add a point here.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I'd like to add a point here.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: . . . on this issue we have to think about how this affects real people.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And the reality of how this affects real people is captured in a story that many of us heard and I will paraphrase.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: There is, any night in America, a parent who has seen that their child has a temperature that is out of control, calls 911, what should I do?

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And they say, take the child to the Emergency Room.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And so they get in their car and they drive and they are sitting in the parking lot outside of the Emergency Room looking at those sliding glass doors while they have the hand on the forehead of their child, knowing that if they walk through those sliding glass doors, even though they have insurance, they will be out a 5,000 deductible, $5,000 deductible when they walk through those doors.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: That's what insurance companies are doing in America today.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: Immediately on January 20th of 2021, I will, first of all - we cannot forget our DACA recipients, and so I'm going to start there.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I will immediately, by executive action, reinstate DACA status and DACA protection to those young people.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I will further extend protection for deferral of deportation for their parents and for veterans, who we have so many who are undocumented and have served our country and fought for our democracy.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I will also immediately put in place a meaningful process for reviewing the cases for asylum.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I will release children from cages.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: I will get rid . ..

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: . . . of the private detention centers.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And I will ensure that this microphone that the president of the United States holds in her hand is used in a way . ..

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: . . . that is about reflecting the values of our country and not about locking children up, separating them from their parents.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: And I have to just say that we have to think about this issue in terms of real people.

speaker: Kamala Harris
sentence: A mother who pays a coyote to transport her child through their country of origin, through the entire country of Mexico, facing unknown peril, to come here - why would that mother do that?

speaker: Kamala Harris

sentence: And I just need to understand as a woman who's worked my entire career as the primary wage earner, as the primary caregiver, in fact, the second -- my second son, Henry, is here, and I had him when I was a member of Congress.

sentence: It was the title of the op-ed and that just causes concern for me because we know America's women are working. 4 out of 10 moms have to work.

sentence: And what President - and what President Trump has done is not only attack these children, not only demonize these immigrants, he is attacking a basic principle of America's moral core.

sentence: And the underlying cause has to do with deep, deep, deep realms of racial injustice, both in our criminal justice system and in our economic system.

sentence: . . . we are going to turn from a dirty economy to a clean economy, we're going to have a Green New Deal, we're going to create millions of jobs, we're going to do this within the next 12 years, because I'm not interested in just winning the next election.

speaker: Marianne Williamson

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: In 1776 our founders brought forth on this planet an extraordinary new possibility.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: It was the idea that people, no matter who they were, would simply have the possibility of thriving.

sentence: We have not ever totally actualized this ideal.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: But at the times when we have done best, we have tried.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And when forces have opposed them, generations of Americans have risen up and pushed back against those forces.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We did that with abolition and with women's suffrage and with civil rights.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And now it is time for a generation of Americans to rise up again, for an amoral economic system has turned short-term profits for huge multi-national corporations into a false god.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And this new false god takes precedence over the safety and the health and the well-being of we the American people and the people of the world and the planet on which we live.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Conventional politics will not solve this problem because conventional politics is part of the problem.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We the American people must rise up and do what we do best and create a new possibility, say no to what we don't want and yes to what we know can be true.

sentence: I'm Marianne Williamson, and that's why I'm running for president.

sentence: The Republicans will so shut us down on everything else.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Everything that we're talking about here tonight is what's wrong with American politics, and the Democratic Party needs to understand that we should be the party that talks, not just about symptoms, but also about causes.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: When it - when we're talking about healthcare, we need to talk about more than just the healthcare plan.

sentence: We need to realize, we have a sickness care rather than a healthcare system.

sentence: We need to be the party talking about why so many of our chemical policies and our food policies and our agricultural policies and our environment policies and even our economic policies are leading to people sick to begin with.

speaker: Marianne Williamson

speaker: Marianne Williamson

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: The issue of gun safety, of course, is that the NRA has us in a chokehold, but so do the pharmaceutical companies, so do the health insurance companies, so do the fossil fuel companies, and so do the defense contractors, and none of this will change until we either pass a constitutional amendment or pass legislation that establishes public funding for federal campaigns.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: But for politicians, including my fellow candidates, who themselves have taken tens of thousands -- and in some cases, hundreds of thousands -- of dollars from these same corporate donors to think that they now have the moral authority to say we're going to take them on, I don't think the Democratic Party should be surprised that so many Americans believe yada, yada, yada.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: It is time for us to start over with people who have not taken donations from any of those corporations and can say with real moral authority: That is over.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We are going to establish public funding for federal campaigns.

sentence: That's what we need to stand up to.

sentence: And until we do it, it's just the same old, same old.

sentence: My response on the Flint water crisis is that Flint is just the tip of the iceberg.

sentence: I was recently in Denmark, South Carolina where it is -- there is a lot of talk about it being the next Flint.

sentence: We have an administration that has gutted the Clean Water Act.

sentence: We have communities, particularly communities of color and disadvantaged communities all over this country who are suffering from environmental injustice.

sentence: I assure you, I lived Grosse Pointe -- what happened in Flint would not have happened in Grosse Pointe.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: This is part of the dark underbelly of American society.

sentence: The racism, the bigotry, and the entire conversation that we're having here tonight -- if you think any of this wonkiness is going to deal with this dark psychic force of the collectivized hatred that this president is bringing up in this country, then I'm afraid that the Democrats are going to see some very dark days.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We need to say it like it is, it's bigger than Flint -- it's all over this country, it's particularly people of color -- it's particularly people who do not have the money to fight back.

sentence: And if the Democrats don't start saying it, then why would those people feel that they're there for us and if those people don't feel it, they won't vote for us, and Donald Trump will win.

sentence: Thank you.

sentence: We need to recognize that when it comes to the economic gap between blacks and whites in America, it does come from a great injustice that has never been dealt with.
