sentence: What makes me qualified to say $200 billion to $500 billion?

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: I'll tell you what makes me qualified.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: If you did the math of the 40 acres and a mule, given that there was 4 million to 5 million slaves at the end of the Civil War, four to five -- and they were all promised 40 acres and a mule for every family of four, if you did the math today, it would be trillions of dollars.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And I believe that anything less than $100 billion is an insult.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And I believe that $200 billion to $500 billion is politically feasible today, because so many Americans realize there is an injustice that continues to form a toxicity underneath the surface, an emotional turbulence that only reparations will heal.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: I'd like to respond.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: I think that all domestic and international policy should be based on the idea that anything we do to help people thrive is a stimulation to our economy.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: That's how you stimulate your economy.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: So if a few people take advantage, but there are four or five people who were going to take the money that they then have in the bank -- when you look at this $1.5 trillion college debt -- this is why I agree with Bernie, or I would be -- OK, why don't we swap it?

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We had a $2 trillion tax cut, where 83 cents of every dollar goes to the very, very richest among us, that does not stimulate the economy.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: If we get rid of this college debt, think of all the young people who will have the discretionary spending; they'll be able to start their business.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: The best thing you could do to stimulate the U.S. economy is to get rid of this debt.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: This is not just about a plan to to do it.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: It's about a philosophy of governing.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And I've heard some people here tonight, I almost wonder why you're Democrats.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: You seem to think there's something wrong about using...

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: ... about using the instruments of government to help people.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: That is what government should do.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: It should -- all policies should help people thrive.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: That is how we will have peace...

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: ... and that is how we will have prosperity.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Yes, our problem is not just that we need to defeat Donald Trump.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We need a plan to solve institutionalized hatred, collectivized hatred, and white nationalism.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And in order to do that, we need more than political insider game and wonkiness and intellectual argument.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Those things will not defeat Donald Trump.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We need some radical truth-telling, not just to talk about health care, but talk about why are we so sick all the time.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We need to have a serious conversation about race and what is truly owed.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: Even on the subject of foreign policy, it's all about symptoms and not about cause.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: We need to talk about the fact that the United States has sacrificed our moral leadership.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: The fact that countries see us, not only domestically but internationally, with policies that simply support our corporate overlords.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: The fact that our national defense agenda is driven more by short-term profits for defense contractors than by genuine peace-building.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: There's some corruption that is so deep, ladies and gentlemen.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And until the Democratic Party is ready to speak to the deeper corruption, knowing that we ourselves sometimes because of our own corporate donations have participated, than I'm afraid those who vote for Trump will continue to vote for Trump and those who might not like Donald Trump will continue to stay home.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: I want a politics that goes much deeper.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: I want a politics that speaks to the heart, because the only way to fight -- you keep talking about how we're going to fight Donald Trump.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: You can't fight dog whistles.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: You have to override them.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: And the only way you can override them is with new voices, voices of energy that only come from the fact that America has been willing to live up to our own mistakes, atone for our mistakes, make amends for our own mistakes, love each other, love our democracy, love future generations, something emotional and psychological that will not be -- be emerging from anything on this stage.

speaker: Marianne Williamson
sentence: It will emerge from something I'm the one who's qualified to bring forth.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: No, I'd like to say something.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Was that directed to me?

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That sounded like me.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I appreciate it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Well, look, first of all, I agree completely with Bernie about what the fundamental challenge we're facing as a country is, 40 years of no economic growth for 90 percent of the American people; 160,000 families in the top .1 percent have the same wealth as the bottom 90 percent; and we've got the worst income inequality that we've had in 100 years.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Where I disagree is on his solution of Medicare-for-all.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: You know, I - I have proposed getting to universal health care, which we need to do.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It is a right.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Health care is a right.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to get to universal health care.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe the way to do that is by finishing the work we started with Obamacare and creating a public option that every family and every person in America can make a choice for their family about whether they want a public option, which for them would be like having Medicare-for-all, or whether they want to keep their private insurance.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe we will get there much more quickly if we do that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Bernie . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Bernie - if I could just finish, Bernie mentioned that - the taxes that we would have to pay.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Because of those taxes, Vermont rejected Medicare-for-all.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Good.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe that will get us the quickest way there.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I thought the vice president was very moving about this and Mayor Pete, as well.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I had prostate cancer recently, as you may know, and it's why I was a little late getting in the race.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The same week, my kid had her appendectomy.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I feel very strongly that families ought to be able to have this choice.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I think that's what the American people want.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe it will get us there quickly.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: There are millions of people in America that do not have health insurance today because they can't.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: They're too wealthy.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Wealthy?

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: They make too much money to be on Medicaid.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: They can't afford health insurance.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: When Senator Sanders says that Canada is single payer, there are 35 million people in Canada.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: There are 330 million people in the United States, easily the number of people on a public option that - it could easily be 35 million.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And for them, it would be Medicare-for-all, as Mayor Buttigieg says.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: But for others that want to keep it, they should be able to keep it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I think that will be the fastest way to get where we need to go.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Also, I will say - Bernie is a very honest person.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: He has said over and over again, unlike others that have supported this legislation, over and over again, that this will ban, make illegal all insurance except cosmetic, except insurance for - I guess that's for plastic surgery.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Everything else is banned under the Medicare-for-all proposal . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I agree.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Well, I think that, first of all, the biggest - the biggest threat to our national security right now is Russia, not China.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And, second, on China, we've got - because of what they've done with our election.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: In China, I think the president has been right to push back on China, but has done it in completely the wrong way.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We should mobilize the entire rest of the world, who all have a shared interest in pushing back on China's mercantilist trade policies, and I think we can do that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I'd like to answer the other question before this, as well.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: When I - when I - when I see these kids at the border, I see my mom, because I know she sees herself, because she was separated from her parents for years during the Holocaust in Poland.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And for Donald Trump to be doing what he's doing to children and their families at the border - I say this as somebody who wrote the immigration bill in 2013 that created a pathway to citizenship for 11 million people in this country - that had the most progressive Dream Act that's ever been conceived, much less passed, and got 68 votes in the Senate - that had $46 billion of border security in it that was sophisticated, 21st century border security, not a medieval wall . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: . . . and the president has turned the border of the United States into a symbol of nativist hostility . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: . . . that the whole world is looking at, when what we should be represented by is the Statue of Liberty, which has brought my parents to this country to begin with.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to make a change.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Gridlock will not magically disappear as long as Mitch McConnell is there, first.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Second, second, second, that's why it is so important for us to win not just the presidency, to have somebody that can run in all 50 states, but to win the Senate, as well.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And that's why we have to propose policies that can be supported, like Medicare act, so that we can build a broad coalition of Americans to overcome broken Washington, D.C.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I agree with what Senator Gillibrand was saying.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I share a lot of her views.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to end gerrymandering in Washington.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to end political gerrymandering in Washington.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The court today said they couldn't do anything about it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to overturn Citizens United.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The court was the one that gave us Citizens United.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And the attack on voting rights in Shelby v.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Holder is something we need to deal with.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: All of those things has happened since Vice President Biden was in the Senate.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And we face structural problems that we have to overcome with a broad coalition.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It's the only way we can do it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to root out the corruption in Washington, expand people's right to get to the polls, and I think then we can succeed.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Chuck, the problem with what the vice president . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The problem with what . ..

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Sometimes you do have to beat them, but - but the deal that he talked about with Mitch McConnell was a complete victory for the tea party.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It extended the Bush tax cuts permanently.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The Democratic Party had been running against that for 10 years.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We lost that economic argument, because that deal extended almost all those Bush tax cuts permanently and put in place the mindless cuts that we still are dealing with today that are called the sequester.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That was a great deal for Mitch McConnell.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It was a terrible deal for America.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Climate change and the lack of economic mobility Bernie talks about.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: What an excellent question.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: First of all, we have to restore our democracy at home.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The rest of the world is looking for us for leadership.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We have a president who doesn't believe in the rule of law, he doesn't believe in freedom of the press, he doesn't believe in an independent judiciary.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: He believes in the corruption that he's brought to Washington, D.C.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And that is what we have to change, and that's why everybody is up here tonight, and I appreciate the fact that they're up here for that reason.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Second, we've got to - we've got to restore the relationships that he's destroyed with our allies, not just in Europe.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: He flew to the G-20 last night and attacked Japan, Germany, and a third ally of ours without saying anything about North Korea or Russia.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And when you've got a situation where you have a president who says something happened in the Straits of Hormuz and the whole world doesn't know whether to believe it or not, that is a huge problem when it comes to the national security of the United States of America.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And we need to change that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Our European allies and every Latin American country that's willing to have a conversation about how to deal with the refugee crisis.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That's a good plan.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: My mom and her parents came to the United States to rebuild their shattered lives, in the only country that they could.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Three hundred years before that, my parents' family came searching religious freedom here.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The ability for one generation to do better than the next is now severely at risk in the United States, especially among children living in poverty like the ones I used to work for in the Denver public schools.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That's why I'm running for president.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I've had two tough races in Colorado, but by bringing people together, not by making empty promises.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I believe we need to build a broad coalition of Americans to beat Donald Trump, end the corruption in Washington, and build a new era of American democracy and American opportunity.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: This is going to be hard to do, but it's what our parents would have expected, it's what our kids deserve.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I hope you join me in this effort.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Last week, I saw one of those Trump signs that says, "America, love it or leave it."

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And it was on the outside of a church.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I love America.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I know we can make it better.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Before coming to the Senate I ran (inaudible) school district where most of the kids live in poverty.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Those kids have exactly the same hopes that I had.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Their parents have exactly the same hopes for them that my parents had for me, and that Susan and I have for our three children.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: But for the last three years, we've been consumed by a president who frankly doesn't give a damn about your kids or mine.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Mr.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: President; kids belong in classrooms, not cages.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And they deserve something better than a bully in the White House.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Let's end this three ringed circus in Washington and make - and let's make this election about reclaiming our future for our kids and our democracy.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Empty promises won't beat Donald Trump, I can.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I agree that it makes it much more likely.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Unlike others on this stage, I've been crystal clear of where I've been for a decade, through two tough races in Colorado.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe we should finish the job we started with the Affordable Care Act with a public option that gives everybody in this audience the chance to pick for their family, whether they want private insurance or public insurance.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It requires the drug companies to be negotiated with by Medicare and it provides competition.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That is totally different from the plan that Senator Warren and Senator Sanders and Senator Harris have proposed, which would make illegal employer based health insurance in this country and massively raise taxes on the middle class to the tune of $30 trillion.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: As Joe Biden said, we don't need to do that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It doesn't make sense for us to take away insurance from half the people in this room and -- and put huge taxes on almost everybody in this room when we pass a public option, trust the American people to make the right decision, and have universal healthcare in this country in two years, not 10 years.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Senator Harris is my friend as well, but I have to say if we can't admit -- if we can't admit tonight what's in the plan, which is banning employer based insurance, we're not going to be able to admit that when Donald Trump is accusing democrats of doing that as well.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to be honest about what's in this plan.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It bans employer based insurance and taxes the middle class to the tune of $30 trillion.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Do you know how much that is?

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That is 70 percent of what the government will collect in taxes over the next 10 years.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We don't need to do that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We can have a public option to have universal healthcare in this country.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: This -- this is -- this has nothing to do with Republican talking points or the pharmaceutical industry.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: This has to do with having faith in the American people that they can make the right decisions for their families and they can choose a public option.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Bernie Sanders, who said last night he wrote the damn bill, and he did, just like I wrote the damn public option bill, is the guy who says it will cost $32 trillion and that we're going to have to raise those taxes to pay for it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: He says that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Republicans don't say it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Don't try to district from the truth.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: You can't hide from the truth.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to be for universal health care.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I disagree that we should decriminalize our border.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: This is personal for me.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: My mom is an immigrant, and she was separated from her parents during the Holocaust in Poland.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And for those reasons, I was part of the Gang of Eight that wrote -- I wrote the immigration bill in 2013 with John McCain that passed the Senate with 68 votes, that gave a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million undocumented people that are here, that would pass the most progressive DREAM Act that had ever been conceived, much less passed on the floor of the Senate, and had $46 billion of border security.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Every single Democrat voted for that bill...

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: ... and a lot of Republicans.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That should be our position.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That is our position as Democrats.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I think this is one in the end that we agree with.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: There's not a single person on this stage if we were president would ever separate a child from their parents at the border.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And that is what this...

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That is what this administration has done in the American people's name.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: They have turned our border into a symbol of nativist hostility.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: The symbol of this country before Donald Trump was president was the Statue of Liberty.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That should be the symbol of the United States of America, not Donald Trump's words.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Yes.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: First of all, the president's racist rhetoric should be enough grounds for everybody in this country to vote him out of office.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That one thing alone should be enough.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Second, Don, I want to answer your question by tagging on the conversation we were just having.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: This is the fourth debate that we have had and the second time that we have been debating what people did 50 years ago with busing...

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: ... when our schools are as segregated today as they were 50 years ago.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need a conversation about what's happening now.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And when there's a group of kids in this country that don't get preschool through no fault of their own and another group does, equal is not equal.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And we've got a group of K-12 schools that are good because families can spend a million bucks, and you've got the Detroit public schools that are as segregated as they were.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Equal is not equal.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And let me tell you something else, Don.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe you can draw a straight line from slavery through Jim Crow through the banking and the redlining to the mass incarceration that we were talking about on this stage a few minutes ago.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: But you know what other line I can draw?

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Eighty-eight percent of the people in our prisons dropped out of high school.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Let's fix our school system and maybe we can fix the prison pipeline that we have.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Dana, this goes to the last question you asked, as well, which is, how are we going to remain competitive?

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It's not just about trade, which we were talking about earlier.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It's about whether we're going to invest in this country anymore.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Since 2001, we have cut $5 trillion worth of taxes.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Almost all of that has gone to the wealthiest people in America.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We have made the income inequality worse, not better, through the policies of the federal government.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We've spent $5.6 trillion in the Middle East.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That's $12 trillion or $13 trillion that from the point of view of driving the economy in Michigan, or anywhere else in America, we might as well just have lit that money on fire.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We've got to stop doing that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And we need to invest in America again.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: For the money that we've spent that I just described, we could have fixed every road and bridge in this country.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We could have fixed every airport that needs to be fixed.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We could have fixed not just Flint, but every water system in this country.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We could have made Social Security solvent for my children.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: But we did none of it because of self-serving politicians in Washington, D.C., who voted for deals that were good for them but not for Michigan or the American people.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I think, look, as we go forward here, we need to recognize a very practical reality, which is that we are four months -- we've got the August recess.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Then we are four months away from the Iowa Caucuses.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I just want to make sure whatever we do doesn't end up with an acquittal by Mitch McConnell in the Senate, which it surely would.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And then President Trump would be running saying that he had been acquitted by the United States Congress.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I believe we have a moral obligation to beat Donald Trump.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: He has to be a single-term president.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And we can't do anything that plays into our -- his hands.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We were talking earlier about -- about climate up here.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It's so important.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Donald Trump should be the last climate denier that's ever in the White House.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: But we need to be smart about how we're running or we're going to give him a second term.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We can't do it.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I -- I don't disagree with that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: You just said it better than I did.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We have to walk and chew gum at the same time.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It is incredibly unusual for members of Congress to be able to do that.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And I'm glad that Secretary Castro has the ambition...

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Ah, that's what I was going to say.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: It's your brother that's given you that good feeling about the Congress.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: That's what we should do.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: What I want to say to all of you tonight is, we have been here before as a country.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We have faced challenges that we've -- we actually even forget some of us tonight how hard the people fought, how hard they worked, how hard they organized, the votes they had to take, the people they had to get to the polls to make this country more democratic, more fair, and more free.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: And now we have a person in the White House who has no appreciation of that history, who doesn't believe in the rule of law, who doesn't believe in the independence of the judiciary, who doesn't believe that climate change is real.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: I think that we have an incredible opportunity in front of us, all of us, to come together just as our parents and grandparents did before them, and face challenges even harder than the ones that we face, but the only way we're going to be able to do it is to put the divisive politics of Donald Trump behind us and the divisive politics of the last 10 years behind us.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We need to come together united against a broken Washington, make Donald Trump a one-term president, and begin to govern this country again for our kids and our grandkids who cannot do it for themselves.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: We have to do it for them.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Please join me at michaelbennet.com.

speaker: Michael Bennet
sentence: Thanks for being here tonight.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I don't think there's any chance of the senator beating President Trump.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: You don't start out by saying I've got 160 million people I'm going to take away the insurance plan that they love.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: That's just not a way that you go and start building the coalition that the Sanders camp thinks that they can do.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I don't think there's any chance whatsoever.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And if he goes and is the candidate, we will have Donald Trump for another four years.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And we can't stand that.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I think we have two questions to face tonight.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: One is, who can beat Donald Trump?

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And, number two, who can do the job if they get into the White House?

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And I would argue that I am the candidate that can do exactly both of those things.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I'm a New Yorker.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I know how to take on an arrogant conman like Donald Trump, that comes from New York.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I'm a mayor or was a mayor.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I know how to run a complicated city, the biggest, most diverse city in this country.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I'm a manager.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: I knew what to do after 9/11 and brought the city back stronger than ever.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And I'm a philanthropist who didn't inherit his money but made his money.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg
sentence: And I'm spending that money to get rid of Donald Trump, the worst president we have ever had.

speaker: Mike Bloomberg

sentence: And I'm asking for your vote to be that president, when the dust clears over the rubble of our norms and institutions at the end of the Trump presidency, pick up the pieces and guide us toward a better future.

sentence: We are absolutely going to confront this president for his wrongdoing, but we're also each running to be the president who will lead this country after the Trump presidency comes to an end one way or the other.

speaker: Pete Buttigieg
sentence: And we are going to have to unify a nation that will be as divided as ever and, while doing it, address big issues that didn't take a vacation for the impeachment process or for the Trump presidency as a whole: a climate approaching the point of no return, the fact we've still got to act on health care, kids learning active shooter drills before they learn to read, and an economy where even when the Dow Jones is looking good, far too many Americans have to fight like hell just to hold on to what they've got.

speaker: Pete Buttigieg
sentence: Well, as President Obama commented recently, we are now in a different reality than we were even 12 years ago.

sentence: Well, first of all, I want to remark that we're in the city of Atlanta, a city where a great local leader, Maynard Jackson, helped create the black middle class that Atlanta is known by, by ensuring that taxpayer dollars were spent in a way that reflected the need to expand opportunity to those who were excluded.

sentence: And just as local leaders have shown great leadership, we need to use the powers of the presidency on challenges like this, expanding opportunity and expanding a sense of belonging to those who have been excluded in this country.

sentence: I am inviting progressives who have agreed on these issues we've been talking about tonight all along, moderates who are ready to be part of this coalition, and a lot of future former Republicans, who I know are watching this, disgusted by what is happening in their own party and in this country.

sentence: This economy is not working for most of us, for the middle class, and -- I know you're only ever supposed to say middle class and not poor in politics, but we've got to talk about poverty in this country.

sentence: We could talk about climate, we could talk about guns, we could talk about all of these issues that we all care about.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: We have a perception problem with the Democratic Party.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: We are not connecting to the working class people in the very states that I represent in Ohio, in the industrial Midwest.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: We've lost all connection.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: We have got to change the center of gravity of the Democratic Party from being coastal and elital -- elitist and Ivy League, which is the perception, to somebody from the forgotten communities that have been left behind for the last 30 years, to get those workers back on our side so we can say we're going to build electric vehicles, we're going to build solar panels.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: But if you want to beat Mitch McConnell, this better be a working-class party.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: If you want to go into Kentucky and take his rear end out, and if you want to take Lindsey Graham out, you've got to have a blue collar party that can go into the textile communities in South Carolina.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: So all I'm saying here...

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: All I'm saying here...

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: All I'm saying is here, if we don't address that fundamental prob with our connection to workers -- white, black, brown, gay, straight -- working-class people...

sentence: ... none of this is going to get done, Chuck.

sentence: I appreciate that question.

sentence: So I've been in Congress 17 years.

sentence: And 12 of those years I've sat on the Armed Services Committee, the Defense Appropriations Committee or the Armed Services Committee.

sentence: And here's why, because these flare-ups distract us from the real problems in the country.

sentence: There's nothing worse than not being heard.

speaker: Tim Ryan

sentence: And I know that because I've represented for 17 years in Congress a forgotten community.

speaker: Tim Ryan
sentence: They've tried to divide us, who's white, who's black, who's gay, who's straight, who's a man, who's a woman.

sentence: And they ran away with all the gold because they divided the working class.

sentence: It's time for us to come together.

sentence: The teacher in Texas, the nurse in New Hampshire, the waitress in Wisconsin, all of us coming together, playing offense with an agenda that lifts everybody up.

sentence: I will only promise you one thing.

sentence: When I walk into that Oval Office every morning, you will not be forgotten.

sentence: America is great, but not everyone can access America's greatness.

sentence: The economic system that used to create $30, $40, $50 an hour jobs that you can have a good, solid middle-class living now force us to have two or three jobs just to get by.

sentence: Now in this discussion already tonight we've talked about taking private health insurance away from union members in the industrial Midwest, we've talked about decriminalizing the border, and we've talked about giving free healthcare to undocumented workers when so many Americans are struggling to pay for their healthcare.

sentence: I quite frankly don't think that that is an agenda that we can move forward on and win.

sentence: We've got to talk about the working class issues, the people that take a shower after work, who haven't had a raise in 30 years --

sentence: Well, if we get our act together, we won't have to worry about it.

sentence: And that's why I'm saying get a chief manufacturing officer, align the environmental incentives with the financial incentives, and make sure that people can actually make money off of the new technologies that are moving forward.

sentence: A new and better economy, a new and better education system, a new and better health care system that focuses on prevention, an education system that focuses on the trauma of our kids.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Well, Anderson, this is my first time on this stage, so I just want to start by reminding everybody that every candidate here is more decent, more coherent, and more patriotic than the criminal in the White House.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But I also want to point out that Anderson's right.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Two years ago, I started the Need to Impeach movement, because I knew there was something desperately wrong at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, that we did have the most corrupt president in the country, and that only the voice and the will of the American people would drag Washington to see it as a matter of right and wrong, not of political expediency.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So, in fact, impeaching and removing this president is something that the American people are demanding.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: They're the voice that counts, and that's who I went to, the American people.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Well, first of all, let me say this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Senator Sanders is right.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: There have been 40 years where corporations have bought this government, and those 40 years have meant a 40-year attack on the rights of working people and specifically on organized labor.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And the results are as shameful as Senator Sanders says, both in terms of assets and in terms of income.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's absolutely wrong.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's absolutely undemocratic and unfair.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I was one of the first people on this stage to propose a wealth tax.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I would undo every Republican tax cut for rich people and major corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But there's something else going on here that is absolutely shameful, and that's the way the money gets split up in terms of earnings.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: As a result of taking away the rights of working people and organized labor, people haven't had a raise -- 90 percent of Americans have not had a raise for 40 years.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If you took the minimum wage from 1980 and just adjusted it for inflation, you get $11 bucks.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If you included the productivity gains of American workers, it would be over $20 bucks.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: There's something wrong here, and that is that the corporations have bought our government.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Our government has failed.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's why I'm running for president, because we're not going to get any of the policies that everybody on this stage wants -- health care, education, Green New Deal, or a living wage...

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: ... unless we break the power of these corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Absolutely.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: As far as I'm concerned, Mr.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Trump's America first program, which involves having no plans, having no process, and having no partners, has proved to be a disaster in Syria, it's proved to be a disaster in terms of our response to Russia's attacking our democracy, and more than that, when we look at the problems around the world, the idea that the United States is going to act unilaterally against a country without the support of our traditional allies makes absolutely no sense.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Let's go to the most important international problem that we're facing, which no one has brought up, which is climate.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We can't solve the climate crisis in the United States by ourselves.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's an international crisis.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've been working on it for 10 years, taking on the corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But we have to work with our allies and our frenemies around the world.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So if you look at what Mr.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Trump is doing, of course he's been bought by the oil and gas companies.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But any problem that we're going to do, but specifically climate, we're going to have to lead the world morally, we're going to have to lead it technologically, financially, and commercially.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: This is the proof that this kind of America first, go-it-alone, trust nobody and be untrustworthy is the worst idea I have ever heard and I would change it on day one in every single light.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Well, I think this is one of the most heartbreaking experiences that America has had, 72,000 people died of opioid overdoses last year, and that's not only a tragedy for them, it's a tragedy for their family and their communities.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And so I think we have to treat this as a health citizens.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We have to move the resources and the support there to try and help people.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But I think that Senator Klobuchar makes a good point.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: The reason I'm running for president is that we have a broken government.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And we have a broken government because corporations have bought it.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And every single one of these conversations is about that broken government.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's about drug companies buying the government and getting what they want.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's about the gun manufacturers buying the government and get what we want.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We need to break the corporate stranglehold on our government.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've put forward actual structural changes, including term limits, a natural referendum, the end to the idea that corporations are people and have the rights of American citizens politically, and make it a lot easier to vote

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: These corporations have taken over our government.

sentence: And 72,000 deaths...

sentence: I started a business from scratch -- one room, no employers -- and built a multi-billion-dollar international business.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We're going to have to show the American people that we don't just know how to tax and have programs to break up companies but also talk about prosperity, talk about investing in the American people, talk about harnessing the innovation and competition of the American private sector.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Trump, I think somebody who can go toe to toe with him and show him to be a fraud and a failure as a businessperson, and a fraud and a failure as a steward of the American economy is going to be necessary.

sentence: He is one.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: His tax plan's a failure.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: His trade war is a failure.

sentence: I would love to take him on as a real businessman and show that, in fact, he's failed the American people, and he has to go.

sentence: So I'm friends with a woman from Denmark, South Carolina, named Deanna Berry, who's fighting for clean water and environmental justice in her community.

sentence: She's a different gender.

sentence: She's a different race.

sentence: But she reminds me of my parents in terms of her courage and her optimism and her honor.

sentence: My mother was a schoolteacher in the New York Public Schools and in the Brooklyn House of Detention.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: My father was the first generation in his family to go to college.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: My grandfather was a plumber.

sentence: He interrupted his law degree to go into the Navy in World War II and he ended up prosecuting the Nazis at Nuremberg.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And when I asked him what that experience meant, he said, when you see something wrong in your society, you fight it from the first day and every single day after.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And that's why I started the Need to Impeach movement two years ago, because there was something terribly wrong at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And over 10 years ago, I saw that there was a terrible threat to the safety and health of every American in terms of the climate crisis.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And I've been fighting those companies with the help of the American people ever since successfully, and that's why I'm running for the president, because our government has failed, it's been bought by corporations, and it's absolutely essential to return power to the people.

sentence: I have been doing exactly what my parents taught me to do, which is to take on the biggest problems in America directly and fight for them every single day.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: What I've done over the last decade is to put together coalitions of ordinary American citizens to take on unchecked corporate power.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We have a broken government in Washington, D.C.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's been purchased by corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Over the last decade, with the help of the American people, we have taken on and beaten the oil companies, we have taken on and beaten the tobacco companies, we have taken on and beaten utilities, we've taken on and beaten the drug companies.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've also built one of the largest grassroots organizations in the United States.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Last year, NextGen America did the largest youth voter mobilization in American history, also, in partnership with seven national unions, knocked on 15 million doors in 2016 and 10 million in 2018.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: What I've done is to try to push power down to the America people, to take power away from the corporations who've bought our government.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And I'm talking now about structural reform in Washington, D.C.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Term limits.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If you want bold change in the United States, you're going to have to have new and different people in charge.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I'm the only person on this stage who will talk about term limits.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Vice President Biden won't.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Senator Sanders won't.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Even Mayor Pete Buttigieg will not talk about term limits and structural change.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I would let the American people pass laws themselves through direct democracy.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's time to push the power back to the people and away from D.C.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Thanks, Andrew.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: When you look at inequality in the United States of America, you have to start with housing.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Where you put your head at night determines so many things about your life.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It determines where your kids go to school.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It determines the air you breathe, where you shop, how long it takes you to get to work.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: What we've seen in California is, as a result of policy, we have millions too few housing units.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And that affects everybody in California.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It starts with a homeless crisis that goes all through the state, but it also includes skyrocketing rents which affect every single working person in the state of California.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I understand exactly what needs to be done here, which is we need to change policy and we need to apply resources here to make sure that we build literally millions of new units.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But the other thing that's going to be true about building these units is, we're going to have to build them in a way that's sustainable, that, in fact, how we build units, where people live has a dramatic impact on climate and on sustainability.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So we are going to have to direct dollars, we're going to have to change policy and make sure that the localities and municipalities who have worked very hard to make sure that there are no new housing units built in their towns, that they have to change that and we're going to have force it, and then we're going to have to direct federal dollars to make sure that those units are affordable so that working people can live in places and not be spending 50 percent of their income on rent.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Rachel, I'm the only person on this stage who will say that climate is the number-one priority for me.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Vice President Biden won't say it.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Senator Warren won't say it.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's a state of emergency, and I would declare a state of emergency on day one.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I would use the emergency powers of the presidency.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I know that we have to do this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've spent a decade fighting and beating oil companies, stopping pipelines, stopping fossil fuel plants, ensuring clean energy across the country.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I know that we have to do this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I also know that we can do this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I would make this the number-one priority of my foreign policy, as well.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We can do this and create literally millions of good-paying union jobs across this country.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I would make sure that my climate policy was led by environmental justice and members of the communities where this society has chosen to put our air and water pollution, which are low-income black and brown communities.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And when we ask, how are we going to pull this country together, how about this: We take on the biggest challenge in history, we save the world, and we do it together.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Do you think that would pull America together?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I do.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Can I respond to that, Rachel?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Look, I came to the conclusion over 10 years ago that climate was the absolute problem of our society and it was the unintended consequence of our whole country being based on fossil fuels.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Everybody in this room has lived in an economy based on fossil fuels.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And we all have to come to the same conclusion that I came to over a decade ago.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If we're waiting for Congress to pass one of the bills -- and I know everybody on this stage cares about this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But Congress has never passed an important climate bill ever.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: This is a problem which continues to get worse.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's why I'm saying it's a state of emergency.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's why I'm saying it's priority one.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If it isn't priority one, it's not going to get done.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And this is something where we absolutely have to address it upfront.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We have to make it the most important thing.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And we can use it to rebuild and reimagine what the United States is.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We can be the moral leaders of the world again, while we clean up our air and water and create millions of good-paying jobs.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I agree exactly with what Bernie said, but I want to talk about how we're going to win in 2020.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I don't mean to change the subject, but I think it's sort of important that the Democratic Party not only beat Donald Trump in 2020 but have a sweeping victory across the country.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And what that's going to mean is turnout.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: In the United States of America, the Democratic Party keeps talking about trying to persuade a few people who are Republicans to like us, when up to half the people don't vote at all because they think neither party tells the truth, no one deals with my issues, the system is broken, why would we vote?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But what we've found at NextGen America is that is the start of a conversation about why votes are so important.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And if you look at 2018 and flipping the House, what really happened was Democratic voting went up by three-quarters.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: In the 38 congressional districts where NextGen America was turning out young people, the turnout went up by more than 100 percent, more than double.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So for us to win, for everybody on this stage, for whoever's the candidate, to have a Senate that's Democratic, for us to have the sweeping victory that we absolutely...

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: ... are going to have next year, it's a turnout question.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We're going to have to tell the truth and we're going to have organize across this country.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Last time I was on this stage, I started by saying that everybody here is more patriotic and more competent than the criminal in the White House.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And I stand by that statement.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But I'm different from everybody else on this stage.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I know that the government in Washington, D.C., is broken.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I know that it's been purchased by corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And I've spent a decade putting together coalitions of ordinary American citizens to beat those corporations.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I'm the only one on this stage who's willing to talk about structural change in Washington itself, term limits, that if we're going to make bold changes, we're going to need new and different people in charge.

sentence: I'm the only person on this stage who will say that climate is my first priority, that it's our biggest challenge, but it's our biggest opportunity to recreate this country.

sentence: I have spent a decade trusting the American people...

sentence: I'm asking you to trust me.

sentence: Well, let me remind everyone that I'm the person who started the Need to Impeach Movement over two years ago because I --

sentence: -- because I believe what counts here is actually the American people's opinion.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Over eight and a half million signed that petition and dragged Washington into the idea that, actually, the most corrupt president in American history -- it's not a question of political expediency, it's not a question of political tactics, it's a question of right and wrong.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So, now, when we look at what's going on, I actually agree with Senator Klobuchar.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: The question here is, if we want the American people to understand what's going on, we need to have the administration officials testify on TV so we can judge.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: The court that counts here is the court of public opinion.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: The American people deserve to see the truth of these administration officials testifying under oath so we can make up our mind.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: If we want Republican senators to do the right thing, we need their constituents to see the truth on TV and tell them, get rid of this guy or we'll get rid of you.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's what I believe in.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I'm a believer in the grassroots as an outsider, getting the American people's voice to count.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's who I trust and that's who I trust now.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So let me say that I agree with Senator Warren in much of what she says.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've been for a wealth tax for over a year.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I'm in favor of undoing all the tax breaks for rich people and big corporations that this administration has put through.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And in addition, I've talked about equilibrating the taxes on passive investment income, which would allow us to cut taxes for 95 percent of Americans by 10 percent.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But there's something else going on here that I think is really important, and that's this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We know Mr.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Trump is going to run on the economy.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I built a business over 30 years from scratch.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We're going to have to take him on, on the economy in terms of growth, as well as economic justice.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We're going to have to be able to talk about growth, prosperity across the board for everyone in America.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: My experience building a business, understanding how to make that happen, means I can go toe-to-toe with Mr.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Trump and take him down on the economy and expose him as a fraud and a failure.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And I think that's different from the other people on this stage.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I think we need a different, unconventional way of attacking a different, unconventional president who actually went after the best-prepared candidate in American history and beat her.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Look, I am hoping that we, in fact, will do what I'm suggesting, which is declare a state of emergency on day one of my presidency.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I have made this -- I believe I'm the only person here who will say unequivocally this is my number-one priority.

speaker: Tom Steyer

sentence: I've taken on oil companies and beaten them on environmental laws.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I've prevented pipelines and I've prevented fossil fuel plants.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But what I know is this: Not only can we clear up the air and water in the black and brown communities where our pollution is concentrated, this is also the opportunity to create literally millions of middle-class union jobs, well-paid, across the United States of America.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Our biggest crisis is our biggest opportunity.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And if we don't declare a state of emergency on day one, I don't understand how we go to the people around the world to lead the coalition that has to happen and that only America can lead.

sentence: Look, this is a generational question.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I have a lot of respect for the people on this stage.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I know everybody is worried about this.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: But, for instance, I would call on Mayor Buttigieg to prioritize this higher because the people in his generation understand that this is a crisis that we have to go on right now, but it's also...

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: ... the greatest opportunity to rebuild and reinvent America.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Look, the point about nuclear power is, it's not at the stage in the United States where it's competitive on price.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It has a lot of risks to it in terms of disasters.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And we have no ability to store the toxins that come out of it and last 100,000 years.

sentence: We actually have the technology that we need.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: It's called wind and solar and batteries.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So, in fact, what we need to do, we can do.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We've got to stop taking a look at this as something that we can't do, because we can do this, and we can do it in a way that creates, rebuilds this country on an accelerated basis, creates millions of union jobs, and we come at it from the standpoint of environmental justice.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: This is our greatest opportunity to reinvent this country, to actually take on the biggest challenge in history and succeed together.

sentence: You want to pull the country together with all this partisanship?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Let's take on the biggest challenge in history and succeed together as a nation.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That's what pulls people together.

sentence: Look, there is a temptation, particularly for this president, to try and answer that on a bilateral -- in a bilateral way.

sentence: People who disturb us, who we disagree with, but who, in effect, we are linked to in a world that is ever getting closer.

sentence: And, in fact, if we are going to treat climate as the threat that it is, we are going to have to partner with the Chinese.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Listen, I am running because this government is broken, because it's purchased by corporations.

sentence: And I've spent 10 years fighting those corporations and beating them and building grassroots organizations to push power down to the people.

sentence: There's someone who is loving this conversation, and his name is Donald Trump.

sentence: He's told us last week he looked at a group of Americans and said, "I don't like you.

speaker: Tom Steyer

sentence: He's a different breed of cat, and we need to beat him.

sentence: ... this corrupt president and beat him on the economy where he thinks he's king and where, in fact, he's a fraud and a failure.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Listen, I think it's important to note that this president is not against immigration.

sentence: He's against immigration by nonwhite people.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: This is his attempt to divide us, as Senator Sanders said, on race.

sentence: He's been trying to inflame his base and scare them that if, in fact, white people lose control of this country, that they're going to lose control of their lives.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And as somebody who lives in a majority-minority state, which is California, what he's doing is so wrong on so many different levels.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: I agree with Senator Sanders.

sentence: We have to go back to the idea that every American is worth being a full human being on every right.

sentence: This is a racial argument by a racist president who's trying to divide us and who's vilifying people.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And it's led him to break the laws of humanity in our name.

sentence: Look, the United States has made a commitment to treat everybody equally.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And that means supporting people with disabilities, both in terms of education and later when they're part of the workforce.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: That means bringing the resources to bear to make sure that we're treating them fairly, in school and after school, to try and integrate them fully and to make them have as full a life as possible.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: The question we've got here across the board is, can we afford to do the kinds of things that Senator Sanders and Senator Warren are pushing?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And the answer is yes, that, in fact, what we need to do is to undo the tax breaks that have been given for two generations to rich Americans and big corporations.

sentence: Last year, the top 400 corporations paid an 11 percent tax.

sentence: That is absolutely ludicrous.

sentence: So the answer on disabilities is a question of focus and money, as so many of these questions are.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: We have a country where the government is broken because corporations have bought it, they're getting their way, and for us to get back to government of, by, and for the people that serves Americans, including Americans with disabilities, we're going to have to take that back.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So, look, this is the holiday season.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And what I'm hearing from every single one of these candidates is that they've gone around the United States and what they've seen from this administration and what they've seen from the Republican Party is cruelty towards the people of the United States for money.

sentence: So when I think about the gift that I'd like to give -- and I've seen that, too.

sentence: I mean, I think it starts with cruelty when children are born and it goes right through life into pre-K, education, health care, a living wage.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: There is cruelty to working people, there is cruelty to seniors.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And so the gift that I would like to give everyone on this stage, which was the original question, is the gift of teamwork.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: Because the question up here is, how are we together going to change this framework?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: How are we together going to beat this corrupt and criminal president?

sentence: How are we going to stand up for the people of the United States together, not by tearing each other down, but by supporting each other and by realizing that what we stand for is the true value of America?

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: And as a team, that's how we're going to do it.

sentence: And as Americans, we're going to come together to stand up for the original values -- freedom, equality, justice, teamwork.

sentence: I'm different from everybody else on this stage, and here's why.

sentence: If you've been listening to this, what we are hearing is 20 years of mistakes by the American government in the Middle East, of failure, of mistakes.

sentence: And if you look who had the judgment, it was a state senator from Illinois with no experience named Barack Obama who opposed the war.

speaker: Tom Steyer
sentence: So I would say to you this: An outside perspective, looking at this and actually dealing with the problems as they are is what we're looking for now.

sentence: I agree with Sen.

speaker: Tom Steyer

sentence: We are spending dramatically too much money on defense.

sentence: The money that we're spending there, we could spend in the other parts of the budget, and it's time for someone from the outside to have a strategic view about what we're trying to do and how to do it.

sentence: I would take military action to protect the lives and safety of American citizens.

sentence: But what we can see in the Middle East and what this conversation shows is that there is no real strategy that we're trying to accomplish in what we're doing in the Middle East.

sentence: So we really have to ask ourselves in the Middle East, what are we trying to accomplish?

sentence: And every single thing we should do should follow into that strategy.

sentence: So every single discussion we've had about Iran has had to do with military power and America versus Iran, whereas, in fact, what worked with President Obama was an alliance of our allies and us putting economic pressure on them for them to give up their military tactic.

sentence: So let me say this.

sentence: I'm the only person on this stage who says climate is my number one priority.

sentence: I would not sign this deal, because if climate is your number one priority, you can't sign a deal, even if it's marginally better for working people until climate is also taken into consideration.

sentence: We cannot put climate on the backseat all the time and say we're going to sign this one more deal, we're going to do one more thing without putting climate first.

sentence: We can do it in a way that makes us richer, but we have to do it.

sentence: Everybody on this stage believes that affordable health care is a right for every single American.
